Thank you for your comment. I'm looking into what details we can share.

A particularly painful thorn in this particular case, since in unit 5.14 Prof. Littman specifically addressed using heaps for Dijkstra and commented, apparently as a hint, that the hardest part would be the 'bookkeeping' that allows heapified Dijkstra code to find a node already in the heap to reduce its value, in constant time.
I spent a fair amount of time writing code that did this, only to find it ran too slowly to meet all the tests, and much slower than much simpler code based on heapq which ignores all bookkeeping other than preventing 'locked-down' values in final_dict from being subsequently overwritten. Indeed, keeping track of the location of an entry in a heap managed by heapq appears impossible without losing the speed advantage heapq offers.
It thus seems, unfortunately, like the hint may have been a red herring, since only heapq-based code seems fast enough to meet all the tests.
I very much hope this doesn't happen on the final!

Yes, Jeff is right - you are on the right path now. Again, just think of the problem as "calculate a median value of a list with n elements in time linear in n". Then consider a definition of the median and see if you know of any algorithms that can solve it in linear time. BTW, the median we are talking about in the literature is often called "sample median" or "statistical median". Here are some details: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/StatisticalMedian.html

No, the HTML and JavaScript parsers will not be fully featured by any sense of the word. Building and maintaining a browser like Firefox costs 100s of millions of dollars a year (we can thank Google for footing the bill). To do CSS you are going to need another set of lexers, parsers, and interpreters and the additional internal structure for the DOM. From the perspective of teaching about programming languages, we don't gain anything from going over CSS and the DOM and we certainly don't have the time to implement the components necessary.

That's definitely possible. We're just showing how you would go about doing optimizations. Arithmetic identities are simple to understand and the "optimizations" are straightforward.

In the real world, it's often the true that an optimization that you put in your code could slow the execution time in certain cases. Sometimes we choose to do an optimization that speeds up the common-case and sacrifice the performance of the rare case. Modern CPU architectures are designed around the principle of making the common-case as fast as possible. Great insight!

# Title: Common Ground
#
# Format: Submit via the Interpreter
#
# Consider the strings "Tapachula" and "Temapache", both of which name
# towns in the country of Mexico. They share a number of substrings in
# common. For exmaple, "T" and "pa" can be found in both. The longest
# common unbroken substring that they both share is "apach" -- it starts
# at position 1 in "Tapachula" and at position 3 in "Temapache". Note that
# "Tapach" is not a substring common to both: even though "Temapache"
# contains both "T" and "apach", it does not contain the unbroken substring
# "Tapach". 
#
# Finding the longest common substring of two strings is an important
# problem in computer science. It is a building block to related problems,
# such as "sequence alignment" or "greatest common subsequence" that are
# used in problem domains as diverse as bioinformatics and making spelling
# checkers. 
#
# We will use memoization, recursion and list comprehensions to tackle this
# problem. In particular, we will build up a chart that stores computed
# partial answers. 
#
# To make the problem a bit easier, we'll start by computing the longest
# common *suffix* of two strings. For example, "Tapachula" and "Temapache"
# have no common suffix -- or a common suffix of length 0, if you prefer.
# By contrast, "Tapach" and "Temapach" have a longest common suffix of
# length 5 ("apach"). One way to reason to that is that their last letters
# match (an "h" in both cases) -- and if you peel those last letters off
# the smaller problem of "Temapac" vs. "Tapac" has a common suffix of size
# four. 
#
# Write a memoized procedure csuffix(X,Y) that returns the size of the
# longest common suffix of two strings X and Y. This is 0 if X and Y have
# different final letters. Otherwise, it is 1 plus csuffix() of X and Y,
# each with that common last letter removed. Use a global dictionary chart
# that maps (X,Y) pairs to their longest common suffix values to avoid
# recomputing work. If either X or Y is the empty string, csuffix(X,Y) must
# return 0. 
#
# Once we have csuffix(), we can find the largest common substring of X and
# Y by computing the csuffix() of all possible combinations of *prefixes*
# of X and Y and returning the best one. Write a procedure prefixes(X) that
# returns a list of all non-empty strings that are prefixes of X. For
# example, prefixes("cat") == [ "c", "ca", "cat" ]. 
#
# Finally, write a procedure lsubstring(X,Y) that returns the length of the
# longest common substring of X and Y by considering all prefixes x of X
# and all prefixes y of Y and returning the biggest csuffix(x,y)
# encountered.

# Hint 1. Reminder: "hello"[-1:] == "o"
#
# Hint 2. Reminder: "goodbye"[:-1] == "goodby" 
#
# Hint 3. suffices(X) can be written in one line with list comprehensions.
# Consider "for i in range(len(X))". 
#
# Hint 4. max([5,-2,8,3]) == 8
#
# Hint 5. You can "comprehend" two lists at once! 
#       [ (a,b) for a in [1,2] for b in ['x','y'] ]
#               == [(1, 'x'), (1, 'y'), (2, 'x'), (2, 'y')]
# This is by no means necessary, but it is convenient.

chart = { }
def csuffix(X,Y):
        if (X,Y) in chart:
                return chart[(X,Y)] # memoization!
        else:
                # fill in your code here 
                answer = 0 
                if X != "" and Y != "" and X[-1:] == Y[-1:]:
                        answer = 1 + csuffix(X[:-1],Y[:-1])
                chart[(X,Y)] = answer # memoization
                return answer

def prefixes(X):
        # Fill in your code here (can be done in one or two lines). 
        return [ X[:i+1] for i in range(len(X)) ]
        # The +1 is so that we get "c" "ca" "cat" instead of
        # "" "c" "ca".

def lsubstring(X,Y):
        # Fill in your code here (can be done in one or two lines).
        return max([csuffix(i,j) for i in prefixes(X) for j in prefixes(Y)])

# We have included some test cases. You will likely want to write your own.
print lsubstring("Tapachula", "Temapache") == 5  # Mexico, "apach"
print chart[("Tapach","Temapach")] == 5
print lsubstring("Harare", "Mutare") == 3        # Zimbabwe, "are" 
print chart[("Harare","Mutare")] == 3
print lsubstring("Iqaluit", "Whitehorse") == 2   # Canada, "it" 
print chart[("Iqaluit","Whit")] == 2
print lsubstring("Prey Veng", "Svay Rieng") == 3 # Cambodia, "eng" 
print chart[("Prey Ven","Svay Rien")] == 2
print chart[("Prey Veng","Svay Rieng")] == 3
print lsubstring("Aceh", "Jambi") == 0           # Sumatra, ""
print chart[("Aceh", "Jambi")] == 0
print lsubstring("Andacity","Petedacity")
print lsubstring("Sean","Archaeologuess")

Thank you guys. Next time I will only print the requested answer.

Regarding the question 1.8, yes, I enter the code in the correct position.

Cheers :)

title: Solutions to 7.8  - Same structure

I thought this was a neat question, too. Here is my solution:

def same_structure(a,b):
    if a == []:
        return b == []
    if b == []:
        return a == []
    elif not is_list(a) and not is_list(b):
        return True
    elif is_list(a) and is_list(b):
        return same_structure(a[0], b[0]) and same_structure(a[1:], b[1:])
    else:
        return False

title: Well. Those badges are sure hard to get...
body: Look at the Badges page! Those are really hard to get! Not that it really matters.

1) The lexer is importing re as he handles the procedure you right. You're not actually doing anything with a regular expression in that code, but rather only declaring a raw string.

2) When a string is the first line like that, it's being assigned as the functions' docstring and accessible programmatically by calling t_WHATEVER.doc and this is exactly what the lexer does. On a separate note, most languages I'm familiar with don't mind if you just leave anonymous values lying around, mostly because it's difficult to tell if that line has side-effects.

3) The lexer automatically checks if the token matches the regular expression, and if it does it calls that procedure feeding in the token as an argument.

4) Once we have a bunch of these we'll be able to parse our JavaScript and HTML into meaningful units and not just a sequence of characters.

pass is Python for "do nothing". If pass is the last line of a procedure it happens to be the same as return None, but you can put a pass anywhere.

Michael, I understand the difference. I was under impression that the first problem is usually called "k-coloring problem" and the second "chromatic number problem". The first is obviously in NP but it is not so clear about the second one. At the same time I remember that "chromatic number problem" was one of the original NP-complete problems presented by Karp in his seminal paper published in 70s (look at page 95). It is also listed as such in Wikipedia's list of NP-complete problems. I had this at the back of my mind from prior studies. What I did not realize though that apparently there is a terminological disagreement about what to call a "chromatic number problem". As it is obvious from carefully reading Karp's paper what he calls a "chromatic number problem" is generally known as a "k-coloring problem", i.e. problem of verifying that graph can be colored with k colors. On the other hand, WolframAlfa article states (unambiguously this time) that chromatic number problem is NP-complete and references Skiena's text:

The chromatic number of a graph $%G$% is also the smallest positive integer $%z$% such
that the chromatic polynomial $%\pi_{G}(z)>0$%. Calculating the chromatic number of a graph is
an NP-complete problem (Skiena 1990, pp. 211-212).

It now appears to me that WolframAlfa just screwed this up (I don't have Skiena book handy to verify the source).

I think I've got it; instead of calculating the cost of the new possible path by adding the actual path cost and the new weight, I calculate it by choosing the maximum of the actual path cost and the new weight, The distance of the final path is going to be the maximum of is weights, ie: the obscurity value

by definition, the mean and standard deviation of standard scores are 0 and 1.

we can calculate b for the standard x and y scores; b = [sum(Zxi - mean(Zx))*(Zyi - mean(Zy))] / sum(Zxi - mean(Zx))^2

title: Homework3: Correct solutions
body:
HW3.1 Lists

If nothing else, this one is relatively easy to solve by bruteforce using few lines of Python code. The "bruteforceless" solution is relatively easy as well.

Let's take it from the end:

  • We want p[2] to be 3. At the time of setting p[2], both p[0] and p[1] should have their final correct values, i.e. 1 and 2, respectively. Thus, this one will resolve itself if we got right the rest.
  • Next one is p[1], which should be set to 2. At the time, when it is assigned its final value, p[0] should be final as well and thus we can be sure, it will equal 1. Calculating initial value of p[2] is then as easy as p[2] = 2 - 1, which is 1.
  • The last one is p[0], which should be set to 1. Its value will be calculated as its original value plus value of p[1]. This means that p[0] and p[1] should be initially set to any two values, which add up to 1. Therefore, there is infinite number of solutions, e.g. 0,1 or 1,0 or -1,2 etc.

Chosen solution might be checked with this simple code (copy-pasted from the homework assignment):

p = [0,1,1]

p[0] = p[0] + p[1]
p[1] = p[0] + p[2]
p[2] = p[0] + p[1]

print p # => [1,2,3]

HW3.2 Mutating Lists

Procedure #1:

def proc1(p):
  p[0] = p[1]

As explained in Unit3.13 Replace Spy, this procedure will clearly modify its argument. In case it is not clear to you, look again at videos 7 to 13 in Unit 3.

It should be noted, that this function will not even work with lists of less than 2 elements. However, this fact has nothing to do with the question being asked.

Procedure #2:

def proc2(p):
  p = p + [1]

This one does not modify the original argument. That is because the + operator creates new instance of list object and makes p to refer to that new instance.

Procedure #3:

def proc3(p):
  q = p
  p.append(3)
  q.pop()

This will indeed modify the argument, but it will also undo all the changes done. When you look closer at it, you will find out that q and p are referencing the same instance of list object, thus the element (integer 3) appended using p "alias", will be popped-out using q "alias", which will leave the original list in the exactly the same state as it was in the beginning.

Procedure #4:

def proc4(p):
q = []
while p:
q.append(p.pop())
while q:
p.append(q.pop())

This one is the most interesting of all four. It will gradually pop-out all elements from p and append them to the different list, referenced by q. The q-list will contain all elements from p, just in the opposite order and p will be left empty. Then, whole process is repeated again in the opposite direction: elements are gradually popped-out from q and appended to p, leaving q empty again and p with all elements from q, just in the opposite order. Lot's of work done, big pile of bricks moved from one heap (LIFO stack in fact) to another and then back, but the result is exactly the same as if nothing was done at all.

You can test it by running the code below:

def proc1(p):
  p[0] = p[1]

def proc2(p):
  p = p + [1]

def proc3(p):
  q = p
  p.append(3)
  q.pop()

def proc4(p):
  q = []
  while p:
    q.append(p.pop())
  while q:
    p.append(q.pop())

def init():
  ret = []
  for i in range(10):
    ret.append(i)
  return ret
def init():
  ret = []
  for i in range(10):
    ret.append(i)
  return ret

a = init()
proc1(a)
print "1:", a

a = init()
proc2(a)
print "2:", a

a = init()
proc3(a)
print "3:", a

a = init()
proc4(a)
print "4:", a

HW3.3 Product List:

This is the first assignment from series with subtitle "Setting initial value correctly" (HW3.3, HW3.4 and HW3.5). It is also about for-loop, but it can be solved also using while-loop from Unit2 (and I think that if one grasps concept of while-loop, then for-loop is about the same, just with slightly different syntax and actually easier).

Regarding the initial value, there was very nice answer from @larry96 in this thread. This information just needs to be written down:

#Define a procedure, product_list,
#takes as input a list of numbers,
#and returns a number that is
#the result of multiplying all
#those numbers together.

#product_list([9]) => 9
#product_list([1,2,3,4]) => 24

def product_list(p):

  # set the initial value to 1 - not 0, not anything else (see fnenu's post)
  product = 1

  # go through all values in the list and sequentialy multiply them
  for val in p:
    product = product * val

  # finally return the computed value
  return product

The equivalent solution using while instead of for would look as ugly as this (that is why we have for-loops):

def product_list(p):

  # set the initial value to 1 - not 0, not anything else (see fnenu's post)
  product = 1

  # initialize loop-controlling variables
  i = 0
  length = len(p)  # see Unit3.15 and Unit3.16 for explanation of len() function

  # go through all values in the list (from its beginning to its end)
  # and sequentialy multipy them
  while i < length:
    product = product * p[i]
    i = i + 1  # I am constantly forgetting to write put this line in

  $ finally return the computed value
  return product

This assignment is yet another example of noticing how are you doing it manually as I mentioned in HW2 post:

  • You note down the product you have at the beginning (i.e. 1).
  • Then you go through all elements of the list, one by one
  • And for each of them, you overwrite your noted product by new number computed as <noted-down value> * <element value>
  • At the end, you have the final result written in your note

HW3.4 Greatest:

The second one from "Setting initial value correctly" series. It reminds me of very simillar example in Stroustrup's book, where he is computing minimum temperature measured at some place during one month and mistakenly sets the initial maximum value to zero. And then winter month, with all temperatures below zero comes... (Disclaimer: The example was not exactly this one, but I have borrowed my copy of that book to one of my friends and I do not remember it exactly - message is the same, however.)

#Define a procedure, greatest,
#that takes as input a list
#of positive numbers, and
#returns the greatest number
#in that list. If the input
#list is empty, the output
#should be 0.

#greatest([4,23,1]) => 23
#greatest([]) => 0

def greatest(p):

  # at first check for empty list
  if not p:
    return 0

  # this is the best initial value I can think of,
  # however 0 would do as well in this assignment,
  # because "takes as input a list of POSITIVE numbers"
  max = p[0]

  # go through all the values in the list
  for val in p:

    # and if some of them is higher than any of them before
    if max < val:
      # update the maximum value
      max = val

  # finally, return result
  return max

It is actually not necessary to cycle also through the first element of the list, since variable max was initially set to its value, but it would be pretty ugly to use while-loop (see HW3.3) and other means of doing it were not yet discussed in lectures.

To repeat myself again, all you need to do is carefully observe all the steps you do, while computing the result manually:

  • You note down the initial value (0 is sufficient here, but the value of the first element, or at least negative infinity, i.e. the lowest possible value, would be better in general).
  • Then you go through all elements of the list, one by one
  • And for each of them, you compare the noted-down value with the element's value.
  • In case the element's value is higher than the noted-down value, you overwrite noted-down value by the element's value.
  • At the end, you have the final result written in your note

HW3.5 Lists of Lists:

And finally the concluding part of the series. However, this one is, besides for loop, also about lists of lists. It is about understanding the concept of list-inside-a-list and for-loop going through elements of a list.

#Define a procedure, total_enrollment,
#that takes as an input a list of elements,
#where each element is a list containing
#three elements: a university name,
#the total number of students enrollect,
#and the annual tuition.

#The procedure should return two numbers,
#not a string,
#giving the total number of students
#enrolled at all of the universities
#in the list, and the total tuition
#(which is the sum of the number
#of students enrolled times the
#tuition for each university).

udacious_univs = [['Udacity',90000,0]]

usa_univs = [ ['California Institute of Technology',2175,37704],
              ['Harvard',19627,39849],
              ['Massachusetts Institute of Technology',10566,40732],
              ['Princeton',7802,37000],
              ['Rice',5879,35551],
              ['Stanford',19535,40569],
              ['Yale',11701,40500]  ]

#>>> print total_enrollment(udacious_univs)
#(90000,0)

#>>> print total_enrollment(usa_univs)
#(77285,3058581079L)

def total_enrollment(univs):

  # be sure that you choose correct initial values
  # (we are going to produce sum, thus initially we need 0)
  students = 0
  tuition = 0

  # go through all elements of the list
  for val in univs:

    # elements of the list turn out to be lists, again:
    # - there is number of enrolled students at index 1
    students = students + val[1]

    # - and annual tuition per student at index 2
    #   (parentheses around multiplication are actually not needed,
    #    but they do no harm and I have a rule, which works very well
    #    for me quite a few years already: "If you are not 100% sure
    #    about operator precedences, use parentheses.")
    tuition = tuition + (val[1] * val[2])

  # function returns not one, but two values (see Unit2.6)
  return students, tuition

I will not repeat the "observe your manual steps" story again, because it is the same all the time and this post is getting long anyway (In case someone is interested in it anyway, please post a note and I will write it to you as a reply.) What I will do, though, is that I will stress again that there are quite a lot of problems, which can be solved just using this very simple "technique".

HW3.6 Max Pages:

I can imagine that this one would look pretty scary at the first glance, but it turns out that it is not that bad. The only thing, which needs to be done is to introduce a counter of pages, which has been crowled, initialize it to 0 at the start ({1}), increment it for each page we crawl ({2}) and add condition, which will stop us when the counter reaches desired value ({3}).

#Modify the crawl_web procedure
#to take a second parameter,
#max_pages, that limits the
#number of pages to crawl.
#Your procedure should
#terminate the crawl after
#max_pages different pages
#have been crawled, or when
#there are no more pages to crawl.

def crawl_web(seed,max_pages):
  tocrawl = [seed]
  crawled = []

  # {1}: no pages have been crawled, yet
  pages = 0

  # {3}: the second part of condition
  while tocrawl and pages < max_pages:

    page = tocrawl.pop()
    if page not in crawled:
      union(tocrawl, get_all_links(get_page(page)))
      crawled.append(page)

      # {2}: a page has been crawled, increment counter
      pages = pages + 1

  return crawled

HW3.7 Max Depth:

This is where homework #3 starts to be challenging. In fact, I think that this two-star assignment is more difficult than HW3.8, which had three stars.

The basic thing, which needs to be solved here is how to store the current depth value, which needs to be compared against desired maximum. One possible, and very obvious to someone, with programming experience, is to make crawl_web function recursively call itself, just with max_depth lowered by one, for each URL returned by get_all_links function, until it needs to make call with max_depth < 0. We would not even need tocrawl variable anymore, but we would need to pass crawled (or make it global variable, which is kind of ugly) - it is thus not viable solution, here, because we do not want to modify crawl_web's header.

The thing about recursion is, each and every recursive function has its non-recursive equivalent using loops. The very same applies to above described solution:

#TWO GOLD STARS#

#Modify the crawl_web procedure
#to take a second parameter,
#max_depth, that limits the
#minimum number of consecutive
#links that would need to be followed
#from the seed page to reach this
#page. For example, if max_depth
#is 0, the only page that should
#be crawled is the seed page.
#If max_depth is 1, the pages
#that should be crawled are the
#seed page and every page that links
#to it directly. If max_depth is 2,
#the crawl should also include all pages
#that are linked to by these pages.

def crawl_web(seed,max_depth):
tocrawl = [[0,[seed]]]
crawled = []

while tocrawl:
  pages = tocrawl.pop()
  add_tocrawl = []
  for page in pages[1]:  # {1}
    if page not in crawled:
      if pages[0] < max_depth: # {2}
        union(add_tocrawl, get_all_links(get_page(page)))
      crawled.append(page)
  if add_tocrawl: # {3}
    tocrawl.append([pages[0]+1, add_tocrawl])

return crawled

The depth of each URL (actually, of each set of URLs) is stored directly in tocrawl variable. Its format goes like this:

tocrawl = [[<depth1>,
           [<url11>, <url12>, ..., <url1N>]],

           [<depth2>,
           [<url21>, <url22>, ..., <url2N>]],

           ...

           [<depthN>,
           [<urlN1>, <urlN2>, ..., <urlNN>]]]

This is not particularily nice, but it works and it can be written much nicer using classes and other tools of the language, which were not yet discussed in the lecture.

The rest of modifications to the function, after we solved the biggest problem of storing depth, is relatively straight forward. We need to add for-loop ({1}) to go through all URLs in pages[1] - that is new place for storing list of URLs to be crawled (pages[0] stores their depth - see above). The second modification is augmentation of algorithm for adding URLs to tocrawl list. We want to do that only in case we did not reach our max_depth, yet ({2}). Because we have changed structure of tocrawl, we do not want to add URLs to it right after we find them - we want to collect as many as we can into the add_tocrawl, mark them all with the depth value and insert whole such "package" (if it is not empty, of course) into tocrawl variable ({3}).

It should be noted, that above described solution is not the simplest one. It is not necessary to use an optimization, I have used, i.e. each URL might have its own depth-tag. In that case, for-loop ({1}) nor add_tocrawl variable would not be needed.

HW3.8 Sudoku:

Note: I posted my "unit-test" in this thread. Just copy-paste the code at the end of your code and run it.

There was lot of discussion about 9-lines long solutions. I did not try to provide one so I do not know how does it look like and thus I can not judge it. However, I would like to emphasize that the better measure of code quality are its readability and complexity. Do not take me wrong, however - it was explicitely stated by several people in that discussion that they agree with this and that the thread's purpose is just to provide kind of brain teaser for more experienced students (which is only commendable).

One more interesting thing in that discussion was post by @PeterUdacity, who wrote that in real Pythonic way, it can be done just on 4 lines of code. And this is very true, because in real life, you do not try to reinvent the wheel. There are lots of libraries out there, which can be used freely - and that is the "Pythonic way": "I just imported antigravity"... Thus I would say that this 4-liner would look something like this (Disclaimer: I just know that there is some sudoku library for Python, but I do not know anything about it, thus the below code is just an example):

1  import sudoku
2  
3  def check_sudoku(sudoku):
4    return sudoku.check(sudoku)

Anyway, my solution (those, who do have mentioned 9-liners correct, please paste them in answers, and especially, I would like to ask @Angel to past his solution, which I was reading handles many very interesting cases) goes like this:

#Define a procedure, check_sudoku,
#that takes as input a square list
#of lists representing an n x n
#sudoku puzzle solution and returns
#True if the input is a valid
#sudoku square and returns False
#otherwise.

#A valid sudoku square satisfies these
#two properties:

#   1. Each column of the square contains
#       each of the numbers from 1 to n exactly once.

#   2. Each row of the square contains each
#       of the numbers from 1 to n exactly once.

def check_sudoku(sudoku):
  n = len(sudoku)
  if n < 1:
    return False

  for i in range(n):
    if len(sudoku[i]) != n:
      return False

    row_chk = []
    col_chk = []

    for k in range(n):
      row_chk.append(False)
      col_chk.append(False)

    for j in range(n):
      row_val = sudoku[i][j]
      if row_val < 1 or n < row_val or row_chk[row_val-1]:
        return False
      else:
        row_chk[row_val-1] = True

      col_val = sudoku[j][i]
      if col_val < 1 or n < col_val or col_chk[col_val-1]:
        return False
      else:
        col_chk[sudoku[j][i]-1] = True

  return True

We just go through all rows and columnsi ({1}) (in the same time - there is no point to do it twice, first time for rows and second time for columns, but this does not make much of a difference) and use auxiliary variables row_chk and col_chk to check that each row and each column contain one and exactly one occurence of each number from set {1 .. n}. Initially, those two auxiliary variables are set to be lists, containing only False values ({2}) and each time we find some number, we set corresponding False to True ({3}).

All the rest are just "paranoid" sanity checks (which, and much more of them, are really required in real-life scenario). E.g. we are checking value being out of range (otherwise, the algorithm would crash on "index out of range" error) ({4}).
@Michele Calgaro: Actually, reduction is introduced exactly at the beginning of unit 6-9. In fact, unit 6-9 title is "Reduction: Long and Simple path" so I do not understand why you were so puzzled.

body:
On Question 24 I wrote my program a little differently than in the answer key. It was marked as correct but I keep getting all of the values until the number (n) and then I get 'None'. Can someone tell me what is actually going on and where I'm wrong in my thinking?

def print_numbers(n):

    i=i+1
    print i

print print_numbers(9)

returns
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8

None
Please! Search!!!

it will not work for any inputs

for example

print stamps(8.)

we will get

(1.6000000000000001, 0.0, 0.0)

mine solution is:

def stamps(num):
   p1 = num % 5 % 2
   p2 = (num - p1) %  5 / 2
   p5 = (num - p1 - p2 * 2) / 5
   return p5, p2, p1

PS. operator % was introduced at least in HomeWork2-5: if n % 2 == 0: # the % means remainder, so this tests if n is even

title: Unit 5-9 solution can be improved
body:
Specifically, lines 13-14 are useless because condition at line 13 is never True. This is due to the fact that 'me', after applying action (roll/hold), is the player out of turn (i.e. paused), so it cannot be the winner (since its score does not change). Therefore it is sufficient to check for the value of 'you', that is state[2], as in the code below, since only 'you' can be the winner:

def play_pig_mine(A, B):
state=0,0,0,0
h={A:B,B:A}
strategy=B
while state[2]<goal:
    strategy=h[strategy]
    if strategy(state)=='hold':
        state=hold(state)
    else:
        state=roll(state,random.randint(1,6))
return h[strategy]

In my opinion it would have been more natural to assume 'me' and 'you' as two static separate players, instead of making 'me' the player always 'on turn'.

title: For the frustrated people and TAs
body:
Hi i read some post from people frustrated with this course, well i join them but add that you should not give up and continue the course, even if you don't get a certificate, you can algwais learn some new trick or tip from the videos and Andy's corner is very usufull for people with basic programing skills.

I studied programing 7 years ago but i'm working as a IT so i consider my self a newbe programmer too, i'm too rusty 7 years without writting code is a very long time. I feel like theres a really big step between CS101 and this course, i think this sould be a CS313 and CS212 should be covering topics like:

Object oriented programming: This wasn't cover in CS101 and i think this is very important for newcomers to know because is the next step to functional programming, when you learn OOP, you really start seeing thing from another perspective, concepts like reusing your code really come alive, doing wrapper libraries for more coplex libraries becomes easier etc.

input/output: how to interact with files, internet(meaning sockets) and hardware (only a basic intro, and i know this is very dificult to grade in an online system), in the search engine we saw a basic intro to interacting with internet and i thinks this is one of this things that get people really insterested in programming, when you know how interact with the rest of the computer you really start scripting for your daily problems, you have a folder full of photos and want to automate the name, you write a script for that, you want your search engine to respond to some comands remotly, you open a socket and wait for commands (well it's more than that but you know), you want to make a powerfull robot to control earth, comunicate with arduino truoght python

timing and optimization: well i haven't saw this in any programing book i ever read (that's provably cos i need to read more) and is how to manage time in your aplications. First use time, if you want to make a musical aplication you need time cos music is notes over time, if you want to make a game you need to refresh the screen every amount of time and this bring me to the second, you don't want your programn to take forever to do somenthing, so understanding time will help you do better programs, we saw a basic introduction to this in CS101 when we meassured the time it took to run the search functions, and i think this is a very good topic and we should go deeper to learn how to optimizate your code, and learnig concepts like events and interrupts are very usefull to take your projects to a more advance leve. So learning how to use python cprofile would be very usufull.
http://docs.python.org/library/profile.html

multythreads: this is posible in python too, well at least as an introducction, if you want serious multythreads you want to use pypy i think. This is one of those topics that people should be introduce to since is one of those thing that make your programs "proffessional", real programs work in this way you have various threads that do different things, like file i/o (wich is slow) and other thread let you keep using the program while you save your file, this gives you a sensation of multitasking, then the threads sync and so on. This and how to run code in parallel (for multicore machines) is great suplemental material for the cryptography course and for mathematicians and phycisist and all the people that need to solve really computational expensive problems and don't know about programming.

GUI programming: This is provably an entire course of it's own but i think it's worth mentioning that with libraries like GTK or QT you can write graphical programs for windows,linux and mac in python, pygame is also worth mentioning.

Well that's what i think it would be a good continuation of the CS101 some of them are more posible to teach in an online eviroment than others, and if someone have more ideas or can add or correct thing that i said, please post since this is very constructive for the teachers at udacity, I only ask for politness since the teachers are working very hard to make this plataform so we can suggest but not demand.

Finally i would like to thank all the people that make possible udacity, i'm enjoing a lot the courses and i would visit as much as i can.

PS: sorry for the misspelling and blurry explanations i do speak english but it's not my native tonge

a macro-based implementation sounds great.. I was hoping that someone would find the idea useful and then adapt it according to his/her preferences. I agree with your comment about using the ptr twice.. it is effective but I do not like it. I tried different options but what ended up happening was that my allocations became buried in libraries and now I seldom have a need to use safe_malloc() directly so it stop bothering me. The benefits are still there, though. All I have to do is to use malloc_objects_num() at the end of the program.

Another possible advantage of using macros is that you could have it work as a normal malloc() or as safe_malloc() depending on a flag. There are some pathological data structures, llke double-linked lists, that use mallocs so often that it might make sense to use safe_malloc() only while developing the application and then, once you are reasonably sure that there is no memory leak, go back to the normal malloc to avoid the penalty of calling an additional function and the cost of the addition or substraction every time that the 'safe' routines are called.

At this point, everything that can be done has been done so let's hope for a successful and spectacular landing. BTW, the time during which the rover enters Mars athmosphere until it radios back to Earth is widely considered as the most dangerous part of the mission. The capsule losses communication with Earth while the parachutes, rockets, pyros and everything else has to work perfectly and autonomously, decelerating from 12,000 miles/hr to zero in 7 mins. In technical terms, it is known as EDL, i.e., Entry, Descend and Landing; in non-technical terms, it is known as the 'seven minutes of terror'. There is a nice video about the EDL of Phoenix, who landed safely on Mars a few years ago, that can gives an idea of what the rover will go through.

title: little mistake in video

I'm a TLC engineer
Athens, Greece

@Sean Mahoney x-bar represents the mean of the sample that we have drawn. What about mu? One of the conclusions of the central limit theorem is that the mean of all the sample means will be the same as the mean of the original population. So, mu is technically mu-sub-xbar, but since that is equal to mu we just write that.

So what we are doing is comparing our sample mean with the mean of all possible sample means that could be drawn from this population (for samples of size 36). And then we are assessing how unusual this occurance is by converting it to standardized score, i.e. by dividing by sigma/sqrt(n). Here we are assuming that the original distribution has a std. deviation of sigma, but the std. deviation of the sampling distribution is sigma/sqrt(n).

The concept of a sampling distribution is really deep and takes time to digest. Kudos to you for trying to understand this and not take it at face value. As we are trying to make a decision about the population mean by using a sample, it really helps to know about the sampling distribution. If we know the mean and the std. deviation of the sampling distribution, we can figure out how far out along the normal curve the sample occurrance that we have observed falls, which in turn will help with the final decision.

"I believe we have an average of means (in your example this average is 10.8) and we therefore have to use an average of the variances for each sample. That is why we have to divide by sigma/sqrt(n) right?
"
10.8 is the mean of just one sample. But, we are comparing this sample mean with all the sample means that could be drawn from this population. That's why we are using sigma/sqrt(n). By the way, if we pick a sample of just 1, sigma/sqrt(n) would be just sigma. As the sample size (n) gets larger, sigma/sqrt(n) gets smaller, which should make sense since the mean of larger samples will be more reliable and won't fluctuate as much.

"Could we also calculate a z value for each laptop and add take that average?" This will lead to (xbar-mu)/ sigma which is not the correct formula for samples of size larger than 1.

title: Final Exam Probem 7.3 Starred - What is wrong with my code? Peter please check
body:
I am just creating a new post here for an older question that I posted inquiring why my code for problem 7.3 starred has been marked wrong although I got the right answers for all test cases including the many ones that were posted in this forum. Many people responded (and I really appreciate their responses and help especially @sudha) and I was supposed to hear back from Peter, and it has been three days now and no answer. So, I am just creating this new post hoping that Peter would see it and provide me with some feedback. Here is my code again:

def multi_lookup(index, query):
    urls = []
    if (len(query) != 0):
        decision = lookup(index, query[0])
        if(decision == None):
            return []
        for i in range(1, len(query)):
            descrip = lookup(index, query[i])
            if(descrip == None):
                return []
            decision = check_same(decision, descrip)
        for i in range(len(decision)):
            if decision[i][0] not in urls:
                urls.append(decision[i][0])
    return urls

def check_same(s, t):
    exist = []
    for descrip1 in s:
        for descrip2 in t:
            if (descrip1[0] == descrip2[0]) and ((descrip2[1] - descrip1[1]) == 1):
                exist.append(descrip2)
    return exist

def crawl_web(seed): # returns index, graph of inlinks
    tocrawl = [seed]
    crawled = []
    graph = {}  # <url>, [list of pages it links to]
    index = {} 
    while tocrawl: 
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            content = get_page(page)
            add_page_to_index(index, page, content)
            outlinks = get_all_links(content)
            graph[page] = outlinks
            union(tocrawl, outlinks)
            crawled.append(page)
    return index, graph

def get_next_target(page):
    start_link = page.find('<a href=')
    if start_link == -1: 
        return None, 0
    start_quote = page.find('"', start_link)
    end_quote = page.find('"', start_quote + 1)
    url = page[start_quote + 1:end_quote]
    return url, end_quote

def get_all_links(page):
    links = []
    while True:
        url, endpos = get_next_target(page)
        if url:
            links.append(url)
            page = page[endpos:]
        else:
            break
    return links

def union(a, b):
    for e in b:
        if e not in a:
            a.append(e)

def add_page_to_index(index, url, content):
    words = content.split()
    for i in range(len(words)):
        add_to_index(index, words[i], i, url)

def add_to_index(index, keyword, pos, url):
    if keyword in index:
        index[keyword].append([url, pos])
    else:
        index[keyword] = [[url, pos]]

def lookup(index, keyword):
    if keyword in index:
        return index[keyword]
    else:
        return None

cache = {
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/multi.html': """<html>
<body>

<a href="http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html">A</a><br>
<a href="http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html">B</a><br>

</body>
""", 
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html': """<html>
<body>

Monty likes the Python programming language
Thomas Jefferson founded the University of Virginia
When Mandela was in London, he visited Nelson's Column.

</body>
</html>
""", 
   'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html': """<html>
<body>

Monty Python is not about a programming language
Udacity was not founded by Thomas Jefferson
Nelson Mandela said "Education is the most powerful weapon which you can
use to change the world."
</body>
</html>
""", 
}

def get_page(url):
    if url in cache:
        return cache[url]
    else:
        print "Page not in cache: " + url
        return None

#Here are a few examples from the test site:
index, graph = crawl_web('http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/multi.html')

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python'])
#>>> ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html']

print multi_lookup(index, ['Monty', 'Python'])
#>>> ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html']

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python', 'programming', 'language'])
#>>> ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html']

print multi_lookup(index, ['Thomas', 'Jefferson'])
#>>> ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/b.html', 'http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html']

print multi_lookup(index, ['most', 'powerful', 'weapon'])
#>>> ['http://www.udacity.com/cs101x/final/a.html']

print multi_lookup(index, ['most', ''])

print multi_lookup(index, ['not_exist'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['python'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python', 'not_exist'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['not_exist', 'Python'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python', 'Python'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python','Monty'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['Python', 'language', 'programming'])

print multi_lookup(index, ['Monty', 'Python', 'is', 'not', 'about', 'a'])

Thank you very much.

Interesting! I used two test harnesses: (1) make_random_graph given by @Job and (2) make_mc_graph based on @Michele's test2 graph generator. As the graph becomes denser, the position-based implementation becomes faster. When the graph is not very dense, my implementation is faster. The three implementations I compared are mine (without heapq), D's (without heapq D) and Michele's (without heapq MC).

In hindsight, this is obvious since my implementation adds the same node to heap multiple times and just ignores some values (this problem will be exacerbated in dense graphs).

using make_random_graph to generate random graphs
avg of time taken for 10 trials of 100 size graph, without heapq/with heapq: 2.818, without heapq D/with heapq: 2.831, without heapq MC/with heapq: 9.515
avg of time taken for 10 trials of 300 size graph, without heapq/with heapq: 2.964, without heapq D/with heapq: 3.182, without heapq MC/with heapq: 11.187
avg of time taken for 10 trials of 600 size graph, without heapq/with heapq: 3.065, without heapq D/with heapq: 3.302, without heapq MC/with heapq: 11.810

Thanks for letting me know! It's SERIOUSLY appreciated. Here, have some karma.
Turns out in most cases it had nothing to do with timing out, but rather just incorrect submissions.

Here's the official solution:

def nfsmsim(string,current,edges,accepting): 
        if string == "":
                return current in accepting
        else:
                letter = string[0:1]
                if (current,letter) in edges:  
                        remainder = string[1:]
                        newstates = edges[(current,letter)]
                        for newstate in newstates:
                                if nfsmsim(remainder,newstate,edges,accepting):
                                        return True
                return False

Better thinking, you're right... It doesn't make a difference after all...

$%CI = a \cdot \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{N}}$%

Where $%\frac{\sigma^2}{N}$% is the variance of the average of the performed experiments with sample size $%N$%. This fraction is a variance by itself.

If I have two different distributions A and B:

$%\frac{\sigma_{A}^2}{N_{A}}$% is the variance of the average of experiments of the distribution A.

$%\frac{\sigma_{B}^2}{N_{B}}$% is the variance of the average of experiments of the distribution B.

To obtain the variance over the combined distribution, I still have to add the variances (although these are variances for the averages of the experiments, not over the original random variable), so the variance of the combined distribution for the average of experiments is: $%\frac{\sigma_{A}^2}{N_{A}} + \frac{\sigma_{B}^2}{N_{B}}$%

And now I understand why Adam broke the fraction in two, even though they had the same denominator. So the experiments do not need to have the same sample size after all. Although if both distributions have the same size, you can derive the variances the way I did on my solution.

title: Webmaster partner needed for competition, trip to Palo Alto,
body:
I posted this in the Done! thread, but have had no takers yet.

Now that I am a gentleman of leisure again, I can give some thought to the contest. I have coded an app that has a good shot at winning, but it would be more fun for everyone if it had a Web interface. I can do simple HTML, but haven't learned to do graphic controls (e.g., a slider to enter a floating-point parameter). Also, my ChromeBook isn't a good development environment, and I have yet to spin up Python on my older Mac. And I don't have a website or a server account. And I've never run a distributed project, so it would good to have a partner who knows how to do that (even though it's not really necessary here).

I'm looking specifically for a partner worthy of the Palo Alto visit, as I have no need to claim that prize myself. You don't need strong Python skills, but there has to be some reason I would pick you over other applicants. I would prefer someone not working on other projects, just to spread the opportunity around -- but I could be flexible on that. My criteria involve what you can do for the contest entry, what you might do for Udacity (just in case they are thinking of this as an interview), and what the trip could do for you. (Furthest distance could well be a tie breaker. :-)

My app parses text, builds a grammar, and generates new text in the same style. Not quality text, of course, but sufficient to be entertaining. I know, many CS students have built such a thing; many have even built full chatbots -- but this one is simple, initialized for course-related material, and works very well. A crystalline gem, if I do say so, yet developed with very little effort. (I've wanted to write this app for 35 years. Python is great, and CS101 taught me all I needed. Thanks, Dave!) The code currently uses only CS101 techniques -- including dictionaries -- though Web hosting might require file I/O and other simple changes. (We can submit the callable non-Web version as well.)

My app doesn't do any Web search. It's possible for someone -- a third team member? -- to add that, but would require some moderately difficult Web scraping to find and extract relevant page content. I can help with further Python coding as necessary. The interactive interface controls and Web hosting are fundamental, and beyond my current ability. We can consider other development directions that may interest you, but I believe the above is sufficient for the contest.

My contribution will be the concept and the core code. I intend to retain any rights to the code not granted to the contest, including commercial rights, just in case this is my last shot at fame and fortune. You would likewise retain rights to your contributions, and the right to run my code for your own noncommercial use or as allowed by the Udacity license.

I'm sure there will be stiff competition, including genuinely useful apps, but I think we've got a shot at winning one of the trips. To volunteer, write to kilaws@gmail.com. Or you can reply here and give me your contact info.

The reason for that is also really cool. Hey, it's physics, of course it's cool!

Imagine an immense cloud of gas and dust in space. This cloud is likely to have some rotation on it. But that rotation may be very, very little. Of course, this gas cloud will want to start to collapse in on itself due to gravity.

As the cloud collapses, its rotation must increase to conserve rotational momentum. To get an idea what I mean, think of an ice skater spinning in place with their arms held out. Now the skater pulls their arms in, and they rotate faster. You can test this out if you have a chair that rotates easily, as well. Put your arms and legs out as you spin, your spin will decrease. Pull them in, and you spin faster.

The gas cloud does the same thing. And so it rotates faster and faster as the cloud collapses. At some point, it starts to glow as it becomes a protostar. And some point after that, fusion begins to occur in the star, and our new star is born! Any rotation at all in the initial gas cloud is magnified as it collapses, leaving a star spinning faster than the original gas cloud.

If you can find someone with a telescope, you can see it, as well. There are often sunspots on the surface, and they give you a reference point by which you can tell it's rotating, if you look at it over a period of time.

Fun fact: It's not a solid sphere, and it rotates faster at the equator than at the poles (called differential rotation).

title: So, now what?
body: Okay, so we have a working web browser. So how do I put it online, so that it can be used to build my own personal search engine? You know, maybe for a web site that I build?

First, let me correct what I said above about Bessel's correction. The N/(N-1) correction is not about the square root. That's a separate issue, about the standard deviation being even more biased than the variance and thus needing an even larger correction -- typically around N/(N-1.5), but varying with N. I've carried some confusion about this for a long time, and now I seem to be infecting others with it. Anyway, the variance itself needs the N/(N-1) correction in order to be unbiased, and the reason is that we are computing the average squared deviation around the sample mean instead of the around the population mean. Sample values are closer to their own mean than to the population mean, so the variance is underestimated. We use Bessel's correction to compute a slightly larger variance that has the desired expectation (i.e., average over an infinite number of experiments) of $%\sigma^2$%.

Now, to your question:

If we know the true population variance, we have no need to estimate it. We should discard any estimates, since we know they are unreliable compared to our prior knowledge of the process. (Using Bayesian estimation, we can assign a confidence to our prior knowledge and can then more or less discard new estimates as they are offered. But for now let's assume that we either know $%\sigma^2$% or are completely ignorant of it.)

If we don't know $%\sigma^2$%, we don't know which sample variances $%s^2_i$% are too high. Some are higher than others, of course. We could arbitrarily throw out the highest and lowest, as Sebastian did with his quartile-based outlier removal, but that's not our best option.

Instead, we average all of our sample variances $%s_i^2$% to get $%\bar{s}^2$%, the average sample variance over an ensemble of sampling experiments. This is an estimator, also called $%\hat{\sigma}^2$%, of the population variance.

(If we only have one sample, that's OK too. We just use that one sample variance as our estimate.)

Unfortunately, the estimator is biased. What it really estimates is $%\frac{N-1}{N}\sigma^2$%. (So why did we say it estimated $%\sigma^2$%? Because we were working with expectations, which are defined in the limit as N becomes infinite.) So we multiply by $%\frac{N}{N-1}$% to get to the value we really want.

title: Homework 1-9 markes as incorrect
body:
Hello,

wrote a piece of code for the HW 1-9

str_x = str(x)
separator_position = str_x.find('.')
fpfn = str_x[1+separator_position] # fraction part first char

rounding_correction = 5 + fpfn.find('5') + fpfn.find('6') + fpfn.find('7') + fpfn.find('8') + fpfn.find('9')
rounded_x = str(x + rounding_correction)

print str_x + " is rounded to " + rounded_x[0:rounded_x.find('.')]

tested and it worked fine with various inputs, but somehow marked as incorrect.

There is always a population, for independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.) draws. See my comment to Sean. The coin flips are considered to be repeated draws (or "trials") from a Bernoulli (or 0-1) distribution, and the population would be that of all possible Bernoulli events. Put more simply, the population is the set of one head and one tail, drawn "with replacement." (Or, just as valid, an infinite, balanced population of heads and tails, drawn with or without replacement.) The distribution is a probability 0.5 of drawing a head (1) and 0.5 of drawing a tail (0).

Or we could think of this as sampling from a binomial population, if we draw multiple times and count the number of heads (irrespective of the order). The concept gets confusing because there is a different binomial population for each N -- from which we take a sample of one draw -- but the math all works out to the same answers.

If we draw from the set (1, 2, 3) without replacement, the conceptual framework gets more complex. As you say, once we have drawn one of the elements, we no longer have the same population for the second draw. The probabilities on the second draw are dependent on the first draw, so we no longer have the i.i.d. samples that statisticians love. The tools of Statistics are of little use, and we are instead in the domain of Probability Theory. (We can still talk of means and variances, but must compute them by considering all possible sequences of draws.)

This is different from Bessel's correction for small samples with i.i.d. draws. Bessel's correction has to do with the effect of taking the square root of an unbiased estimator (the variance $%\sigma^2$%). Because the square root is a concave function (i.e., curving upward), it produces a sample statistic that always underestimates the corresponding population statistic $%\sigma$%. Without the correction, N would have to be infinite before the bias disappears (though in practice 30 is usually close enough). With the correction, there is no bias. (But the mean square error of the corrected $%s$% is a bit higher than for the biased statistic $%s_n$%. Alas, there is no free lunch, and Statistics is a complex, tricky business when you get this deep into the theory.)

It would be possible to talk about a small-sample correction for drawing without replacement from a finite set, but the math would be complicated. We'd have to work it out for each sequence of draws, or at least for equivalence classes of them. It's not something a statistician would usually consider, unless faced with an important physical problem that motivates the analysis.

title: finding out who started a rumor by "reverse search"  how might this work?
body:
from slashdot.org http://paritynews.com/science/item/168-researchers-develop-algorithm-to-trace-source-of-computer-virus-epidemics-more

do you think this is a 'new' algorithm or a variant of something we've already been exposed to?
Yeah, there was a problem. Refresh your page and try submitting it now. It should work.
We haven't announced how grades will be calculated. When we do there will be an announcement.

Suppose you have a clock where you can only ask what is the current number of minutes in the hour. So the only numbers you can use are 0 to 59.

But it's obvious as you go around the clock (clockwise), 60 minutes is the same as 0 minutes, and 61 is the same as 1 minute, and so on. Also, if you go anticlockwise 1 minute (-1), it's the same position as 59 minutes.

This is what the modulo operator does.

-1 % 60 = 59, and so on for the examples above.

In Python you can always be certain that for integers, a % len(p) will 'cycle back' to the value greater than or equal to 0 and strictly less than len(p), so that if you kept cycling around to the actual index, a%len(p) references the same position as a. Make sure the second argument is the size of the correct array.

Mathematically, a%m can be defined as the integer r which is greater than or equal to 0 and strictly less than m such that m divides (a-r); or equivalently r-a if you're uncomfortable when a is negative.

for e in p:
    product = product * e

return product

You're all very welcome.:) Thanks for sharing your solutions. It's cool to see all the different ways you can implement it. Thanks for the random.sample() hint, @Michel Dusseault. I tried about 3 different functions from random and then assumed that none of random functions would work with set(). @Carmen, set() is really cool. Its operations are very close to sets from math, so it's very intuitive to manipulate set(). You can make all sorts of cool things:

setA = set([1, 2, 3, 4])
setB = set([3, 4, 5, 6])

# difference
# result: set([1, 2]) 
setA - setB

# union
# result: set([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
setA | setB

# intersection
# result: set([3, 4])
setA & setB

# symmetric difference (only elements that are not shared between the two sets)
# result: set([1, 2, 5, 6])
setA ^ setB

As @Sergei pointed out in this thread (in the comments to Carmen's answer), set.pop() is decidedly non-random (arbitrary != random). It seems to just return the numbers in order. A good thing to keep in mind. You can't use choice (without turning it into a list), but you can use random.sample like this:

picked = random.sample(doors, 1)[0]

Sample can return multiple randomly picked elements (note the last argument, which is just 1 in this case), and returns a list, hence the [0] at the end. Mind you, in @Marcio's case, two elements are sampled right off, so it might make sense to sample 2 elements at the start.

If you have one element left in the set and you want to extract it, I suppose that would be a good place for set.pop(). It can't really fail to give you the only element in the set.

And thanks for contributing, @Marcio! I've enjoyed these solutions using sets (among others).

@pcarmo, that is how Python works.

You can change an object's variables and then just return from the member function. This will, as expected, change/update values of the object that invokes the function.

But it doesn't make sense to return the object itself through its member function (move() is a member function of class robot). If we are so desired to return an object from a member function, we need to create a new / different one.

For this course, "problem" is perhaps a bit strong, since the counter-examples require using JavaScript syntax that was not covered in class and is not a direct translation of Python (cf. elif vs. else if). Our primary goal is making the eventual interpreter easier for students to write, even if that means making it a little harder for people who have outside knowledge of JavaScript.

That said, I don't want students to be frustrated, so I have made changes so that our interpreter accepts both Rajeev's example and your github example "out of the box". Time permitting, Peter may be able to push those changes to the grading servers to help with any subsequent JavaScript assignments or subsequent runs of this class.

I do want to thank the two of you for bringing this additional possible source of frustration to our attention. I think you (and the students who complained earlier) have made the world a better place for future students. That said, this line of work does reach diminishing returns quickly -- it is not necessarily a good use of time to support every possible JavaScript corner case.

if e in var :

2nd -

@Leslie: as it turns out, sampling distribution mean is the same as the original population mean. This I believe is one of the conclusions of the central limit theorem. Here is a link that mentions this: http://msenux.redwoods.edu/math/R/CentralLimit3.php

We might even be able to prove that: Say the mean of the original population is mu. Then the mean of (X1+X2+.....+Xn)/n = (1/n)mean(X1+.....+Xn)= (1/n)[mean(x1)+...+mean(Xn)]=(1/n)(mu + mu+.... mu] = (1/n)(n *mu)=mu

The sampling distribution will tend to be bell-shaped (i.e. normal) based on the central limit theorem, as n="sample size" gets larger.

As for the statement about 95%.... that is known as the empirical rule and I had a link about that in my post.

  else if(b>a) {
    return gcd(a,b-a);
  }
}

title: Course, contest and few other questions
tagnames: cs101 libraries ranking suggestions certificate contest
body:
1. Course in general

    1.1. Concatenation of certificates

    It has been mentioned that we'll receive a certificate upon successful completion of this course. Though although it would be nice to count all the classes that we've attended and hopefully passed, as it is going, soon they will take more than majority of the resume.


    It's not a bad thing but, with case of someone going to college/university, they don't count 40'ish classes that they attended, but just the degree that they received. Now I'm not asking for a degree, but am mostly interested if, after completion of several courses, sort of concatenation of them will be offered as an e-certificate?


    So... if I complete one course, I can put it on my resume but if I would complete 5 courses of which 3 are computer related and 2... let's say medical related, I would just have to mention them individually. But if I would complete 5 (or more/less) of them from the same field such as Building a Search Engine, Design of Computer Programs, Web Application Engineering, Programming Languages and let's say Programming A Robotic Car, I'd be eligible for... Udacity's Programmer e-certificate, so I could put just that one and anyone that is interested can easily google to find out what is required for it.


    Well not exactly those classes since Programming A Robotic Car is apparently for advanced, but collection of classes with similar difficulty.


    1.2. Retaking classes

    Although this one is probably a "duh..." question, it is still better to ask. If we're not satisfied with our final grade, can we retake the class and keep "better" certificate? Or it's more of a "Can retake as long as you don't pass it, and when you do, it's done"

  2. Contest

    2.1. Libraries, robots.txt and such

    Will we be able to use libraries when building a search engine for the contest at the end of a class. Will it "have" to obey the robots.txt.

    Well, what I'm mostly interested in is... would there be a chance for someone that just started to program to actually win with "if-then-else" type of programming or will they surely fail compared to those that will use regex, machine learning and some libraries that half of population haven't even heard about yet?


    2.2. Ranking

    How will search engines be ranked? How will algorithms be compared to others? By the execution speed? By the number of pages they can index, or by the results it will give on searching for specific keywords.

    Will the testing environment be controlled or it will be an actual Internet.

    If Internet, will it use our desktops/servers(if someone has one/some)/bandwidth or will it be uploaded and then executed on your computers.

  3. Suggestions

    3.1. Teamspeak/Ventrilo/Mumble

    If Google's software for communicating is crashing a lot, why not use an alternative such as Teamspeak, Ventrilo or Mumble?


    3.2. Wiki

    This is more from the MITx, but I liked the idea of having a Wiki that students could edit and expand. Even without the books or references, attendees would have nice amount of information to read. And although you can find most of information on forums, wiki would be more structured and easier to search.


    3.3. One registration for Udacity forum

    Considering it's on the same domain, it's bit weird that I had to register on CS101 forums and CS373. Wouldn't it be simpler to register just once and have access to all forums of classes that someone attends?

title: My experience with Udacity (so far...)
tagnames: cs101 learning udacity future advice experience
body:
Brief history:

I have wanted to learn to write code since I can remember. I took an AP Computer Science course in high school, and did quite well at it. I spent a semester in University as an "Undecided" major, although my courses were geared towards Computer Science. A rough patch came up in my personal life that required me to leave school and begin working, but I never stopped wanting to learn how to control and manipulate my computer to complete various tasks for me. I have found all "by yourself" means of learning to program insufficient for my particular learning style (how-to books, internet sites promising to teach you xxx language). With no deadlines, and lacking a specific direction, I often found that I would stray from completing anything worthwhile.

Flash to present:

It's been over 10 years since I dabbled in actual programming in any structured way. When I read about Udacity, my first thought was, "if it sounds to good to be true, it probably is." I figured there would be a hidden fee, or some other gimmick once you got your foot in the door. Obviously that skepticism proved false, and here I am, having completed my first Udacity course successfully (because I feel I have a solid grasp of the material, since I don't know my grade yet).

I'm thrilled by the prospect of what is happening here, and to think that I'm in on the "ground floor" so to speak is incredible indeed. I'm excited about the two courses I signed up for this next hexamester, and I am quite enjoying the community that has developed (even though I'm not the MOST involved in it).

Something I found that helped:

Frequently throughout this course I found it invaluable to "code" in an environment where I couldn't use an actual interpreter. I found that this forced me to run through my code and keep track of each iteration (or recursion) to find out the results. It gave me a better understanding of the internal workings of the code, and the language in general. I am sure there would be some difficulties using this approach while working on more complex programs, but then again, if you're accomplishing abstraction well, it's a feasible way to approach a problem you're struggling to get your head around.
In addition to the above advice, I can't stress enough how helpful I found these forums, in general. There were, of course, the distracting posts, but for the most part, there were many times that a simple comment or thought presented in the forums helped something click into place in my head, and allowed me to get over a hurdle.

The reason for my post here:

I thought people could share a few things in this area.
1). What is/are your thoughts on your Udacity experience after the first course (or JUST ABOUT after, if you haven't submitted the final exam yet)
2.) Since many of us are taking an online course for the first time, and in addition, since many of us are entirely new (or almost new) to programming, did you stumble upon any techniques that helped you when things weren't so smooth? How did you finally find the solution after many hours of being stuck on a problem? How did you juggle this course with your real world every day life?

~ Thanks guys, happy learning/coding!

title: Time Management for Programmers
body:
I commented recently that an intended change in my code would only take a couple of lines; in fact it took me half the night. Not that my original plan was wrong (perhaps), but I saw a better approach and couldn't resist starting again from scratch to "do it right."

For those of you new to Computer Science, there is a scheduling formula that is commonly applied in software engineering and the management of programmers. If a programmer says he can do a job in a minute, be grateful if he gets back to you in less than two hours. If he estimates an hour, allow two days. Likewise a day means two weeks; a week means two months; a month means two years; and a year means you can't expect results within the current budget cycle. The general formula is that you double the given number and increment the temporal unit.

I ran across this formula decades ago (in Fred Brook's The Mythical Man-Month?) and have found it to be generally accurate. Experienced programmers can produce code much faster than beginners, but will also be tackling harder problems. And they will add extra bells and whistles, or do a few extra test runs, just because they "have more time" before their schedule slip starts to feel serious.

The management lesson is obvious: allow more time. Lots more time. "Software always takes longer." (Longer than what? Doesn't matter. It will take longer.)

The lessons for programmers are less obvious. Start with "curb your expectations," of course, but throw in a pinch of "don't beat yourself up over it." Keep Scotty's "I canna' change the laws of physics!" on the tip of your tongue, but know that sometimes you can beat a deadline if you have to -- and sometimes you can't, and won't be able to solve the problem at all. And sometimes it won't be your fault, as with our inability today to run or submit code on the Udacity server. And sometimes it will be your fault, and someone else will point out what should have been obvious to you.

Why do we always overestimate our abilities and underestimate time required? My personal belief -- 'sorry if it offends anyone -- is that self-esteem problems are a principle cause. (That and simply not being able to envision all the difficulties until confronted by them.) When asked for a guess, or even when generating them internally, we want to appear competent. Many programmers are of the nerd persuasion, and programming is one of their core competencies; hence a very strong need to feel proficient and to appear proficient. The result of this social urge is denial. And the more often the programmer falls behind desired or promised performance, the stronger the social need and the stronger the denial. "Doing it right" becomes an obsession, partly to make up for so often turning it in late. The programmer lives with shame, and compensates with a gloss of fantasy and perfectionism. If you enter this field, and care about it, know that this is a demon you will encounter. The demon can destroy your self-esteem, and your marriage, possibly even your job (usually the last thing lost before serious depression, sometimes breakdown or suicide). But programming is also a magnificent obsession, and worth living with the demon.

Hubris is necessary in a great programmer; so is humility. The field will teach you both.

Cheating is always cheating oneself. If it were possible to do as you describe and some silly fool were to do that, then the certificate would just be a piece of paper. And the same holds for degrees, no matter what the institution granting them is. If you don't know what you're doing, that will be painfully obvious to any interviewer.

I'm glad you find it helpful. The most common complaint I hear about CS grads from traditional universities is that they don't know how to code straight out of college. Unfortunately, my experience with Udacity so far indicates they are reinforcing this stereotype. By his own admission Professor Regehr's example solution is crap.

Computer science and computer programming are not the same thing but there is no reason computer science couldn't be taught with examples that demonstrate good programming.

I still cringe every time I think of Sean Bennett's challenge to try and beat his lines of code. Unless you are Alan Kay, focusing on lines of code is almost always the wrong path to quality.

I think it would be great if the community reviewed a few code examples for each problem set. After the community discussed and refined the code the best solutions could be saved and presented as official answers. I think this would be better than the shoot from the hip stuff the instructors are doing right now. Ultimately, it should involve less work for the professors and offer higher quality to the students.

But the point here is not the code. The problem is there was no spec as to what the answer should produce.
