title: My Very Long, Non-Levenshtein Final Double Star Answer
body:
Here's my very-long, non-Levenshtein (or at least I haven't looked at Levenshtein in detail yet) final double star answer:
(and yes- I'm sure it could be cleaned up. And I may have thought of some potential inputs on which it wouldn't work. And yes- it got full points.)

def calcalliance(s, t, offset):
    if offset >= len(s):
        print "Offset too big", offset, "length of", s, " to len", len(s)
        if len(t) > len(s):
            return len(t)
        return len(s)

    finished = False
    total = 0
    current = 0
    while not finished:
        if (current + offset) >= len(s):
           # print "Finished case 1"
            finished = True
            total += len(t) - (len(s) - offset)
            #print t, s, offset
            #print "Total: ", total
        elif current >= len(t):
            #print "Finished case 2"
            finished = True
            total += len(s) - (offset + len(t))
        elif t[current] != s[current + offset]:
            #add one for not matching
            total += 1
        #else:
         #   print "Found a matching: ", t[current], current, s[current+offset], current+offset
        current += 1
    #add the beginning offset to the total cost
    total += offset
    return total

def bestalliance(s,t):
    bestvalue = 10000
    bestoffset = 0
    finished = False
    offset = 0
    #print s, t
    while not finished:
        mismatch = calcalliance(s,t,offset)
        #print "num mismatch", mismatch
        if mismatch < bestvalue:
            #print "new bestoffset", offset, "bestvalue",mismatch
            bestoffset = offset
            bestvalue = mismatch
        if bestvalue == 0:
            finished = True
        offset += 1
        if offset >= len(s):
            finished = True
    return bestvalue, bestoffset

def find_largest_matching(s, t, offset):
    start = -1
    end = -1
    retstart = -1
    retend = -1

    index = 0
    finished = False
    #print "********find_largest_matching"
    #print s, t, offset
    matching = False
    while not finished:
        #if the two are matching
        #print s[offset + index], t[index]
        if s[offset + index] == t[index]:
            if start == -1:
                #print "Starting start point"
                start = index
                end = index
                matching = True
                #print "** ", start, end
            else:
                end = index
        else:  # now not matching
            #print "not matching index is", index
            if (end - start) >= (retend - retstart) and matching == True:
                #greatest length of matching so far
                #print "Now not matching"
                retstart = start
                retend = end
                #print "retstart", retstart, retend
                matching = False
            #print "resetting start and end"
            start = -1
            end = -1
        index += 1
        if offset + index == len(s):
            finished = True
        if index == len(t):
            finished = True
    if retstart == -1 or retend == -1:
        #print "Saving..."
        retstart = start
        retend = end
        #print "***", retstart, retend
    return retstart, retend

def basecase(start, finish, a, b, off):
    bval = 0
    #print "basecase: ", start, finish, a, b, off
    if start == -1 or finish == -1:
        if len(a) > len(b):
            bval += len(a)
        else:
            bval += len(b)
        return True, bval
    return False, bval

def basestr(s1, s2):
    if len(s2) == 0:
        return True, len(s1)
    if len(s1) == 1 and len(s2) == 1:
        return True, 1
    if len(s1) == 0:
        return True, len(s2)
    return False, 0

def findright(finish, a, b, off):   
    #print "findright"
    bval = 0
    # no sense doing recurssion if only one letter in either
    # if only one character- no need to do anything.  We know it is one operation
    # either a delete, add or replace
    righta = a[finish + off + 1: ]
    rightb = b[finish + 1: ]
    #print "findright. a:", righta, "b: ", rightb

    timetostop, bval = basestr(righta, rightb)
    if timetostop:
        #print "Basecase on findright, returning ", bval
        return bval
    bval += edit_distance(righta, rightb)    
    return bval

def findleft(start, a, b, off):
    #print "findleft"
    bval = 0
    timetostop = False
    # no sense doing recurssion if only one letter in either
    # if only one character- no need to do anything.  We know it is one operation
    # either a delete, add or replace
    lefta = a[0:start + off]
    leftb = b[0:start]
    #print "findleft. a:", lefta, "b: ", leftb
    timetostop, bval = basestr(lefta, leftb)
    if timetostop:
        #print "Basecase on findleft, returning ", bval
        return bval
    bval += edit_distance(lefta, leftb)
    return bval

def callagain(a,b,off):
    bval = 0
    #print a, b, off
    start, finish = find_largest_matching(a, b, off)
    #print "callagain, start:", start, "finish: ", finish, off
    timetostop, bval = basecase(start, finish, a, b, off)
    if timetostop:
        #print "basecase in callagain.  Time to stop. bval: ", bval
        return bval

    # and now we have the break aparts.
    # calculate edit_distance for each part, add them up.
    # will only need to call recursively twice, but add in bvalue for the shift so far.
    bval += findleft(start, a, b, off)       
    bval += findright(finish, a, b, off)
    return bval

def edit_distance(s,t):
    # find the best alliance
    # from there, break apart into parts and find best alliance again
    #take two arrays, match up in all ways possible, find the best match, go from there.
    bvalue = 0
    #print "edit_distance: ", s, t
    alliance, off = bestalliance(s,t)
    alliance2, off2 = bestalliance(t,s)
    #break apart and call on substring
    if alliance < alliance2:
        if alliance == 1:
            return alliance
        #print "bestalliance: ", s, t, off
        bvalue += callagain(s, t, off)
    else:
        if alliance2 == 1:
            return alliance2
        #print "bestalliance: ", t, s, off2
        bvalue += callagain(t, s, off2)
    return bvalue

print edit_distance("amanaplanacan", "docnoteidisse") 
#== 12

# ********* below are working
def printworking():
    allworking = True
    #For example:
    print edit_distance("aud", "ub")
    # 2

    print edit_distance('audacity', 'ubacity')
    #== 2 (insert a, replace b with d)
    print edit_distance('audacity', 'udboacity')
    # 3 insert a, delete boo

    print edit_distance('aud', 'udbo')
    # 3 insert a, delete boo

    print edit_distance('audacity', 'udbacity')
    #== 2 (insert a, delete b)

    print edit_distance('audacity', 'audboacity')
    # 2 - delete bo

    # Delete the 'a'
    print edit_distance('audacity', 'udacity')
    #>>> 1

    # Delete the 'a', replace the 'u' with 'U'
    print edit_distance('audacity', 'Udacity')
    #>>> 2

    # Five replacements
    print edit_distance('peter', 'sarah')
    #>>> 5

    # One deletion
    print edit_distance('pete', 'peter')
    #>>> 1
    return allworking

print printworking()

title: HW 4.5 Solution
body:
Here is my solution, sure isn't the best one, is like bruteforce some comparisons, but whatever jeje

def split_string(source,splitlist):

    if splitlist == "":
        return [source]
    elif source == "":
        return []

    ret = []
    aux = ""
    i = 0
    for s in source:
        if s not in splitlist:
            aux = aux + s
        else:
            if aux != "":
                ret.append(aux)
            aux = ""

    if aux != "":
        ret.append(aux)
    return ret

title: HW 6.3 explained
body:
Hello, can someone please explain what homework 6.3 is asking? I don't understand the question and I don't understand where they're taking the numbers from. For example, hexes_to_udaciousness(100000, 2, 36230) How did they come up with those numbers?

Thanks

The vector is the belief state of the robot.

  1. Initially, it believes that it can be anywhere, so the vector is [1/5, 1/5, 1/5, 1/5, 1/5]
  2. When it senses the "red", its beliefs change to match that observation, so the vector becomes [1/9, 1/3, 1/3, 1/9, 1/9].
  3. Then it moves to the right. It is sure he moved to the right, so if it believed with confidence 1/3 that it was in the 3rd cell, it will be 1/3 confident that it is now in the 4th cell. Doing the same procedure for each position of the vector, his belief vector becomes [1/9, 1/9, 1/3, 1/3, 1/9].

The idea is that the vector represents the belief state of the robot and the values are the certainty of the robot about whether it is in that cell.

As for the 3 vs 4. The length of the substring you are trying to find is 3. Which means that the next occurrence of the substring can be 3 positions after the first occurrence of it. It will not be accepted as a correct solution, because it fails for test string 'zipzip'. In a general case you would do:

text = "all zip files are zipped"
search_string = "zip"
search_string_length = len(search_string)
first = text.find(search_string)
second = text.find(search_string, first + search_string_length)

And then you can change the value of search_string and you will not need to modify the part where you search for second occurrence of the search string, because it adjusts automagically.

Good question. That was first mentioned in lesson 24-21, then proved in 24-24, but for me the clearest explanation came from @Roshan Kamath in http://forums.udacity.com/st101/questions/8906/unit-24-24-derivation-of-variance .

I don't think it's quite that simple, as it depends on the specifics of the two surfaces. Two surfaces that are not real rough may still match up poorly and have lots of contact points that cause friction. In contract, two very uneven surfaces may still be in a position to glide over each other relatively easily.

title: Unit 4.3 - Add to Index - Mistake answer mistake
body:
The answer of the video give us the following code:

for entry in index:  
    if entry[0] == keyword:  
        entry[1].append(url)  
        return  
index.append([keyword,[url]])

When you try to add an url twice, for the same keyword, you can do that.
To prevent it I modified the code as follows:

for entry in index:
    if entry[0] == keyword:
        if url not in entry[1]:
            entry[1].append(url)
            return
        return
index.append([keyword,[url]])

I agree that the worst case is O(n) but the average case is O(1). You can demonstrate this to yourself by considering equal length slices. If I step by ~1 slice, since the average should be half the maximum, each time, how many slices do I need to move to pass that? The answer is approximately 1 as a simple simulation will show. To start, it's a bit more inefficient as the smaller weights require more steps. For truly random data, the answer seems to start at 2 and then converge to 1 as the particle is localized.
FROM UTTAR PRADESH FINAL YEAR UNDERGRAD

Insect vision is different again. Insects are sensitive to the polarization of light and can use that to navigate. Insects are cold blooded, so their eyes can see into the IR that a warm-blooded animal cannot. Insects have a compound eye; essentially an array of cameras, each of limited capability. To produce a comparable system in silicon is difficult. How would you design a 100 x 100 array of cameras? You would need nanotechnology. Insects have simple visual requirements. Frog vision has been modeled as simply detecting small moving objects (stick out you tongue and eat it), large moving objects (jump to get away from it) and a couple other things.

Thank you for your help!

Thanks. I was trying to mimic Prof Littman's code because we haven't got a full solution to this quiz.This is the full working code with the fixes:

import csv
import time
import heapq

def make_link(G, node1, node2):
    if node1 not in G:
        G[node1] = {}
    if node2 not in G[node1]:
        G[node1][node2] = 1
    else:
        G[node1][node2] += 1
    if node2 not in G:
        G[node2] = {}
    if node1 not in G[node2]:
        G[node2][node1] = 1
    else:
        G[node2][node1] += 1
    return G

def read_graph(filename):
    tsv = csv.reader(open(filename), delimiter='\t')
    G = {}
    characters = {}
    index = 0
    for (node1, node2) in tsv: 
        if node1 not in characters:
            characters[node1] = index
            index += 1
        make_link(G, node1, node2)
    return G, characters

marvelG, characters = read_graph('uniq_edges.tsv')

def val(node):
    return node[0]

time1 = time.time()
charG = {}
for char1 in characters:
    if char1 not in charG:
        charG[char1] = {}
    for book in marvelG[char1]:
        for char2 in marvelG[book]:        
            if char1 > char2:
                 make_link(charG, char1, char2)
time2 = time.time()
print "time to compute strenghts", time2 - time1

heap=[]
k = 10
for char1 in characters:
    for char2 in charG[char1]:
        #avoid duplicates by only including pairs where the character
        #number of the first is less than that of the second
        if characters[char1] < characters[char2]:
            if len(heap) < k:
                heapq.heappush(heap,(charG[char1][char2], (char1, char2)))
            elif charG[char1][char2] > val(heap[0]):
                heapq.heappushpop(heap,(charG[char1][char2], (char1, char2)))
print [heapq.heappop(heap) for _ in range(k)]

You are supposed to return the value not print it. I'll update the description to make that clear.

I might have made the point differently (it reads as slightly sarcastic to me, though it makes the point well), but I think you bring up a valid issue, @Sergei.

I would say that's one reason I write simulations like this to correspond as directly as possible with the process I'm simulating. For one, less chance of making an incorrect assumption. And I'm trying to simulate the process as closely as possible and make it convincing. Though if the problem as stated is intractable, of course, shortcuts will be taken.

So I guess you could say, though the logic is good, the above solution isn't a faithful simulation, strictly speaking.

Still, don't feel bad, Samo. Your logic is otherwise sound, and it's not like the "philosophy of simulations", if you will, has been discussed at all.

Yeah, that's pretty much it. The variance of the mean sounds like it's something too out of the ordinary, but if you get to this point it isn't really. When you're summing random variables, you get a random variable whose mean is the sum of the means, and whose variance is the sum of the variances of these variables. This is what's happening with the coin flips, and that is the general result: the resulting mean and variance is the sum of all the means and variances (think about the random walk. It's the same thing).

Now, for the variance of the mean, you basically just use a result that was obtained previously, that $%Var(aX)=a^2Var(X)$%. To make things clearer:

You found the mean and variance of the sums or coin flips, or $%\Sigma X_i$%, where each $%X_i$% is a coin flip. But what you're trying to get isn't $%\Sigma X_i$%, but rather $%\frac 1 N\Sigma X_i$%. Then it's simple: use the rule of the variance multiplication above to find that $%Var(\frac 1 N\Sigma X_i)=\frac {1}{N^2} Var(\Sigma X_i)$%. You already have all of the $%\Sigma X_i$%, since $%Var(\Sigma X_i)=\Sigma Var(X_i)$%, so you divide each by $%N^2$%.

There are two ways to view this class: As an introduction to how to build a self-driving car or as a survey of major concepts from several disciplines used to build one.

Viewed as the former, we've covered how the car can discover and keep track of its position given a map and sensor readings, how to plan given a location, goal and map and how to steer given that route. The adjacent omitted areas are how we get the sensor data to use in localization, how we build a map using that sensor data in order to both localize and plan (e.g. specify obstacles), and how to build an interface from our controller to the car. Using Stanley as an example, a complete picture can be seen in this diagram of Stanley's systems with what we've covered boxed in red.

Note the diagram was taken from "Stanley: The Robot that Won the DARPA Grand Challenge"

If you see values flicker by +-8, 64 is probably a reasonable level to use as your variance. Note that it's actually a bit less and you can estimate it better by computing the sample variance but higher variances probably work better. To confirm, choose a couple variance values around it and see how they perform. If needed, you could actually optimize the value for R.

That said, your bigger issue will be once you turn on your PWM, it will only accurately model the system is you supply it with additional state variable to make the problem approximately Markovian. In this case, that means you'll need to use a magnetic field variable and orientation and compute the update using both of those. Of course, that will also require adding velocity and acceleration state variables...

BTW, the sampling process is often more complex than drawing from an urn. My father ran across one such at a Hormel meat packing plant. Ground meat was dropping off a conveyor belt onto a lower belt, and the plant had a man there to take samples. He would hit the stream of ground meat with a stick, knocking some of it into a plastic bag. When the bag was full enough, it was sent to the lab to be blended and analyzed.

This was not a particularly demanding job, and the plant didn't hire Ph.D.s for it. As with any industrial process, it was necessary to train the workers in how to do it. In this case, the training consisted mostly in teaching them to keep well away from the stream of meat, as otherwise they quickly acquired several pounds of ground meat in their sleeves.

def is_palindrome(s):

The problems tend to be fairly easy while the programming assignments are fairly mechanical. We're told how to structure every substantial piece of the program. To the extent I've learned and I believe I have, it's principally been from thinking about why things work and most importantly answering questions and attempting explanations on the forum.

I believe I've spent about an hour a week on the homework with the majority of it being for the programming assignments.

They're decently enjoyable but not fascinating. Having either harder bonus/honors questions or structuring the assignment to have a number of starting places could be helpful. For example, this past week, a harder version could have expected us to write the particle filter from scratch and derive the motion equations. Alternatively, a harder problem could have been to determine the relationship between the number of particles, measurement frequency, motion frequency and localization error or to build a basic motion governor with the aim of localizing in the smallest number of steps. Creating workable grading systems for these isn't trivial so I understand why they aren't here now but I think this course has the potential to be far more challenging.

title: Unit 3 Q42: The correct answer is not accepted
body: The correct answer "page not in crawled" is not accepted.

If what happens when we use self-driving cars is as simple as replacing current cars, you're absolutely right. Reducing the cost of a thing will cause that thing to be consumed more. In this case the hassle cost of driving is being reduced.

However, when we consider the use of self-driving cars more broadly, we'll see that they result in massive environmental benefits. The key change that facilitates different use is that they can be automatically delivered when you need the car. This means that you don't need your car to sit around idle for 95% of its life. This should reduce the number of cars manufactured by up to an order of magnitude. Furthermore, such a model would speed the transition to electric cars if it hasn't already occurred. Since they're already more economical at higher mileage amounts, they would be used except in the small percentage of cases where range is a concern. Furthermore, electric cars used by such a service wouldn't need as large batteries since the distribution of ranges could be matched (conservatively) with the distribution of trip lengths as opposed to the current bias for buying the longest range one might need. The same also goes for vehicle sizes: They could be matched to the distribution of trip capacity requirements since you could request a larger car for extreme trips with no additional overhead. Lastly, most of the land currently used for parking could be repurposed.

So while it's possible there will be a transition period where people consume more gasoline, the endstate should more than offset any interim issues.

I guess it doesn't matter, because the tolerance is so small, but why are we measuring the change by adding up all the changes in x and in y for every point, rather than adding up the Euclidean distance between the old point and the updated point?

That is, we have a tolerance we are aiming for, and to see if we have made it, we add up all the changes we made in all the x's and y's (or their absolute values?) and see if it's less than our tolerance. But why are we not computing the distance between old point and updated point, for each point, and adding those up, instead?

You're merely delaying the communications overhead. Writing to a local disk is communications overhead. Around 1992 (when Pentium came out), disks maxed out at about 1MB/sec. FDIV results in a 10-byte result. Assume on the 486 and Pentium system we use pseudo-random numbers from the same seed, so all we need are the results. At 1MB/sec, we can write to the local disk at 100,000 results/second. FDIV on Pentium took 39 clocks, and Pentium released at 60MHz. So we're limited by disk speed to write the results. At 100,000 results per second, that leave 600-39=561 clocks to do FP emulation of FDIV. This is trivial, emulation can be done at least twice that fast without even being carefully optimized. That beats just writing the results to disk, and ignores the time to read back the results for comparison. Even if you assume much faster disks, once you count in the time to read back the results, FP emulation easily is the better choice.
You don't have to communicate. At all. You just need to collect results of FP computations on the same sample program from Pentium and from 486, and compare them. Simple as that =)

@Sean Mahoney Check out videos 19-1 and 19-2. This is where Sebastian performs an experiment: he flips a coin 1000 times and writes down the mean. He repeats the experiment many times. Now he has many means. He plots a histogram of these means and what does he see? A bell curve. The means of all his experiments approximate a normal distribution. title: Lecture 5.19 hash_string operation cost
body:
In lecture 5.19, it's mentioned that comparing the procedures below, hash_string1 is less expensive than hash_string2. Would anyone be able to explain why that is?

def hash_string1(keyword, buckets):
    h = 0
    for c in keyword:
        h = (h + ord(c)) % buckets
    return h

def hash_string2(keyword,buckets):
    h = 0
    for c in keyword:
        h = h + ord(c)
    return h % buckets

title: Final Starred 7.3 Clarification please
body:
what does this quiz mean?
Modify the index to keep track of not only the URL, but the position

within that page where a word appears.

The reason the variance only goes down is that we omitted control variance. If you include uncertain movement, convergence depends on the relationship between measurement variance and control variance. If control variance is high, it doesn't necessarily converge at all.

I'll try to explain K: K is just the generalization of the single dimension gain factor. In one dimension for variables with means v and n and variances r and m, our new estimate was (rn+mv)/(m+r). We can rewrite this in terms of the adjustment to the current state by subtracting n. So the adjustment is (rn+mv-nm-nr)/(m+r)=m(v-n)/(m+r). This is simply the one dimensional version of x=x+(P*H.T*(H*P*H.T+R).I)(z-Hx) where A.I is the inverse of A and A.T is the transpose of T. Because of the length of the equation, it's usually written in several pieces: S represents the total variance and is equivalent to (m+r). K is the adjust factor applied to the difference m/(m+r). y is the difference (v-n).

While this might make it easier to see how this is a generalization of the single dimensional case, it elides over some new concepts introduced, namely hidden variables and covariance. Let's work through a simple example to see how these work. Consider the example in class of tracking a point moving along a line by its position and speed. Let's start with S. This is supposed to represent the total variance. R is a single number that represents the variance of the measurement. If we had multiple measurements, it would be have not only the sensor errors but also the covariance of them. To that we need to add the uncertainty of the measurement given the system. While we have two state variables, we're only measuring one of them which is represented by H=[[1,0]]. The first H*P gives us a 1x2 matrix with the first entry being the variance of the position and the second the covariance of position and speed. Multiplying by H.T leaves us with just the variance of position. Adding that to R gives us our total variance. Note that H would have more interesting behavior if our measurements were actually sums of state variables. In that case it would actually add variances.

Now that we've shown that our denominator is the total variance, we need to show that the numerator is the variance of the state which gives us the weight to apply to the update. The complication over the single variable case is that K has two entries since it needs to provide updates for each state variable based on the measurement. To compute we multiply P*H.T which gives us a 2x1 matrix with the first entry being the variance of the state position and the second being the covariance of the state speed and position. This is one of the two steps that enables the Kalman filter to infer speed. To see how, note that after the first motion step, F creates covariance between state and motion. Let's quickly multiply F to see the magnitude. F=[[1,dt],[0,1]]. For uncertain but uncorrelated position and motion we have P=[[a,0],[0,b]]. F*P=[[a,b*dt],[0,b]]. Multiplying by F transpose yields: [[a+b*dt^2,b*dt],[b*dt,b]]. Then in computing K, speed is updated with a weight of b*dt/(a+b*dt^2+R). So to the extent the uncertainty in position is small and measurement noise is low, speed is simply updated by multiplying the change in position by 1/dt which is equivalent to calculating speed!

The issue is really just a typo, but a typo that may flag a more general issue. One 'wants' to use a function that is 1 or 0 because of the nice applications of such 'characteristic' functions in probability and measure theory. However, conventional enumerations force changes in the particular description of such functions in code applications. For what it's worth, to a (present or former) mathematician, the summation you describe is over all w and all x in G[v], and thus double-counts the potential edges, which are what one implicitly selects at random with a probability of 2/(n(n-1)). Hence the '0.5 or 0'. (With a denominator instead of n(n-1), one would be selecting instead ordered pairs at random. The issue is merely pedantic until one's code starts producing answers that are off by a multiple.
An interesting question is how to change the sampling procedure to get faster convergence, but that's another topic.)

title: Product List wrong?
body:
Can someone tell me what is wrong with my code?
It is exactly the same as the answers provided :

def product_list(l1):
    product = 1
    for e in l1:
        product = e * product
    return product

I would appreciate some help thanks!

The state matrix represents the relationship between the state at t and t+dt. It might help to write down the relationships as a set of equations and then transform those into matrices. If that's challenging, try multiplying a symbolic state matrix and comparing the resulting system of equations with those that you developed.

Just as a brief reminder:

[[a,b,c]] * [[d],
             [e],
             [f]]
=a*d+b*e+c*f

Matrix multiplication takes the dot product of the rows of the left matrix with the columns of the right one. The product matrix has the number of rows of the matrix on the right and columns of the one on the left. So if there were 3 rows in the matrix above, the result would be another column vector with three items: the dot product of the columna and row 1, of the column and row 2 and of the column and row 3.
It doesn't matter. With only four cells, the moves are equivalent. Down wraps to moving up. Left wraps to moving right.

def move(self, motion): # Do not change the name of this function

    alfa = motion[0]
    dist = motion[1]
    beta = dist * tan(alfa) / self.length
    if beta < 0.001:
        # straight move
        xp = self.x + dist * cos (self.orientation)
        yp = self.y + dist * sin (self.orientation)
    else:
        # move with steering angle
        R = dist / beta
        cx = self.x - sin (self.orientation) * R
        cy = self.y + cos (self.orientation) * R
        xp = cx + sin (self.orientation + beta) * R
        yp = cy - cos (self.orientation + beta) * R
    op = (self.orientation + beta) % (2*pi)
    myrobot = robot (self.length)
    myrobot.set (xp, yp, op)
    return myrobot

def ordered_search(index, ranks, keyword):

    rank = []
    listFinal = []
    list=lookup(index, keyword)

        return None
    else:
        for l in list:
            rank.append(ranks[l])
        values = quickSortFirstElement(rank)

        for value in values:
            for l in list:
                v=ranks[l]
                if(v == value):
                    listFinal.append(l)
        return listFinal

def get_page(url):
    if url in cache:
        return cache[url]
    return ""

def get_next_target(page):
    start_link = page.find('<a href=')
    if start_link == -1: 
        return None, 0
    start_quote = page.find('"', start_link)
    end_quote = page.find('"', start_quote + 1)
    url = page[start_quote + 1:end_quote]
    return url, end_quote

def get_all_links(page):
    links = []
    while True:
        url, endpos = get_next_target(page)
        if url:
            links.append(url)
            page = page[endpos:]
        else:
            break
    return links

def union(a, b):
    for e in b:
        if e not in a:
            a.append(e)

def add_page_to_index(index, url, content):
    words = content.split()
    for word in words:
        add_to_index(index, word, url)

def add_to_index(index, keyword, url):
    if keyword in index:
        index[keyword].append(url)
    else:
        index[keyword] = [url]

def lookup(index, keyword):
    if keyword in index:
        return index[keyword]
    else:
        return None

def crawl_web(seed): # returns index, graph of inlinks
    tocrawl = [seed]
    crawled = []
    graph = {}  # <url>, [list of pages it links to]
    index = {} 
    while tocrawl: 
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            content = get_page(page)
            add_page_to_index(index, page, content)
            outlinks = get_all_links(content)
            graph[page] = outlinks
            union(tocrawl, outlinks)
            crawled.append(page)
    return index, graph

def compute_ranks(graph):
    d = 0.8 # damping factor
    numloops = 10

    ranks = {}
    npages = len(graph)
    for page in graph:
        ranks[page] = 1.0 / npages

    for i in range(0, numloops):
        newranks = {}
        for page in graph:
            newrank = (1 - d) / npages
            for node in graph:
                if page in graph[node]:
                    newrank = newrank + d * (ranks[node] / len(graph[node]))
            newranks[page] = newrank
        ranks = newranks
    return ranks

##########################################################################################
# Method quickSortFirstElement                                                           #
##########################################################################################        
def quickSortFirstElement(values):
    if len(values) <= 1:
        return values 
    minor, mid, major = [], [],[] 
    pivot = values[0]

    i=0

    while (i < len(values)):

        if values[i] < pivot: 
            minor.append(values[i])
        elif values[i] == pivot:
            mid.append(values[i])
        else:
            major.append(values[i])

        i = i + 1

    return quickSortFirstElement(major) + mid + quickSortFirstElement(minor)

#Here are some example showing what ordered_search should do:

#Observe that the result list is sorted so the highest-ranking site is at the
#beginning of the list.

#Note: the intent of this question is for students to write their own sorting
#code, not to use the built-in sort procedure.

index, graph = crawl_web('http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/index.html')
ranks = compute_ranks(graph)

print ordered_search(index, ranks, 'Hummus')

#>>> ['http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/kathleen.html', 
#    'http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/nickel.html', 
#    'http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/arsenic.html', 
#    'http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/hummus.html', 
#    'http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/index.html']

print ordered_search(index, ranks, 'the')
#>>> ['http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/nickel.html',

#    'http://udacity.com/cs101x/urank/hummus.html',

What he asks is if the standard deviation grows, shrinks or stays (about) the same with the size of the sample. The empirical standard deviation obviously depend on n, but it does not particularly grows or shrinks with the size of the sample. It gets closer and closer to the true standard deviation of the distribution as the sample size increases. Edit: I see you removed "They depend on $%n$%.", so I believe you understand.

title: Solutions for hw6.3star
body:
My solution - without quicksort

def ordered_search(index, ranks, keyword):
match=lookup(index,keyword)    
if match:
    result=[]
    for i in match:
        act_rank=ranks[i]
        pos=0
        temp=[]
        for elem in result:
            if act_rank<ranks[elem]:
                pos=pos+1  
        temp=result[0:pos]
        temp.append(i)
        temp=temp+result[pos:]
        result=temp        
    return result
return None

Basically, we are first measuring the discrepancy between what we actually got (10.8) and what we expected to get (12) and it is -1.2 hours. Than we standardize this, that is we figure out how many standard deviations that discrepancy represents. That's why we are dividing -1.2 by [ sigma/ sqrt(n) ]. For each new problem the amount of discrepancy will be different, but once we standardize it and get the number of standard deviations that discrepancy represents, that is a universally recognized measure of deviation. Sometimes this is referred to as a z-score or in the context of hypothesis testing, it is also called the test statistic.

I am assuming that one can show derive this formula starting from the confidence interval formula and vice versa.

This link includes the formula I used above: http://math.elon.edu/statistics112/hyp_testing.html

Sebastian did not use this formula since he did hypothesis testing using confidence intervals, but Adam used a variation of this in problem set 5-5. There, the formula was slightly more complicated, since his example had to do with comparing two groups.

You can check out page 5 in the following link for a more comprehensive list of all different types of test statistic formulas, including those for single sample problems and for dual sample problems: http://apcentral.collegeboard.com/apc/public/repository/ap09_frq_statistics.pdf

(Note: My major is actually "Information Systems", which might be slightly different than IT, but I think they're similar.)

As an Information Systems major, I can confirm that fndmntl and Gibgezr's answers are spot-on, except I wouldn't call it "Diet CS". It concentrates on a broader range of topics than what CS does, while CS focuses on programming. Because of this, the CS curriculum includes the supporting courses around that - such as data structures, algorithms, etc. IT/IS concentrates more on how to effectively leverage the use of these programs in a business environment.

In my case, the programming portion was covered in two Java courses, as well as a course covering of web development languages (JS, PHP, etc). However, the reasoning behind the Java courses was more to understand it decently enough to manage teams of programmers. It definitely didn't get into hardcore algorithms or anything.

In IS/IT, a lot of emphasis is placed on developing a curriculum that can bridge the gap between business and programming. Executives understand business well, but they often don't understand programming. At the same time, software developers may not be in a position to understand business requirements. One aspect of IT, systems analysis, focuses on studying how a business operates, transforming that into a logical model, then using that as a starting point for a software development project.

If you're interested the scope of my curriculum involved topics (in order of depth of coverage):

  • Systems Analysis and Design
  • Database Architecture/Administration
  • Network Architecture
  • Information Security
  • Project Management
  • Programming
  • Information Storage

Lower level courses (100/200) tended to be more similar to the pre-req's that a business major would need (Accounting, Economics, Law + plus various basic reqs). In a CS major, the pre-req's would be more math oriented.

bucket is not a list itself, it is a reference to a list instead. That's a big difference. If bucket would hold a list then the list would die (like integers do) once the block where it's defined finishes. But because bucket just points to a list, you can mutate that list with bucket and as long as this list is still referenced somehow (e.g. by a global variable) this list won't die once the variable bucket dies. In fact all other references to that list will show the changes that were made through bucket.

I wondered the same thing. The stated reason is that it shows us how thinking and coding can work together to solve problems. It also suggests something deeper about the interplay between them. Brute force can make a problem trivial that is analytically fairly difficult but brute force solutions are slower by orders of magnitude than the solutions that we come up with analytically.

In robotics, brute force approaches make possible formulations that aren't analytically tractable such as arbitrary distribution shapes. Yet analytical insight enables us to formulate versions of those algorithms that are vastly more efficient than brute force. Consider the Kalman Filter, it's an analytical solution but to a problem that's often the wrong one. When we generalize it, we're left with an integral of an arbitrary function that we can't solve. So we can approach it by brute force using a histogram filter but that becomes slow at high enough resolution with enough dimensions. If we shift to analyzing where the computation is occurring, we see that much of it is in low probability regions. So why not make accuracy proportional to probability...and that's the particle filter.

title: Advice to students with no previous experience
body:
Here is my advice to students with no prior programming experience. Hopefully, this will help the neophytes in next hexamester’s class.

This is what I wish I knew the first day of class.

• Programming requires active learning. If you are a successful passive learner that will help, but you still need to get your hands dirty if you want to learn how to code. That is why Dave continually challenges you with quizzes. Take his problems, alter them and rework them. To learn a new procedure, try to apply it in various ways. As you work more problems, you will start to see when and where you can apply the tools that you are learning.

• Keep a list of the procedures, processes, and commands as they are introduced. This will help you to reduce time searching PDF files and reviewing videos.

• The best place to test your code is at this python tutorial site. It allows you to step thru your code and see how the computer executes it. The site also has examples of coding procedures/commands that you can run. The only limitation is that it times out at 200 steps.

• Experienced programmers will help you. Though there is no programming experience required to take this course, the majority of active students will have prior experience. The bad new is that they will kick your ass on the homework. The good news is that they will teach you what you have problems learning. In my class, one generous experienced programmer held weekly study groups on Google+ and another posted all his answer for one week’s homework with his explanations of how he addressed the problems.

• Use the discussion forum. If you need help, post your questions on the discussion forum. If you think the answer you get is inadequate or you did not understand the comment, follow-up with additional questions in the same thread.

• Programming can be frustrating – don’t take it personally. You will get error messages for a variety of reasons. Over time you will get better at finding the cause and learning techniques and practices that help reduce errors. But if you cannot solve a problem, post your code on the discussion forum. The more experienced programers have made the error you just made and they are excellent at proofreading code.

• Reviewing other people’s code helps you learn. There usually are many correct coding solutions for the same problem. You can learn new tools and techniques by seeing how someone else answered a question. Frequently student post their answers on the discussion forum.

• Remember why you decided to take this class. I assume you want to learn something new. You did not take this course to improve your GPA. Most of you will find this course to be challenging and many of the experienced programmers will not. The grades compare you to them --- instead, compare you to yourself. Do you know more today than you did last week. Focus on improving your knowledge and abilities. If, on the other hand, you pick this stuff up easily, I am happy for you, please help those who are not as quick on the uptake and there really is no need for you to broadcast your success.

• Partial credit really does not apply in coding. This isn’t a history class. On one homework problem, I coded it correctly, but my procedure name was “Median” rather than “median” – yes, 100% wrong because of a capital letter. (See Remember why you decided to take this class.) In this case, my answer was marked wrong because the software that was grading the homework only had “median” as an acceptable answer. But a more important point is that in the real world if you get coding 99% right – it still is wrong.

The instruction in CS101 is excellent – good luck.

title: Homework 5.7 Marked Incorrect
body:
Problem 5.7

I'm pretty sure I know where I screwed myself on this one. While playing around with it, I added an if statement that caused it to skip printing the very last result of the running factorial. I did it for cosmetic reasons because we were calling factorial() preceded by a print statement. This caused the final result to be printed twice; once as part of the running factorial, and again when the print statement printed the result. So, to make it more aesthetically pleasing, I told it not to print the last line in the running factorial calculation.Oops. However, I believe that the actual cache code works properly. You can't really tell by speed because calculating factorial is so fast that you need to give it a huge number to make it take any time, then you run into memory issues. I was using factorial2() to see how high you'd need to go to see any difference.

On another note, the recursive fibonacci procedure is interesting, but it doesn't use the cache.

Thank you,
reighnie

#[Double Gold Star] Memoization is a way to make code run faster by saving
#previously computed results.  Instead of needing to recompute the value of an
#expression, a memorized computation first looks for the value in a cache of pre-
#computed values.

#Define a procedure, cached_execution(cache, code), that takes in two inputs: a
#cache, which is a Dictionary that maps strings representing Python expressions
#to their previously computed values, and code, a string that is a Python
#expression.  Your procedure should return the value of code, but should only
#evaluate code if it has not been previously evaluated.

def cached_execution(cache,code):
    return eval(code)

#Here is an example showing the desired behavior of cached_execution:

def factorial(n):
    if not cache:
        print "Running factorial"
    else:
        r = 'result = result * ' + str(n)
        #print 'cached'
        if r in cache:
            return cache[r]
    result = 1
    for i in range(2, n + 1):
        r = 'result = result * ' + str(i)
        #print r
        if r not in cache:
            result = result * i
            cache[r]=result
            if i<n:
                print result

    return result

def factorial2(n, silent=False):
    if (not cache) and (not silent):
        print "Running factorial"
    else:
        r = 'result = result * ' + str(n)
        if r in cache:
            print 'In cache '
            return cache[r]
    result = 1
    for i in range(2, n + 1):
        r = 'result = result * ' + str(i)
        #print r
        if r not in cache:
            result = result * i
            cache[r]=result
            if not silent:
                print result

    return result

cache = {} # start cache as an empty dictionary
### first execution (should print out Running factorial and the result)
print 'First time:'
print cached_execution(cache, 'factorial(50)')                           
#print cache
print "Second time:"
### second execution (should only print out the result)
print cached_execution(cache, 'factorial(50)')

#Here is a more interesting example using cached_execution 
#(do not worry if you do not understand this, though, 
#it will be more clear after Unit 6):

def cached_fibo(cache, n):
    if n == 1 or n == 0:
        return n
    else:
        return cached_execution(cache, 'cached_fibo(cache, ' + str(n - 1) + ')') \
               + cached_execution(cache, 'cached_fibo(cache, ' + str(n - 2) + ')')

cache = {}
# do not try this at home...at least without a cache!
#print cached_execution(cache, 'cached_fibo(cache, 100)')

#Hint: you will need to use the built-in eval function similarly to how we used
#it in time_execution.  The eval function takes a string as input, and returns
#the result of evaluating that string as a Python expression.

#print 'First time:'
#print cached_fibo(cache, 25)
#print cache 
#print "Second time:"
#print cached_fibo(cache, 25)
print 'Problem 7 End'
print ''

Answering Matt: I'm not sure, but p as probability makes sense, and I took it when used with the mean as indicating that the average / mean (given enough samples) is probably a good indicator that there is a high probability that succeeding samples taken under the same conditions will tend to fall within the same ranges as the original samples.

I took a class several years back in educational testing to determine success / failure of various methodologies and/or resources. The assumption was that if 50 of 100 students in the trials typically made a "C" (or whatever the grading standard was on the final test, when a given course of study involved testing at the end), and the remaining students fell on a symmetrical bell curve, then the unit / course / whatever would prove to be statistically fair for all students in the same categories as the tested students. Follow up testing (typically over the course of several years) was expected to show the same trends. Unfortunately, we were given the statistical outcome for the various studies, but teaching us how to run the statistics ourselves was not part of the course, so I can't explain the outcomes mathematically. The primary reason I'm taking this course, is because I felt and continue to feel that just being given numbers without the understanding of how those numbers were generated didn't really teach me anything about the validity of educational testing. I have at various times been somewhat to highly challenged by this course, but am really glad to finally have the opportunity to fill out my knowledge so that I can, hopefully, eventually understand how the data we studied in the education class was created, and consequently be able to determine for myself whether or not those studies were valid. :-)

title: Passing Grade
body: What is considered a passing grade 75%?

first of all, I wanted to say that this was much more interesting than running on the sodukus. I'd like to hear what others are using for bug reports. (the released valgrind doesn't handle MacOSX applications well, although saw some posts that they may have some of the bugs fixed in the SVN repository)

Anyways, I tested on a MacSPICE, a MacOSX CAD program for circuit simulation. I used the sample libraries provided with the program as my starting point, and fuzzed per the Charlie Miller / class video. The program didn't like the normal unix path I was feeding it, so I needed to move the fuzzed file to an application-specific directory first, and then launch the program with the source file as an argument. I added a very minor bit of logging to save the files that caused crashes:

num_crashes = 0
...
process = subprocess.Popen([app,fuzz_output])
time.sleep(1)
crashed = process.poll()
if not crashed:
    process.terminate()
else:
    num_crashes = num_crashes + 1
    print "Crash# " + str(num_crashes) + " for fuzzed file " + file_choice
    log_crash_fname = "crashed_fuzzfile_" + str(num_crashes) + ".cir"
    open(log_crash_fname,'wb').write(buf)

After ~2k iterations, I'd had 5 crashes due to invalid memory execution attempts. These were being caused by corruption of some arguments to some of the SPICE deck commands:

* Normal line:
.disto dec 20 1.0e3 1.0e8 0.9

* Corrupted line:
.disto dec 20 1.0e3 1.0N8 0.9

Update:
I had sent one of these bugs to the developer, and just got a nice note back indicating that he had found and fixed the cause of the crash. And then he invited me to send any other bugs found (while also warning about the ability to construct and execute shell commands with certain inputs). I did feel a bit guilty about sending the bug back to him, as in the scheme of things, crashing from an invalid input isn't as big of a deal for this type of program as, say, not running a valid analysis or giving an incorrect result. I have really appreciated his ongoing development effort of this tool over the years (most non-commercial SPICE tools don't get too far from the crusty university code). So, cheapeau!!!

Matt

This is what worked for me:

  • The robot starts in the lane and section specified in init, at the start of the section.
  • For each section, you take the cost of the lane used to enter that section.
  • Sometime during a section, you chose which lane you are going to take for the next section.
  • The last section that the robot traverses is the the one before the goal. It can use the same lane as the goal or the one next to it.

And the reason it shrinks is that it is tied to the sample mean's standard deviation, which can be estimated as $%1/\sqrt{N}$% times the standard deviation of the population. The larger the sample size N, the closer we can expect the sample mean to be to the true population mean -- hence there is less spread in the estimates, and the variance, standard deviation, and confidence interval all become smaller.
@Ken: please tag your posts as spoiler when you post the solutions. thanks!

I'll leave this to @Adam, but note that the central limit theorem suggests that a sample mean (or any other linear combination of independent variates) tends toward a normal distribution, [almost] regardless of the original population distribution. Of course, we only have an N of one if we consider the sample mean to be our variate. I'm not sure how that's handled in the proofs of these techniques.

def triangle(n):
    if n == 0:
        return []
    if n == 1:
        return [[1]]
    tmp = []
    for i in range(0, n - 2):
        tmp += [triangle(n - 1)[n - 2][i] + triangle(n - 1)[n - 2][i + 1]]
    return triangle(n - 1) + [[1] + tmp + [1]]

I think some have misread or misinterpreted the question. The OP is not suggesting that everyone should be considering TDD, but asking how those of us with development knowledge and some knowledge of Python might use CS101 as a vehicle to help us practice TDD using Python.

Obviously not all questions are suited to TDD but I have tried to use it where possible. Below is the test code I wrote for HW 2.6. I initially used assert statements like this.

assert find_last('aaaa', 'a') == 3
assert find_last('', 'a') == -1
assert find_last('', '') == 0
assert find_last('aaaa', '') == 4
assert find_last('aaaa', 'aa') == 2
assert find_last('aaaa', 'aaa') == 1
assert find_last('aaaa', 'aaaa') == 0
assert find_last('aaaa', 'aaaaa') == -1
assert find_last('How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?', 'wood') == 65
assert find_last('aAa', 'aa') == -1
assert find_last('It works fine for me too', '') == len('It works fine for me too')
print 'Tests pass'

This relies on the assert statement raising an exception that stops execution but has the downside of not running all tests and not indicating which test failed, so I refined it to this.

def test(search, target, expected_result):
    actual_result = find_last(search, target)
    if actual_result == expected_result:
        return True
    print "find_last('" + search + "', '" + target + "'): actual =", actual_result, ", expected = ", expected_result
    return False

success = test('aaaa', 'a', 3)
success = success and test('', 'a', -1)
success = success and test('', '', 0)
success = success and test('aaaa', '', 4)
success = success and test('aaaa', 'aa', 2)
success = success and test('aaaa', 'aaa', 1)
success = success and test('aaaa', 'aaaa', 0)
success = success and test('aaaa', 'aaaaa', -1)
success = success and test('How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?', 'wood', 65)
success = success and test('aAa', 'aa', -1)
success = success and test('It works fine for me too', '', len('It works fine for me too'))

if success:
    print 'All tests pass'

So now it will print a message for all failing tests, showing the input values along with expected and actual results. If all tests pass a message is printed indicating this.

body:

deep_count(1)

This is not a list. Should it return 1 or 0?

The previous answers are correct in that you don't need a random number generator. That said, this problem is certainly solvable with a monte carlo approach. Doing so introduces some additional challenges to ensure that the answer is correct with sufficiently high probability.
So far, it has been just videos. homework and the forums.

You can also use

name[1:].capitalize()
You should be able to derive what you need from the probability. pHit and pMiss just give information about sensor accuracy. Writing it down in terms of Bayes Rule might be suggestive.

No, because they're scaling factors not probabilities. See here and other threads for more discussion. To convert to probabilities, just norm to 1. So 1/(0.6+0.2)=1.25. Hence, 0.6*1.25=0.75 is the probability of the sensor being correct. Since you normalize the final probabilities anyway, it doesn't matter if you do this or not. You could even use 6 and 2 as the factors if you prefer integers.

Almost no course in CS curriculum is about a certain programming language. The programming techniques courses are mostly about building abstractions and techniques to managing complexity, which happen to use a certain language, but the language itself is (or should be) just a vector. Teaching the basics of a certain programming language is something better left for recitations and seminars, or in an online setting - a small companion course.

More so, pointers and references are not just another concept which appear in some programming languages. They are fundamental constructs which arise naturally from the fact that any computer has a working memory. It is my opinion that they should be introduced very early in the curriculum, during 101. So it is IMO an understanding of the basic data structures, which I mentioned before. I am constantly dismayed at how little attention those fundamental concepts get in way too many intro courses, and that ppl consider those some form of black magic which is used only to code drivers or whatever. The result is that many students loose sight of how you should structure data and build ADt's(which out in the wild proves very important, and the place where many programmers fail, they fail to abstract sensibly the data). Make ppl learn how to implement basic data structures, how to structure data , how to chose more advanced data structures sensibly, how to build custom structure on those primitives, teach data structure starting from CS 101, and slowly build to something like 212, which is an outstanding course, and you will create much better programmers IMO.

title: Homework5: Correct solutions
body:
I had no time to provide such post last week, but here it is for HW5. So here you go and remember, before posting "incorrect grading" question, please check:

  • The solution video (the video right after the homework submission form), which should be available, now,
  • This post, which contains all the most frequent mistakes in homework.
  • Correct solutions and their explanations in this post. Please note that for programming assignments, there is more than one correct solution (actually there is infinite number of them) and the fact that you did not write exactly the same thing as me does not mean, your solution is inevitably incorrect. Feel free to paste your correct solutions here, in case you approached the problem differently - it will be interesting to compare them.
  • "Incorrect grading" posts from other people on this forum, which may contain your answer.

HW5.1: Growth

Function #1:

def sum_list(p):
    sum = 0
    for e in p:
        sum = sum + e
    return sum

There is exactly one loop, which is going through all elements of its input list p, thus complexity of this function definitely is linear, i.e. O(n).

Function #2:

def has_duplicate_element(p):
   res = []
   for i in range(0, len(p)):
       for j in range(0, len(p)):
           if i != j and p[i] == p[j]:
               return True
   return False

This function contains two loops and both of them will visit each element of input list p exactly once. First, all elements will be compared to the first one, then all elements will be compared to the second one, etc. etc. until all elements will be compared with the last one. We are here speaking about the worst case, naturally. In other case, it may happen that the first and second element might be the same, which will end the function and return true almost immediately. But that is not the point. Regarding complexities, you are always (well, not really, but almost - average case is also important sometimes) thinking about the worst case. And this function has quadratic complexity, i.e. O(n^2).

Function #3:

def mystery(p):
   i = 0
   while True:
       if i >= len(p):
           break
       if p[i] % 2:
           i = i + 2
       else:
           i = i + 1
   return i

This mysterious function, whatever it does, its complexity indeed is linear, i.e. O(n). That is true in the worst case, when all the values in the input list p are not divisible by 2. It even stays true in the best case, when all those values are divisible by 2, its complexity will just not go up so fast (i.e. 1/2 O(n)), but that is linear function as well (and constants like that 1/2 are being neglected, when speaking about complexities, anyway).

HW5.2: Hash String

Statement #1

The number of string comparisons done to lookup a keyword that is not a key in the hash table may be less than the number needed to lookup a keyword that is a key in the hash table.

This one is true. Just imagine a keyword, which is not in a hash table, but if it was, it would belong to the bucket, which is currently empty. Result of looking up such non-existent keyword is produced without even one string comparison. Opposing example to this would be a keyword present in a hash table, stored on last position in a bucket, which contains other 200 (in fact, just one is enough to make that statement true) keywords.

Statement #2

We should expect the time to lookup most keywords in the hash table will decrease as we increase the number of buckets.

We should indeed expect that. If we have just one bucket, all keywords go into it, which will effectively make our "one-bucket-hash-table" behave like a list, with linear complexity. In case of two buckets, the average lookup time will be halved. In theory, such "two-bucket-hash-table" might end up with all keywords, except only one, being stored in one bucket and just one in the other bucket. Looking up such keyword would require constant time as opposed to linear time, which would be needed in "one-bucket-hash-table". Such case as described here is indeed highly unprobable, but not impossible and the question says we should not we always must.

Anyway, it will not be as unprobable with "normal" hash tables, containing at least several buckets and in general, the more buckets the hash table has, it becomes more easier to spread all keywords in such a way that each bucket will contain at most one of them, which makes lookup faster.

Statement #3

It is always better to have more buckets in a hash table.

Well, it might seem so, but it is not entirely correct. I was tempted to say it is correct, because I was not sure whether also such things should be taken into account, but this question says always, not most of the time or something similar. The truth is, that when you take everything (e.g. also memory limitations) into account, this statement can not hold. Just try to think about it this way: In case it is always better to have more buckets in a hash table, the best hash table will have infinite number of buckets. Given that each bucket occupies at least some space, you will need really huge memory/harddrive/whatever in order to put it there (not speaking about swapping, locality of reference etc.).

Matter of fact, best hash table is such one, which has exactly the same number of buckets as keywords stored. This is obviously not possible in practice though. In case I remember correctly (I might be wrong, it is long time since I was looking at these things), hash table is (statistically) able to spread stored keywords very well (i.e. without too many conflicts, which means too many keywords in the same bucket) in case it is cca 95% full (i.e. <keywords> / <buckets> = 0.95). 95% is unbelievably high number, but it is true.

Statement #4

The time to lookup a keyword in the hash table is always less than the time it would take in a linear time list (as used in Unit 4).

Almost all of the time, including worst case, it is true. But not always. Just imagine list, with the keyword you are searching for right at its beginning (i.e. first position) and compare that case to hash table containing your keyword in a bucket together with other 200 keywords and, even worse, your keyword being at the last position in that bucket. Improbable, but not impossible - statement #4 is wrong.

HW5.3 Is Offered

def is_offered(courses, course, hexamester):
  return course in courses[hexamester]

This is nice one-liner. It is, of course, also possible to write it e.g. like this:

def is_offered(courses, course, hexamester):
  if course in courses[hexamester]:
    return True
  else:
    return False

It is the same thing, just on more lines and arguably more readable for some. It just checks whether the course is present in given hexamester and returns appropriate boolean value.

See also this post by @PeterUdacity about issues regarding this assignment.

HW5.4 When Offered

def when_offered(courses,course):
  # define the future result:
  # we are supposed to return a list so let's initialize it to empty list
  res = []
  # go through hexemesters
  for hs in courses:
    # check if the course is present in given hexemester
    if course in courses[hs]:
      # the only slightly tricky part: do not add the same hexemester twice
      if hs not in res:
        # append hexemester to the result
        res.append(hs)
  # return result after going through all hexemesters and all its courses
  return res

Not as easy as previous one, but still pretty straightforward. The most difficult thing on whole this series (3,4 and 5) is to make sense of the dictionary's structure. In fact, I hope you would almost never use such a huge dictionary in dictionary in dictionary ( am I the only one being reminded of Frank Herbert? :) ) in real practice (please correct me if I am wrong, because I am no Python guru, but I would give fair share of arguments to support this statement of mine). There are things like classes out there, which are designed to help you in organizing such monsters. This series are there just for pedagogical purposes, I think, in order to exercise working with dictionaries (not to give some best-practices example).

HW5.5: Hash String

def involved(courses, person):
  # define the future result:
  # we are supposed to return a dictionary this time so let's initialize it to empty dictionary
  res = {}

  # traverse all hexemesters
  for hs in courses:

    # traverse all courses in each hexemester
    for c in courses[hs]:

      # traverse all attributes in each course
      for attr in courses[hs][c]:

        # if the value of attribute equals to name of searched for person
        # let's append it to the result
        if courses[hs][c][attr] == person:

          # but first make sure that there is a list to append to
          if not hs in res:
            res[hs] = []
          # when we are sure, we can proceed with append itself
          res[hs].append(c)

  # and finally return result after going through whole input dictionary
  return res

And the very same thing again, just slightly more difficult. Actually, the only difference (in difficulty I mean) between this and the previous one is that this one needs more loops. "The tricky" part of adding the key into dictionary in case it does not exist is the same as in previous assignment, just the other way around - we need to add it, in case it does not exist instead of not adding it twice.

HW5.6: Refactoring

# new function:
def hashtable_get_entry(htable, key):
    bucket = hashtable_get_bucket(htable, key)
    for entry in bucket:
        if entry[0] == key:
          return entry
    return None

# original function:
#def hashtable_update(htable, key, value):
    #bucket = hashtable_get_bucket(htable, key)
    #for entry in bucket:
        #if entry[0] == key:
            #entry[1] = value
            #return
    #bucket.append([key, value])

# refactored function:
def hashtable_update(htable, key, value):
    entry = hashtable_get_entry(htable, key)
    if entry != None:
        entry[1] = value
        return
    hashtable_get_bucket(htable, key).append([key, value])

# original function:    
#def hashtable_lookup(htable, key):
    #bucket = hashtable_get_bucket(htable, key)
    #for entry in bucket:
        #if entry[0] == key:
            #return entry[1]
    #return None

# refactored function:
def hashtable_lookup(htable, key):
    entry = hashtable_get_entry(htable, key)
    if entry != None:
      return entry[1]
    return None

This is what you will do for a great deal of time in case you will do dome serious programming after finishing this course. Without refactoring, your code would get uglier and uglier (especially when you are not the only one, who is modifying it) very fast until the point, when it would get unreadable, unmaintainable, unusable and worthless. That is why refactoring is very important part of programmer's job.

What was done here is very simple. Duplicated piece of code was identified (as part of assignment), you were then supposed to move this code to the newly created function and call that function at the original place of the code. Done - as easy as that. However, at least in real world, always make sure you do not actually break the code by refactoring (customers tend to be unhappy to pay you salary for the same visible result, which just contains more bugs). Ideally, you should have unit tests in place and run them for each small change you do to the code.

One more comment regarding my solution: It would probably be a good idea to make the new function return both element and bucket, because hashtable_update is calling hashtable_get_bucket twice. Once as part of hashtable_get_entry and second time directly on the last line. This idea is arguable, though, since it does not influence complexity very much (hashtable_get_bucket is of O(1), i.e. constant time function, so we are really speaking about micro-optimization here) and makes the code slightly harder to read (at least I feel like that).

HW5.7: Hash String

def cached_execution(cache,code):
  if code in cache:
    return cache[code]
  else:
    res = eval(code)
    cache[code] = res
    return res

Just look into cache to see whether the code caller is asking for is already there and based on your findings either return already known result or execute the code, store the result and return it. This is very simple demonstration of how cache works like. However, it is missing several important points:
- Computer's memory is not unlimited. Because of that, it is impossible to hold all results in the cache forever. There must be some means of removing least needed (whatever that means - e.g. last accessed, least accessed, etc.) records from the cache. Otherwise it will only grow and grow, until it will be impossible to hold it in the memory/harddrive/whatever.
- Results for the same request may change in time. This probably does not apply to this particular cache, but it indeed does apply to (almost all or even really) all real-world ones. Therefore, we need some means of invalidating records in cache. E.g. your browser may cache web pages you visit most frequently, but those pages always tell your browser (by means of HTTP protocol), how often they need to be really refreshed from the original server instead of using browser's cache.

Edit: Added your image, removing my comment below /Velak

You are correct that the variance of a sample is [usually] the population variance divided by the sample size

Are you sure about that? You are saying that we calculate the variance in the normal fashion (sum up the squared differences from the mean and divide by the number of samples) and then divide by another n factor? I am struggling mightily with some of these concepts and this statement has just set me back quite a bit!

He gets the variances of wˉB and wˉA by squaring their given population standard deviation estimates and dividing by the sample sizes. That follows from the central limit theorem.

Again, same question. I know we calculate the CI by dividing by N and taking the square root, but are you saying that the variance is calculated by squaring sigma and then dividing by N again?

So to put this example into numbers, for PS5-5 the standard deviation is 10. If we convert this as you say into a sample variance we get 100/10000 = .01. If we use the normal formula for variance we get 10*10 which is 100. So you are telling me that the sample variance is .01 but the population variance is 100?

I don't think he threw in a red herring when he said standard deviations add. He said we have to add them. It doesn't necessarily follow that he means simply taking the two numbers and adding them together. It's like saying we have to add 3x^2 + 3x. I wouldn't claim this is 6x^2 but yet you can still add these two terms together if you know x.

title: Solution in One Line to HW5.6
body:
Solution in one line long

I would like to share my code to everyone about HW5.6

def hashtable_util(htable,key,value):
    bucket = hashtable_get_bucket(htable, key)
    for entry in bucket:
        if entry[0] == key:
            if value:
                entry[1] = value
                return
            return entry[1]
    bucket.append([key, value])

def hashtable_update(htable, key, value):
    hashtable_util(htable,key,value)

def hashtable_lookup(htable, key):
    result = hashtable_util(htable,key,None)
    return result

Omega is an information matrix so its inverse is the covariance matrix. The diagonal, as always, is the vector of variances for each component. This is intuitive since we add 1/noise to an entry each time its observed. In the single observation case the inverse this simplifies to 1/(1/noise_1+...+1/noise_n) or for constant noise noise/observations.

In our example, we're weighting inversely proportionately to the standard deviation as opposed to the variance. Also note that the random noise is actually uniformly distributed between -noise and noise.

In the actual implementation of GraphSLAM, the variance is used and the covariance matrix is an accurate reflection of uncertainty to the extent the input variances were correct and the noise is gaussian.

title: Programming as a profession
body:
The teaching of programming has, more or less, been about the same for decades, at least, in terms of content. CS 101 is trying to teach the basics (which isn't easy) of what a language like Python can do. This includes control flow (if, for, procedure calls), things that hold data (variables, lists, dictionaries) often called data structures, and how to make code do things--at its purest, this is algorithms (something is called an algorithm if it solves a mathematically well-defined program).

However, that's the tip of the iceberg. It's the central part of programming. If you don't know this, then it's hard to do anything else.

Since Java was introduced, libraries have become huge in programming. Until then, some programmers had NIH (Not Invented Here) Syndrome which meant, if they didn't write the code, they didn't use the code. This stemmed from computer science education not teaching people how to read other people's code (good or bad). These days, so much has been done in libraries by experienced programmers that writing your own version would produce one that's probably buggier and has fewer features than the libraries.

The next part is collaboration. Programmers have need to collaborate since programming began, but this is more important than ever. Thus, programmers have to deal with multiple people handling the same code and how to resolve and communicate with one another.

  • version control (software that tracks each saved version of your code, and allows you to create different "versions" by a process called branching, and allows you to "tag", i.e., give a name to a snapshot of the files you have at a specific point in time). This is a skill that's beyond programming. (Common examples: Subversion, Git, Perforce)
  • bug tracking software This is now extended to "issue tracking" and can be used to keep track of the progress of code development. (Common examples: Bugzilla, JIRA)

In addition, software design needs to be planned and adjust to changes. This is the whole software development cycle. The old way that was used (and still is used) is called the waterfall model. It divided software development into a few phases. The first is requirements analysis (what does the customer want). Then decisions on what classes and functionality to support. This would often be spelled out in great detail. Then implementation, testing, and acceptance with testing and implementation potentially cycling, and occasionally certain design decisions being revisited.

These days, there's also agile software development that starts with a minimal feature set, emphasizes fast iterations (creating small features every 2-4 weeks) and getting customer feedback.

Then, because people care about saving their data ("persisting it") and doing things on the Web, some programmers must learn "web application stacks" that include a language (like Java), a database (like Oracle), and ways for code to talk to database. This can involve several other technologies.

Then, there's testing. How do you test your code? There are unit tests to test the smaller aspects of the code. There's functional testing. People need to test web pages (Selenium is popular).

There's code organization. So far, you've worked with one file. What if there are hundreds of files? How do you manage this? You start creating folders, but do you come up with your own scheme or follow a standard scheme used in the industry.

You may need to know about build tools that build your software. You may need software to deploy your software. You may want continuous integration that checks any commits for errors and lets you know very quickly that something bad has happened.

And you have to keep an eye out on developing trends in software, lest the industry move some place and you're not aware of it.

CS 101 is like pure essential programming. I liken it to running a restaurant. The essence of running a restaurant is cooking. But there's a lot more to it than that. In particular, there's getting food, organizing the kitchen, establishing roles in the kitchen, creating the menu, pricing the menu, how to handle guests, etc. There's a lot more to running a restaurant effectively than merely cooking. Similarly, there's more to developing software than just programming.

No, under these assignments we don't specify invalid expressions. Whitespace guarantees the start of a new token but if a token ends, a new token begins at the next character. This happens in actual languages too in some cases: a=1*2 is valid in many languages including Python even though no whitespace delimits the symbols. Identifiers can't have numbers so once abc was determined, the lexer considers 123 next.
