Даны 5 ячеек: 2 красные и 3 зеленые. Робот может находиться в любой из них, и мы не знаем, в какой именно ячейке он находится в данный момент. До вопроса №4 робот не сообщал нам о своем местоположении, поэтому вероятность нахождения его в каждой ячейке была одинакова. Теперь он сообщил нам, что находится в красной ячейке. Мы не можем это игнорировать, и должны увеличить вероятность его присутствия в красных ячейках.

Это легко сделать, если домножить вероятность в красных ячейках на один коэффициент, а в зелёных - на другой, причем коэффициент для красных должен быть больше.
Домножим красные ячейки на 0.6, а зелёные - на 0.2, для красных в 3 раза больше, чем для зеленых (нельзя исключать возможность нахождения робота в зелёной ячейке, так как его сенсоры не идеальны, и он может врать).

Вопрос №5: нам предлагают просуммировать значения в каждой ячейке. Оно не равно 1, поэтому полученные в вопросе 4 значения не являются вероятностями.

Вопрос №6: для того, чтобы получить из этих значений вероятности, необходимо их нормализовать, разделив каждое из них на сумму, полученную в вопросе 5.

"What the hell does the mean of the probability of fair coins even mean?"

Remember that the mean is simply the average value. After a large number of flips, the mean will approach the probability,

The 0 and 1 part is just one way to represent a binomial (2 outcome) experiment, quite useful for programming. Say you flip 10 coins, 5 heads 5 tails. 5 * 0 = 0 for tails, 5 * 1 = 5 for heads. The sum of them is 5, divided by the amount of flips which is 10, making it a .5 mean.

In this example, 11th flip will cause it to be (6 heads, 5 tails) or (6 heads, 5 tails), which would result in a mean of .545 or .455.

If, however, you had 100 flips which ended up being equal to the proabbility (50 heads 50 tails and a mean of .5), the 101st flip would result in 51 heads 50 tails or 50 heads 51 tails, or a mean of .51 or .49 depending on if the 101st flip was a heads or tails.

The point is fairly simple with confidence intervals, the more trials (N) you take, the more confident you will be that the mean will fall close to the probability. It's really quite amazing when you get deep into the theory, and has a lot of applications. It's difficult to grasp at first, but keep it up! It's a great way to train your brain and learn something of use. If you still are confused about why he's using 0 and 1 for tails and heads, I could try explaining it a different way.

No, I really mean multiplication by sqrtN and not division. Remember, the variance of (X1+X2+X3+...) = varX1 + varX2+ ... = n*varX. So the stdev is sqrtN*sigmaX

When you talk about the std dev of the sum, you multiply sigma by sqrtN. When you talk about the std dev of the average, you divide by sqrtN.

It tells us how far we've progressed along a vector. The projection of a vector along the x axis is its x coordinate. More generally, it's a coordinate of the vector if we expressed its position in terms of a vector pointing in that direction.

In the lecture we're computing the ratio of the projection to the path to see if the projection exceeds the length of the segment: dot(motion,path)/dot(path,path)=dot(motion,path)/(norm(path)*norm(path))=motion proj path / norm(path)

I agree with you that an alternative presentation would have been clearer and there's certainly value in explaining what the algorithm is actually optimizing. That said, seeing an algorithm first view is also educational, especially for those of us who have seen it before both because it both forces us to think about what an algorithm does given that it seems to work and suggests to those of us with a more mathematical disposition that picking algorithms that seem to work is an effective strategy. This often happens in practice and it can take a surprisingly long time and require more than average creativity to reconcile the approaches.

Consider AdaBoost which was first released in 1995. Friedman, et al. didn't show it was equivalent to a maximum likelihood fit of an additive model until 1998 As a more extreme example, minimum bias, a popular modeling technique among actuaries, wasn't realized to be equivalent to generalized linear models until 26 years later. Perhaps the most famous example is showing that Feynman's algorithm for modifying diagrams is equivalent to a specific set of path integrals, which was though it was shown relatively quickly, was not obvious to most and required months of study by Freeman Dyson before his end of summer epiphany.

You're interested in (approximately) the situation where both the result of A and B at the same time fall in one specific tail of their confidence interval. This chance is only 2.5% * 2.5% = 0.0625%. So your confidence is much, much bigger than 95% (> 99% !)

Note: this is not totally accurate since you can have a situation where the result of e.g. A is not in its tail, but that of B is deep, deep in its tail. This is not very likely though since the distributions have very flat tails.

S0 this should give you a feel why you should have much more confidence than 95%!

As a matter of fact, for precise calculation you have to calculate the z-value with mu = 20-10 = 10 and sigma = sqrt(0.01+0.04). This gives you a z-value of (10 - 9.412)/sqrt(0.01+0.04) = 2.63. This comes down to a confidence level of 99.57%.

You're absolutely right that taxis provide the service but the key reason taxis are expensive (aside from quotas in some areas) is the cost of labor and positioning loss. The lack of driver solves one of those problems directly. The positioning loss will be solved in part through higher utilization and in part through far more sophisticated positioning algorithms.

The other argument you could raise is that people don't like taxis. Some of the reasons include uncertainty about the experience, lack of privacy, potential safety risks. All of those are eliminated by the self-driving taxi.

I'm sure many people will have a similar negative reaction initially but over time it will come to be seen as normal and the advantages will outweigh your fear. Consider how restrictive it is to always have to use the same car regardless of what you're doing. How inefficient is it that you manage repairing and temporarily replacing your car due to mechanical defects?

I think this risk is far enough down the road that it receives little consideration at car companies. Regardless, in a competitive market, rational companies invest in things that cause reduced profitability as long as the innovation reduces profitability less if you also have it. If they didn't, they would suffer the higher unmitigated loss. In more differentiated industries, this can be a bigger problem. This is discussed at length in The Innovator's Dilemma.

title: Collatz computation - astounding results
body:
@John Broecher posted a question, posting a code for testing out the collatz conjecture, the nemesis of many in hw2. I thought about it, I have thought about this problem a bit, having seen it in project euler, and came up with a program to get some numbers, and the results were astounding, mind boggling really.

The code first



import time


collatz_sequence = 1             # initialize the list with 1

time_to_run = float(raw_input())   # in hours

start_time = time.time()

end_time = start_time+time_to_run6060     # time when the loop ends, in seconds

while time.time()<=end_time:              

    temp_list = []

    i = collatz_sequence[-1]+1

    while i!=1:

        temp_list.append(i)

        if i%2:

            i = 3*i+1

        else:

            i = i/2

        if i in collatz_sequence:

            break

    collatz_sequence = collatz_sequence + temp_list

    collatz_sequence.sort()

f = open('collatz_2.txt','w')

f.write('Total values : ' + str(len(collatz_sequence))+'\n')

f.write('Highest value : ' + str(collatz_sequence[-1]) + '\n')

f.write('Digits in highest value : ' + str(len(str(collatz_sequence[-1]))) + '\n')

f.write('Start sequence\n')

f.write('__\n')    # 14 '_'s + 1 new line = 15 chars.

for i in collatz_sequence:

    f.write(str(i)+',')

f.close()

I ran it twice - once for two hours & then for six hours.

The first time it returned a list of 358105 numbers, with the largest being a mammoth 366 digits at ~5.56*10365! The file was almost 51mb in size, with 10754 pages in open office at a font size of 10 - it wouldn't open in gedit.

The second time around I let it run for six hours & got a list of 589089 numbers, in a file of size over 122mb and 25841 pages, with the largest number being 522 digits long at ~7.15*10521.

I had my jaw drop to the floor when I got these results.

Wow, just wow! Also, kudos to Python for handling such huge numbers like a champ.

PS - Sadly, this program doesn't cover all the numbers between 1 & largest. It has gaps, a lot of gaps in between because it starts the next iteration of the main loop with the current largest + 1

If anyone is interested I have blogged about this here, though I think this post is much better than the blog post. Also, if you want to download the code, it's available on code pad

Update

Wrote another program, this one makes a graph of all numbers between 1 & n(and some more) using a python dictionary and each entry in the dictionary has a list, with the first element the next number in the cycle & the second element the length of the cycle.



#!/usr/bin/python

# Program to calculate the Collatz of each number from 1 to n

import math
import time

def collatz(n, cg):
    if n in cg:
        return
    if math.log(n, 2)==int(math.log(n, 2)):
        cg[n]= [int(2**(math.log(n,2)-1)), int(math.log(n, 2))]
        collatz(2**(math.log(n,2)-1), cg)
        return
    else:
        if n%2:
            c= 3*n+1
        else:
            c= n/2
        collatz(c, cg)
        cg[n]= [c, cg[c][4]+1]
        return

def calc_cycle(n):
    collatz_graph= {1: [None, 0]}
    for i in range(2,n+1):
        if i not in collatz_graph:
            collatz(i, collatz_graph)
    return collatz_graph

I think it's pretty efficient, made a graph for 1..1,000,000 in a little over 30 seconds.

The code pad link is here.

@eaglests: I will try to answer your question 1.How does one decide whether we have a two tail or one tail for a given problem? Is that explicitly stated in the question typically?

I would say that this should be stated or at least implied in a given problem situation. For example if we are asked to determine if a new teaching method makes a difference in student achievement (as measured by final exam scores) I would use a two-tailed test, since we are given no indication if the new method will contribute to an increase or decrease in students' scores.

In another situation, to determine if a certain exercise program is helping participants lose weight, we would set the hyp. test as a one tailed test. The Null could be that the program does not work or that the average participant will not lose any weight, i.e. $% \mu =0 $% The alternate could be that $% \mu <0 $% or that the avg. participant will lose weight. (Assuming a negative value represents a loss.)

In general, if the problem just asks something like "Is there a difference in ....... ," then I'd say that we need a two-tailed test. If the question spefically asks if there is a decrease in cholesterol level or if there is an increase in memory retention etc, we need to use a one-tailed test.

You could use a monte carlo algorithm and simulate the assignment of a large number of tuples and determine the fraction that are (1,1). You could also multiply 0.5*0.5. The slicing approach adds two function calls to len, two additions, and two divisions as well as an additional slice call. Since each of these is an individual python operation, it's much slower than the equivalent native code operation. The savings from doing this is ~n/2 comparisons in the worst case in which it's a match. However, in the vast majority of cases with real words, one can determine that they aren't palindromes before you're half-way through the word so there's no savings.

There is an intermediate answer: Have the simulator generate a function that accepts only string and current. It can then refer to edges and accepting as defined in the parent function. The two variables behave like globals for any functions defined in the defining function. They will be referenced before globals though that doesn't matter in this particular case. Also if you need to mutate the variable which we don't, the nonlocal keyword is used instead of the global keyword.

To illustrate see the following. Note that edges and accepting are called edges1 and accepting1 to avoid ambiguity. Global copies are created just to illustrate that they're not referenced.

#Not required. Would cause an error if fsmsimr used these. 
#Demonstrates that Python checks scopes hierarchically.
edges="See elsewhere"  
accepting="Delegate!"

#Operative portion of the code
edges1 = {(1, 'a') : 2,
         (2, 'a') : 2,
         (2, '1') : 3,
         (3, '1') : 3}

accepting1 = [3]

def fsmsim(string, current, edges, accepting):
    def fsmsimr(string,current):        
        if string == "": return current in accepting
        else:
            letter = string[0]
            if (current,letter) in edges:
                return fsmsimr(string[1:],edges[(current,letter)])  
            else: return False
    return fsmsimr(string,current)

print fsmsim("aaa111",1,edges1,accepting1)

f,e,e,d=15,14,14,13. To convert to base 10, recall that each digit represents the number of groups of 16 of the digit that is to its right. So to convert the second rightmost digit multiply that digit by sixteen. The digit to the left of that must be multiplied by 16 to convert it into the units of the digit to the right (groups of 16) and then by 16 once more. So conversion is accomplished by multiply each digit by 16^n where n is the number of places away from the rightmost digit. So 0xfeed=15*16^3+14*16^2+14*16+13=65261

You could argue that it should be a syntax error given that specification but unless you do that explicitly this should work. The reason for this isn't in the language specification. It's because we are writing only one definition for the lexer. The other definitions and the order in which the tokens are checked determines this answer. If you insert the hex function after decimal instead of before, you'll see that you get three x's and 0's.

This not the purpose of this course to cover all concepts that appear in different programming languages. This is an introductory course that does not aim to graduate professional programmers that can go out in the wild and start writing drivers. This course aims to teach the very basics of programming concepts and enable people to start building useful tools right away, without having to deal with low level concepts while doing that. There is only so much that can be covered in a time period.

We don't have a full CS curriculum right now and we are sorry about that. We will try to fill in the gaps with time.

Economically speaking, it's best to just leave it up to chance. If one finds it discouraging to hear another talking at a higher level than them about the material, one can just skip the post. For the rest of us, I find it very exciting that such connections and resources are sitting here to help take the material to the next level. I'm sure Sebastian is more than happy that his course is getting such detail-oriented criticisms, it's an opportunity to edit and improve the course.

Returning to the subject of leaving it to chance, it's not very practical to try and maintain someone to look over these forums for years to come. Just as long as old posts are retained for reference, let nature take its course. Old posts address frequent questions that came about during the course. There will come a time when the enrollment numbers plateau to a few thousand active students, and that's ok. The forum community can strive even with a few hundred students, the lack of expert knowledge would force them to go out and research themselves, which is great experience. I'm sure there will be re-surges of activity in the future as well, especially when courses that recommend this as a prerequisite come out.

The key idea is that either of those equations minimizes the objective in a number of steps inversely proportional to the scale paramater. So if we take 1 as the scale parameter, y[i]+x[i]-y[i]=x[i]. Similarly y[i]+y[i+1]+y[i-1]-2*y[i] sets y[i] to something analogous to the average of the previous and subsequent observations. The weighting between these determines the weighting of the two objective functions. Note that if it weren't for the complication of omitting end points, the second iteration could be simplified to just consider the lagging observation. Of course, in that case, it could be solved as a regularized least squares problem.

title: Does CS262 teach about HTML5?

Please answer.

There are multiple algorithms involved in this: Feature extraction from the sensors which is largely a machine learning computer vision exercise that we'll study in a couple weeks, correspondence between object state and predicted object state to match what's being observed with what's being tracked, the tracking algorithm to predict their future locations, the localization algorithm to estimate the car's trajectory, the car's planning algorithm to decide what it needs to avoid and where it needs to go, and the actual controller to change the car's motions.

While this may seem like a lot of work, remember that human reaction time is on the order of 0.2 seconds. In that time 4 3GHz processors can execute 2.4 billion simple computations.

Another way to consider the problem is by how much notice the car has of an object that's moving into its path. The car itself will only move at most about 12 feet on a non-controlled access road in that time. A human or cat would need to be very near the path for uncertainty to cause an issue and the car would be aware of that in its calculations. To take a sudden movement and get into the path of the car from even a couple feet away would take an amount of time approaching a second which is an enormous amount of time for a computer running efficient algorithms.

See 2:10 in this video for an example of how quickly it reacts.

The landmark locations aren't known. The non-zero values reflect that the measurements are offsets between the landmark location and the position. Consider the equations L1-x1=5. Then we could write [[-1,1],[1,-1]]*[[x1],[L1]]=[[-5],[5]]. Matrix multiplication results in a system of two equivalent equations: L1-x1=5 and x1-L1=-5.

Let's start with the second cell: Initially, we know the robot is there. As you note, after one move there's only a 10% chance it didn't move and hence a 0.1 probability of it being there. The probability of it not moving on its second move is also 10%, which yields a 0.01 (0.1 x 0.1) chance of being in its initial cell after two moves.

Now moving back to the first cell, we see it has the same probability. The reason is that to get there requires two moves of 2: To cell 4 and then wrapping to cell 1. There is no other sequence of moves that will work. The probability of a move of 2 is the same as that of 0 so the answer is the same: 0.1*0.1=0.01.

Now let's consider the most likely case of cell 4. It can arrive there by either moving 2 and then 0, 0 and then 2 or 1 and then 1. So the chance of it happening is the chance of any of those move orders which is their sum. The probability of a move of 2 and then 0 is only 0.01 because each of those moves has a 0.1 probability. The probability of a move of 0 and 2 is the same. The probability of moving 1 each of two times however is the probability of moving 1 (0.8) time the probability of moving 1 again (0.8) which is 0.64. So the total probability is 0.64+0.01+0.01=0.66.

You should now be able to compute the probabilities for cells 3 and 5 to check your understanding.

Once the particle filter converges to a relatively tight unimodal distribution, why not use a Kalman filter to update as long as the measurements remain tightly clustered around the belief? This seems to have two advantages: Computational efficiency and avoiding the degradation in diversity that comes from localization. A new set of particles could be generated to avoid this but why not only generate it once there's more uncertainty and thus more benefit to the particle filter? Do multi-modal or other meaningfully non-normal distributions frequently emerge in a narrowly localized state? Or is the reason simply that it's easy enough to fix the diversity problem in other ways and not worth the additional complexity to switch between filtering methods. If it's the later could you talk more about how you decide to inject diversity in practice?

In most specific cases, yes. The key is to ensure that you traverse it in such a way that no value is needed after it's modified without being stored first. When couldn't you? Imagine that every possible move error has a meaningful non-zero probability. You would need the complete prior matrix for each update in such a case.

In practice, this isn't an issue because the full matrix wouldn't be stored. We normally have a decent idea of where the robot is which means most states have nearly zero probability. If we round that nearly zero probability to zero, we can use sparse matrices while losing little information. Similarly, in a particle filter one needs far fewer particles than the number of states for a sufficiently large system with a decently localized robot.

If you really wanted to save memory while computing a full matrix, the first step would likely be to store the deltas in a separate matrix which could use a more compact type. If you then wanted to implement in place copying to save even more memory, you could modify that algorithm to commit the differentials after verifying that no further cells depend on a previously computed value.
We'll have to change it to Write in Python now.

Note that q copies p so you're changing both of them. To copy p to q, use q=p[:] which creates a new copy of each of the elements in p. Note that for a nested list, this only copies the top-level elements, not the individual elements but that's not relevant here.

Also you might want to try using the % operatore to cycle. Explicitly coding length offsets will break if U cycles more times than you code.

I would presume that it needs to work for all inputs that meet the specifications given in the video. So it should handle an arbitrary numbers of movements and measurements but can assume that they have the same length. Similarly, it should work for a 2D list of arbitrary dimensions but it will always be 2D. The movements also appear to be restricted to a single step in each of four directions or no step.

First we need to figure out what we mean by a method. Generally, a method in this space can be thought of as some combination of assumptions about the world, available data, and heuristics and approximations employed in the solution. Markov refers to the first piece. It is the assumption that our current state contains all information. Assumptions about the world also includes more specific things like the number of dimensions and continuity or discreteness. Our available information was color and motion feedback. Since the problem was so simple, we computed it exactly.

By this definition, in the lecture we implemented a 1-D color/motion exact markov localization algorithm. In the homework, we're implementing a 2-D version. Of course, since they're so similar and it's possible to implement the algorithm so that the number of dimensions is arbitrary, it's often classified as a single algorithm.

I'm sure I'll miss many but to give you some idea for the range of algorithms, I'll give some examples. I believe all algorithms are fundamentally Markovian since given the right state variables, that's a reasonable assumption. The world can be either continuous or discrete as we'll see next week. The vast majority of what I suspect most will call methods for localization are really computational approaches to handling continuity. In a continuous world, we have to make either strong assumptions about errors to facilitate exact computation or approximate. The histogram is an example of approximation by partitioning a continuous space often into a grid. Another common approximation is the particle filter which is based on sampling from a probability distribution and continuing the calculation for each sample point instead of each partition while resampling as an efficient means of convolution. Within each of these methods, there are many more sub-methods based on implementation questions like grid density, resampling adjustments and the like. On the more analytic side, the most basic example is the Kalman filter which assumes that the uncertainty is normally distributed. There are many extensions to it that attempt to compensate for the error of that assumption such as the extended Kalman filter which provides a first order adjustment for non-linearity.

One other assumption we've made in all of these localization algorithms is that they're forward pass. That is we only care about our position at the moment we're there. We could broaden our class of algorithms if we were interested in obtaining the most accurate path of the robot at each point to include those that update all past localizations at each point or as needed.

One can make the robot move and sense in any order. What matters is matching our interpretation of the robot's moving and sensing to what the robot did or in this case, what it's been stipulated that it did.

q and p merely refer to an underlying object which in this case is a list. q=p tells python to make q point to the same thing p does so when you change q you also change p. Try copying with: q=p[:]. This tells python to retrieve all of the elements from p and assign them to q.

This has been discussed extensively. For other comments on the same issue see this thread.

For anyone interested in timing, I wrote a simple benchmark. Comparing the string to its reversed self per BastienC is both shortest and fastest. Adjusting to be case and non-alpha insensitive can be accomplished most efficiently with the translate method. Also note that slicing half strings is less efficient, presumably because it requires two slices.

Some times:

Reversal: 5.07 microseconds

Reversal (case insensitive): 8.80 microseconds

Reversal (case and non-alpha insensitive): 11.28 microseconds

Reversal compare halves (case and non-alpha insensitive): 16.44 microseconds

Recursive: 24.96 microseconds

Comprehension: 40.29 microseconds

RegEx: 47.60 microseconds 

from timeit import Timer
import re
ttable=''.join([chr(i) for i in range(256)]).lower()
nalpha=''.join(['' if chr(i).isalpha() else chr(i) for i in range(256)])

def t(n):
    print "Failed Test" if eval('map(%s,P)'% n)!=PRes else \
    u"%s runs for %f \u03bcs" % \
    (n,10*Timer('map(%s,P)'% n,'from __main__ import %s,P'% n).timeit(number=100000))

P=['kayak','madam','able was I ere I saw elba','alecsileminaretteranimeliscela',
   'this is a test','a word','python','non']
PRes=[True, True, True, True, False, False, False, True]

isPComprehension=lambda s:all([s==r for s,r in zip(s,s[::-1])])
def isPReverse(s):return s==s[::-1] 
def isPReverseCINS(s):
    s=s.lower()
    return s==s[::-1] 
def isPReverseAlpha(s):
    s=s.translate(ttable,nalpha)
    return s==s[::-1] 
def isPReverseAlpha1(s):
    s=s.translate(None,nalpha).lower()
    return s==s[::-1] 
def isPReverseAlphaHalf(s):
    s=s.translate(ttable,nalpha)
    return s[:(len(s)-2)/2:-1]==s[0:(len(s)+1)/2] 
def isPRE(s):
    s = ''.join(re.split('\W+',s)).lower()
    return s == s[::-1]
def isPRec(s):
        return (s[0] == s[-1]) and isPRec(s[1:-1]) if len(s) else True

t('isPReverse')
t('isPReverseCINS')
t('isPReverseAlpha')
t('isPReverseAlpha1')
t('isPReverseAlphaHalf')
t('isPRec')
t('isPComprehension')
t('isPRE')

The middle one which is a list comprehension is the fastest. My quick benchmark on p of length 1000 shows times of 233, 105, and 237 microseconds respectively. It's easy to run microbenchmarks like this with the timeit module. The code I used was:

from timeit import Timer
def normalize1(p):
    q = []
    s = sum(p)
    for i in range(len(p)):
        q.append(p[i]/s)
    return q
def normalize2(p):
    s = sum(p)
    return [x/s for x in p]
def normalize3(p):
    s = sum(p)
    return map(lambda x: x/s, p)

p=[0.0001]*1000
for i in range(1,4):

For example, the following code generates the message: "Incorrect. Your function didn't provide the right update for input of (9., 6., 5., 4.)":

def update(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
    new_mean =(var2*mean1+var1*mean2)/(var1+var2)
    new_var =1/(1/var1+1/var2)
    if (10., 9., 13., 2.)==(mean1, var1, mean2, var2):
        return [new_mean, new_var]
    else: return "Wrong Answer"

The example refers to tracking another object though at constant speed tracking a fixed point from a moving object is the same.

The key attribute of a cyclic world is that you can't fall off of it. Our world is cyclic too but it's large enough that it's rarely noticed. That said it is possible to have barriers in cyclic worlds which introduce the edge problem. For example, a road is on a cyclic world but we assume for most purposes, the car's possible world ends at its sides. I suspect that they account for this by assigning a low prior probability to being off the road.

The problem of not knowing what the world looks like is known as Simultaneous Localization and Mapping. There are a variety of approaches for this that all rely on expanding the list of unknowns we estimate to include features. See here for more details.

You can run sense and move independently. Just call one or the other as the information is received.

As used in this course a 2D array is a list of lists. You can initialize explicitly with: L=[[1,2],[2,3]]. You can also use a comprehension such as [[a+b for a in range(1,3)] for b in range(2)] which produces the same result.

You can also build it up through a loop:

L=[]
for a in range(2):
    r=[]
    for b in range(1,3):
       r.append(b+a)
    L.append(r)

It's also possible to simply copy list uses the * operator but this creates references which creates problems if you later change the list so if you're just starting out, avoid.

The sig variables are the variances for their respective measures. So measurement_sig and motion_sig are the variances for each entry in measurements and motions respectively. Sigma is our initial uncertainty. Setting sigma to a very high value makes the distribution relatively flat which expresses that we don't know much about the state initially. It's similar to initializing p to a uniform distribution for histogram.

This is known as the correspondence problem which was mentioned and quickly dismissed in the video. The simplest solution is the maximum likelihood approach. In short, given your approximate knowledge of where you are and an approximate location for each car, compute for each measurement a probability of it corresponding to a known car and assign the measurement to the car with the highest probability. Of course, if you're allowed to have cars move in and out of view, you'd add a new car if it had low likelihood of being an existing one. I imagine this is relatively straightforward since cars don't generally go into reverse on a road.

This is correct but it's important to understand the assumptions under which it is correct: You have two unbiased measurements with known and independent standard errors. This is a strong assumption in that we believe there is no chance that our knowledge of the sensor error is wrong either temporarily or permanently. This assumption is almost never true. If we saw one measurement like that and certainly if we saw more, we would adjust our estimate of sensor accuracy (or bias if consistently misaligned). The most probable location may not change but our certainty should.

I think how one handles this in practice would make for an interesting office hours discussion. I suspect it's rare though since as mentioned last week, he has a bias for inflating variance compared to theoretical estimates, which is likely, in part, to avoid such problems.

I think you make a good point, Megan. The return keyword really does two things: it establishes the function's return value and it also serves as an "exit function" to send the flow back to wherever the function was called from.

When you are using multiple return statements in a function, you have to be careful that you really have covered all situations, that the function definitely returns something (other than None). If all of your return statements are buried inside of blocks, you might have a function that gets all the way to the end and never reaches a return statement. That's why it's good for the very last statement of the function to be itself a return statement (not inside of any block). That can serve as your default return.

(Of course if we only care about the side effects of a function, this does not apply.)

This depends on two things: Access to the control and the pattern of speed changes. If you have access to the control state, then you can just update with that. If the car's velocity changes constantly, adding acceleration per bnsh works. The challenge is if velocity just changes arbitrarily. In that case, a plain Kalman filter won't work because it will become increasingly confident about position, speed, and acceleration and won't adapt sufficiently to the speed changes. For an example of how to fix this see this question on oscillation.

body:
What will the deep_count return for this input?

The Kalman filter can used for localization. The histogram was introduced first, principally for pedagogical reasons.

However, the Kalman filter can only be used for a certain class of localization problems. Specifically those in which the movement function is linear and the uncertainties are normally distributed. The requirement for a normal error distribution precludes application in environments where there might be multiple peaks which can happen in practice in localization if you don't have a precise fix at the beginning or if the tracker gets lost for whatever reason. Therefore, I believe the car uses the particle filter in practice which like the histogram filter handles arbitrary distributions but is more efficient.

pHit and pMiss represent the relative probability of a square being a given color given that the measurement is a given color. Since we normally expect that the color measured is the color, the ratio of pHit to pMiss is a measure of the accuracy of the sensor known as the odds ratio. Since we normalize after multiplying, it doesn't matter what they total. To convince yourself multiply pHit and pMiss by a few arbitrary numbers of recalculate. Your updated state should be identical in each case.

You're exactly right: In the simple example the change in t is assumed to be one. However, Professor Thrun will mention your point later. Note that usually we use dt or delta t since t usually refers to absolute time.

While they are alternative methods for solving the same problem, they can also be used together. The self-driving car is an example. As Professor Thrun notes, it uses a Kalman filter to track other traffic. I believe that it uses a particle filter to localize itself. They could even be combined on the same task since a particle filter is vastly superior for dealing with multi-modal data but the Kalman filter is more efficient for updates with little noise. One approach would be to use a particle filter until the variance was below a certain level, switch to a Kalman filter and then switch back whenever the correspondence between measurements and prediction dropped below a certain threshold.

When you use = the list that your variable labels is changed. The first time you use =, a list is created. title: why is this marked incorrect? (median)
body:
def median(a, b, c):
    min_value = 0
    med_value = 0
    max_value = 0
    if(a>=b & a>=c):
        max_value = a
        if(b>=c):
            min_value=c
            med_value=b
        else:
            min_value=b
            med_value=c
    elif (b>=a & b>=c):
        max_value = b
        if(a>=c):
            med_value = a
            min_value = c
        else:
            med_value = c
            min_value = a
    else:
        max_value = c
        if(a>=b):
            med_value = a
            min_value = b
        else:
            med_value = b
            min_value = a
    return med_value

@Raman: For the N^2 in the formula in point 1 I am actually referring to unit 24-19. I am following the procedure that Sebastian was demonstrating - first get the actual variance of the individual scores, then the variance of the means (which he says is equal to sigma^2 / N^2), then the standard deviation of the means (which then gets equal to sigma / N) and then we multiply this standard deviation with 1,96 (the z-value). Therefore, the formula for the confidence intervals actually becomes:

CI = mu +- z * sigma / N : which is the same as: mu +- z * square root of (sigma^2 / N^2)

This is also different from what I know for confidence intervals, but maybe the difference is that in the case above we know the true population mean and variance, and we are looking for a confidence interval for the sample means, and NOT the other way around. That is what I am trying to find out, why do we have N^2 and not N in this formula. Is it my confusion or is it something else?

Well there's two approaches if you don't use post_id in the form:

  1. If you want to overwrite the existing page, make sure you can uniquely retrieve the old wiki page from the datastore. I did this by storing the URL as part of the WikiPage object. Then retrieve it, e.g. via wiki = db.GqlQuery('SELECT * FROM WikiPage WHERE url=:1 LIMIT 1', link_.get()), update it, .put() it back.

  2. If you are wanting to also implement the history (i.e. the second question), you need to do something else. You either need to store a diff (as in, the difference between the versions) or, much more easily, store the new page as a separate entity (URL is not unique). Then if you have to retrieve the latest WikiPage, just update the previous query to something like: wiki = db.GqlQuery('SELECT * FROM WikiPage WHERE url=:1 ORDER BY created DESC LIMIT 1', link_.get()).

It does seem that the expected level of the course based on prerequisites and course numbering is not consistent with the difficulty of the actual lessons and assignments. That said, the core concepts can be explained without all those prerequisites by avoiding some complications. That's enabled far more people to learn something about robotics than would have been the case by truly assuming knowledge of the prerequisites.

Whether it's better to move some people from very little knowledge to some knowledge or fewer people from significant knowledge to even more knowledge is debatable based on both specific parameters and the future actions the participants take. The real solution is to build courses at a variety of levels or better yet make them adaptive to the level of the student. title: can I learn more than one programming language at the same time?
body:
My question is a general question not related to search engine, but the programming language
Is it possible to learn more than one programming language at the same time?
What are the damages or benefits?

Twiddle is supervised learning. The distinction between supervised and unsupervised learning is whether one can calculate an error metric.

It's a bit like gradient descent except that it can only move in the direction of a basis vector and it estimates the distance based on the number of successful steps in a given direction, less the number of previously unsuccessful steps rather than the actual slope. What it's most similar to is a human manually changing parameters which is how it earned its name.

As noted in office hours, other optimization techniques are likely better but may be more work. It's best to think of twiddle as the least you should do to tune your parameters. If they still don't look right or you have doubts, use something more sophisticated. The easiest single modification would just be to run twiddle with multiple randomly selected starting points and to add randomness to the movement much like in a particle filter.

The data list has N-1 entries each representing a movement and measurement. data[i][0] is a list of measurements for however many landmarks were sensed. Each element in it is of the form [landmark_number,x distance,y distance]. data[i][1] contains the movement in the form [x movement, y movement].

You're correct that mu has x and y interlaced for the positions and then the measurements. So it should be [Px1,Py1,Px2,Py2,...,Lx1,Ly1,...]

Why does a grade need to be a scaler? A Udacity grade could be a vector of [understanding, learning speed, tenacity, programming accuracy, coding efficiency, machine efficiency,..]. Presumably most of those would be aggregated across classes while knowledge would be subject specific and aptitude might be subject area specific.

Ultimately, grades only matter to the extent they're used. Since one of your biggest advantages in matching students with companies (or advertisers or...) is the richness of the data, the grade should be either the set of scores you will use to distinguish students, the input variables available for those scores, or a reasonably sized set of aggregates that approximates the different scores in use.

Actually, I think if you changed the swapped j and n it'll be cleaner? This manner:

def fibonacci(n):
a = 0
b = 1
i = 1
j = 1
while i!=n:
    j = b+a
    a = b
    b = j
    i += 1
return j

My opinion is that since n is the input, you shouldn't really pass it into the variable j and pass new values into n with each iteration of the loop.
And maybe you would like to add a if statement right at the start to return 0 or None if n is < 1, this will prevent the code from hanging when given an inappropriate input.

The overarching question is how localization changes in the tightly localized case. The particle filter appears to be massively less efficient than the Kalman filter as one would expect for a more general method. A Kalman filter in two dimensions requires only 4 state variables and approximately 1000 operations. A particle filter optimistically requires an order of magnitude more. You're right that the decision process introduces some overhead if variance isn't explicitly computed but it likely is and it could be be done every k cycles if required.

You're right that the Kalman filter doesn't fix the diversity problem but neither does the particle filter once it's been localized. If one needs to keep checking to decide whether to introduce additional variance, why not use a more computationally efficient alternative as long as those checks don't reveal the need for the more general method.

I agree that in some applications spontaneous emergence of multimodal distributions is common. It's not clear that that's true in this case.

Yes. Consider self.Gaussian() as P() for a Gaussian. So you're computing the product of P(Measurement|Location_i) for all locations. Since the probability of a particle being in a region is the current belief of P(Location), the probability of sampling a particle is equivalent to P(Location) multiplied by the product of the measurement probabilities.

Maybe, this solution fulfills you request. The extension is made by selecting different separators, depending if the value numeric value is not 1. 

def convert_seconds(seconds):
    timenames = [" hour"," minute"," second"]
    separators = [[", ",", ",""],["s, ","s, ","s"]]

    h, r = divmod(seconds, 3600)
    m, s = divmod(r, 60)
    x = [int(h), int(m), s]

    t = ""
    for i in range(0,3):
        t = t + str(x[i]) + timenames[i] + separators[x[i]!=1][i]

    return t

def add_to_index(index, keyword, url):
    for entry in index:
        if entry[0] == keyword and url not in entry[1]:
            entry[1].append(url)
            return
    # not found, add new keyword to index
    index.append([keyword, [url]])

The problem is that the initial distribution is enormously skewed: The maximum is 80 times higher than the average. I suspect that most real robots start with better priors. If not, I don't see why you wouldn't do a binary search the first time, unless the cost is so low in practical terms that it's not worth the extra code.

Eliminating all particles with weight<<average would also work. In the first run the bottom 96.5% of particles account for only 2.75% of the cumulative probability so deleting them should have a negligible effect.

Browse through some Hidden Features of Python

The compiler optimization question really depends on details of code you write within the loop. (If you define an iteration counter but make no use of it, an optimizing compiler will implement the loop control in a different way.)

As for your own coding practice, with experience you will learn to choose loop structures that are tight and efficient for each specific task. If you need to execute a loop at most a specific number of times, use a counter and either count up or count down. In many languages this is called a for loop or a do loop, whereas Python apparently uses a while loop. The "while" construct can also be used to test a logical stopping criterion. (I've used a language that also offers an "until" construct for this. Until loops are sometimes guaranteed to execute at least once, but not in this language.) The Python "for" control is used for stepping through a list and assigning a name to each element in turn, which is probably different from the for loops you are used to.

Here's mine, graded correct. Compare with yours?



def crawl_web(seed,max_pages):

    tocrawl = [seed]

    crawled = []

    while tocrawl and len(crawled) < max_pages:

        page = tocrawl.pop()

        if page not in crawled:

            union(tocrawl, get_all_links(get_page(page)))

            crawled.append(page)

    return crawled

If we paramaterize a 2D world with x and y, consider a case in which the controller only knows the amount of force applied in the direction of motion. To the extent that the angle of motion, arctan(dy/dx), is uncertain the off diagonals could have large non-zero values. Note that this also holds if we know the angle for the controller but it's uncertain.

If the car could be accelerating, acceleration could be modeled as well. The filter would then learn that the car is accelerating when it accelerates. The difficulty is that after a long time period of not accelerating, the filter would place too high a probability on acceleration being 0. This is a problem of non-normality. Ideally, we would express the higher likelihood of extreme values. One way to do that is with the thick-tailed gaussian that is shown in the homework.

def involved(courses, person):

        for c in courses[h]:

                    clist.append(c)

Many languages such as C and Java separate pointers from ordinary variables. Note that in Python, simple objects such as numbers and characters are an exception in a sense in that the underlying object is a constant rather than a thing that can hold one. So i=5;k=i;i=6; leaves k at 5 since k points directly to an object that is 5 which cannot change.

Depending on how one interprets variables, this might not be right. Since the question is the memory complexity of localization, if the localization algorithm has a higher memory complexity than the state itself, it would dominate. For example, taking the cartesian product in a naive way of lists of size n and m, has a memory complexity of n*m while the representation has a complexity of n+m. That said, in any particular instance the complexity of the two might be equivalent.

Let's walk through a discrete example. For a discrete function, convolution of p and m and point n is sum(p((n-x))m(x)). For a movement of U, m(x)_U={U-1:0.1,U:0.8,U+1:0.1}. So for a movement of 2 we have m(x)_2={1:0.1,2:0.8,3:0.1}. So the convolution at point 3 is m(0)p(3)+m(1)p(2)+m(2)p(1)+m(3)p(0). Substituting in m we have, 0.1p(2)+0.8p(1)+0.1p(0). Note that since p is circular, we can require an additional summation for p+k(len(p)) for all k. This isn't relavent in this case since the movement function is 0 for all such values.

title: Homework 1.3: assumptions about option 4 (multiple assignments)

I'm not sure I agree with that:

a,x = x,a
a,x = x,a

being equal to not changing the value of x. In all other cases, a was declared in the chunk of code given, so you didn't need to presuppose anything about it's assignment. But in this case, if a is not assigned before the execution of this code, the first line of code should produce an error (because a is not assigned and we need to assign its value to x). The fact that this code may fail in a case where the code "x=x" wouldn't makes me think this option should be out.

From The Hard Way is Easier, by Zed Shaw, Author of Learn Python The Hard Way, and other Learn Programming Books

Reading and Writing

It seems stupidly obvious, but, if you have a problem typing, you will have a problem learning to code. Especially if you have a problem typing the fairly odd characters in source code. Without this simple skill you will be unable to learn even the most basic things about how software works.

Typing the code samples and getting them to run will help you learn the names of the symbols, get familiar with typing them, and get you reading the language.

And, this

Do Not Copy-Paste

You must type each of these exercises in, manually. If you copy and paste, you might as well just not even do them. The point of these exercises is to train your hands, your brain, and your mind in how to read, write, and see code. If you copy-paste, you are cheating yourself out of the effectiveness of the lessons.

Here is my solution, it seems clearer for me than the one provided in the Video.

I just transfer all the tocrawl from the curent level(depth) in the crawled ones.

The tocrawl empties but meantime i store in another list(aux) all the links the next level have and then i point tocrawl to it...and so on, level by level.

Is my logic Ok ? and sorry for my English.

def crawl_web(seed,max_depth):
tocrawl = [seed]
crawled = []
#A vriable to keep track of the depth
lvl = 0
while lvl <= max_depth:
    #another list to keep track of all the links that this level "point to"
    aux = []
    while tocrawl:
        page = tocrawl.pop()
        if page not in crawled:
            crawled.append(page)
        union(aux,get_all_links(get_page(page)))
    lvl = lvl + 1
    #make tocrawl point to aux, which have all the links of this level
    tocrawl = aux
return crawled

@Emil, thanks for taking a look. Here are the three biggest differences between my code and the original: (1) He sets off two general sections of the code with comment lines, the stats functions and data structures, and the predict functions and data structures. These fit very nicely into classes, so I just made them classes. (2) The C code relies on a lot of side-effects in his functions. I tried to remove side effects whenever I saw them, as I think they make code harder to understand and debug. You see this change most evident in in the do_history (I renamed match_history, sorry) and scan_predict functions. (3) Finally, I noticed the original do_history had repetitive copy-pasted code; I tried to follow DRY principle, and called the function three times instead.

        xi.value[ind+offset+2][0] += motion[1] * (1./motion_noise)

    # measurement
    for i in range(len(measurement)) :
        ii = (measurement[i][0]+N)*2

        # x then y
        for offset in range(2) :
            omega.value[ind+offset][ind+offset] += 1./measurement_noise
            omega.value[ii+offset][ii+offset] += 1./measurement_noise
            omega.value[ind+offset][ii+offset] += -1./measurement_noise
            omega.value[ii+offset][ind+offset] += -1./measurement_noise

            xi.value[ind+offset][0] += -measurement[i][offset] * (1./measurement_noise)
            xi.value[ii+offset][0] += measurement[i][offset] * (1./measurement_noise)

mu = omega.inverse() * xi

Yes I see now. This is the working code so far with heapq, so as to not code the whole heap and not double add with the index:

import csv
import time
import heapq

def make_link(G, node1, node2):
    if node1 not in G:
        G[node1] = {}
    if node2 not in G[node1]:
        G[node1][node2] = 1
    else:
        G[node1][node2] += 1
    if node2 not in G:
        G[node2] = {}
    if node1 not in G[node2]:
        G[node2][node1] = 1
    else:
        G[node2][node1] += 1
    return G

def read_graph(filename):
    # Read an undirected graph in CSV format. Each line is an edge
    tsv = csv.reader(open(filename), delimiter='\t')
    G = {}
    characters = {}
    index = 0
    # graph characters-comics books
    for (node1, node2) in tsv: 
        if node1 not in characters:
             characters[char] = index
             index += 1
        make_link(G, node1, node2)
    return G, characters

marvelG, characters = read_graph('uniq_edges.tsv')
# graph characters-characters

#Let's make a character-to-character graph
#Note that if an edge is added multiple times, the strength increases
def val(node):
    return node[0]

time1 = time.time()
charG = {}
for char1 in characters:
    for book in marvelG[char1]:
        for char2 in marvelG[book]:        
                 make_link(charG, char1, char2)
time2 = time.time()
print "time to compute strenghts", time2 - time1

heap=[]
k = 10
for char1 in characters:
    for char2 in charG[char1]:
        #avoid duplicates by only including pairs where the character
        #number of the first is less than that of the second
        if characters[char1] < characters[char2]:
            if len(heap) < k:
                heapq.heappush(heap,(charG[char1][char2]/2, (char1, char2)))
            elif charG[char1][char2] > val(heap[0]):
                heapq.heappushpop(heap,(charG[char1][char2]/2, (char1, char2)))
print [heapq.heappop(heap) for _ in range(k)]

We have seen a lot of questions about homework 1.4. While we don't have time to check everyone's code, it seems like the majority of problems fall into one of a few cases.

  1. Students deleted or modified the code above the comment section. This section was necessary for grading purposes. Admittedly this is not the most robust system and we will try our best to make future homework more clear about what you can modify.
  2. Students redefined the show() function. While this wasn't explicitly forbidden, this had the same affect on the grading as modifying the show command. The reason you couldn't do this is because we actually redefine the show command in our grading script. This was an effort to prevent us from grading you wrong if your solution included print statements for debugging.
  3. Students did not make their solution general enough. These solutions tended to only work for a world of 20 cells. We tested with a variety of worlds, so such a solution would not have been marked as correct.

We apologize for the confusion and the effect this had on some of your grades for the first hw. I hope everyone still enjoyed the homework, we put a lot of work into making it and we are as disappointed as you when it doesn't turn out perfectly.

I solved the problem after more than an hour and it was quite difficult. I came here and saw the solution by dexter and then watched the solution video but don't understand how that is a solution. Take the following case where:

x = 3.49

adding 0.5 to the number gives:

x = x + 0.5
print x

3.99

according to the video and the answers on this page if I understand correctly the next step is to strip away everything after the decimal point.

x = str(x)
x = x[:x.find('.')]
print x

3

as you can see this is incorrect. The answer should be 4. When you round a number you start from the last digit and work your through the entire string of digits.

So that's why I took so long to solve it, cos I actually solved it and the code will work for any number decimal or float:

working code

y = str(x)
point = y.find('.')  
plus = ''  # must declare this variable here because you cannot declare them inside loops.
if point != -1:  # if -1 then no there is no point so code will work if you put x = 32 for example, it'll just give back the same value
    while y[-2] != '.':  # must round off all the digits until only 1 digit is left after the decimal point.
        if int(y[-1]) >= 5:  # i.e. if last integer greater than or equal to 5.
            if int(y[-2]) == 9:  # This was tricky. If second to last digit is 9 then it must stay the same else things get screwed up.
                plus = int(y[-2])  # as you will see below plus is a variable which holds what the last digit should be.
            else:
                plus = int(y[-2])+1
            y = y[:-2]  # remove last two digits from y before concatenating plus to the end.
            y += str(plus)  # This is a shortcut to concatenation. It's the same as y = y + str(plus)
        else:  # at this point you just have to slowly navigate through the if else branches and work it out.
            y = y[:-1]
    if int(y[-1]) >= 5:
        x = int(y[:point]) + 1
    else:
        x = int(y[:point])
else:
    pass

print x

now try with 3.49

x = 3.49

run the code
4

Bam! :)

Wow. That's a good article, and helped clear my thinking. The last paragraph is an especially helpful summary (if you also scan back to see statement T).

@Brendan, you're close with your final statements, but not quite there. On the assumption that the population mean is 52, 95% of the confidence intervals constructed from random samples will contain the value 52. And that does provide information about the likely closeness of the sample mean and population mean, but only when considering an ensemble of samples that have each given the same estimate (52).

(EDIT: Have I even gotten that right? We compute a confidence interval centered on 52 because that is our observed sample mean. [We could, in theory, construct other confidence intervals, symmetric or non-symmetric, centered anywhere we like. Even discontinuous intervals.] How necessary is that sample mean in describing what the confidence interval means?)

Which nicely illustrates why frequentist definitions are often difficult to work with. (Whether they are true, in some logical sense, is a separate issue. I believe they are true -- but just as there can be non-Euclidean geometries, there can be other valid definitions of probability.)

@Rob, I don't know that I can satisfy your curiosity about the foundational issues, but I see it as all revolving around whether unknown quantities are necessarily fixed or can be assigned probability distributions. Given a single random sample (of size N) and a single population, a frequentist has little to say. The sample statistics are what they are, just as the population mean is what it is. The confidence interval either includes the population mean or it doesn't (we just don't know which).

To make statistical statements, the frequentist must generalize to an ensemble of such experiments. Thus we get Sober's discussion of the procedure's statistical properties. Carry out this procedure often enough and it will have the 95% property that we ascribe to the confidence intervals it produces. Carry out any frequentist procedures often enough and your test conclusions will be right 95% of the time. (Or whatever significance level you choose to use.)

Bayesians start from a different theoretical perspective, in which there is a prior probability distribution for the population parameter. It might be an impulse function (which reduces to the frequentist position) or a uniform distribution, or from the Dirichlet family, or anything else reasonable in the specific problem domain. That prior distribution propagates through the equations we use, but usually has decreasing effect as more data is gathered. And it allows us to make statements about the probability that the true, unknown parameter value falls within some range, the credible interval.

title: Historic figures mentioned in lectures
body:
I really like the idea of introducing some of the people in the history of the field of computer science, as well those used to make the quizzes more interesting. Below is a summary of the historic figures mentioned so far (mostly taken from Wikipedia and the History of Computing Project)

John Backus (1924-2007)

Lead designer of the programming language Fortran (Formula Translator) and developed the Backus-Naur Form notation. Awarded the Turing Award in 1977. His award lecture 'Can Programming Be Liberated from the von Neumann Style? A Functional Style and Its Algebra of Programs' can be found here. Referenced in Unit 1 - Grammer.

Lothar Collatz (1910-1990)

A German mathematician who proposed the Collatz conjecture (or 3x+1 problem) in 1937. At present the conjecture remains unsolved. One part of HomeWork 2.5 used this conjecture as the basis of a program for which it is not currently known if it will always halt for any given positive integer. The sequence of numbers generated by this formula is know as a hailstone sequence.

Georges Danton (1759-1794)

A prominent figure in the French Revolution. Gave us a great quote to work with in the example Unit 1 - Finding with Numbers "il nous faut de l'audace, et encore de l'audace, et toujours de l'audace" - "We need audacity, and yet more audacity, and always audacity!"

Grace Hopper (1906-1992)

Developed the first compiler for a programming language and influenced the design of COBOL (COmmon Business-Oriented Language). Referenced in Unit 1 - Grace Hopper and more details supplied in the CS101 Unit 1 Notes.

Augusta Ada King (1815-1852)

Wrote what is considered to be the first algorithm designed for execution on a computing machine (Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine) for calculating Bernoulli numbers, hence she is credited as the first programmer. The computer language Ada is named in her honor. Referenced in Unit 1 - Ada and more details supplied in CS101 Unit 1 Notes.

Richard Feynman (1918-1988)

Considered both a great physicist and teacher. Made fundamental contributions to quantum electrodynamics and theoretical physics. Well know for his pictorial representation of particle interactions known as Feynman diagrams. Won the Nobel prize in physics in 1965. Feynman gave, a now classic, talk on the prospects of what has grown into the field of nanotechnology. You can read his Nobel lecture here, and a transcript of his talk 'There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom' here. Referenced in Unit 3.20, his picture appears on the hypothetical nanodollar.

Alan Turing (1912-1954)

Established several important concepts in computer science and mathematical logic. His 1936 paper 'On Computable Numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem' introduced the concept of an abstract computing model which is now known as the Turing Machine. He also had important an influence on the fields of artificial intelligence ('Computing machinery and intelligence in Mind'), mathematical biology, and cryptanalysis. Mentioned at the end of Unit 2. There is also great summary in the Unit 2 Notes on page 12.

@Nagarjuna page contains 1 URL. When you do get_page(page), you get the content (source) or the page URL, that may contain HTML formatting, text and URLs. In the union(tocrawl,get_all_links(get_page(page))) line the first thing that is done is get_page(page), but instead of storing the returned value in a variable, the returned value is passed right into get_all_links() procedure. And after that, instead of storing the return value of the get_all_links(), the return value gets passed into the union function. If it makes it easier for you to understand, this line can be written as:

page_content =  get_page(page)
links_in_page = get_all_links(page_content)
union(tocrawl, links_in_page)

But since we don't really need the variables page_content and links_in_page, these 3 lines can be written in a shorter way.

What union does is - it adds the links_in_page to tocrawl and then looks at the combined list and removes all duplicate entries and keeps only unique entries. So, for example, if tocrawl = ['url1', 'url5'] and links_in_page = ['url2', 'url5'], then after union is called tocrawl will be ['url1', 'url5', 'url2'], and not ['url1', 'url5', 'url2', 'url5'] (because 'url5' is duplicate, the second entry is removed)

I think the first thing you want to know about it why computers use boolean logic instead of probability distribution, if most problems in robotics are solved using a probabilistic paradigm.

I would say that is because: 1) Many computational problems can be solved with traditional boolean logic; 2) Probabilistic approaches can be formulated using generic boolean logic computers with arithmetic computational units; 3) It is not trivial to build and formulate something like a "probabilistic digital circuit", as opposed to the classical AND, OR, NOT gates based on boolean logic. The only thing I can think of is the Bernoulli discrete distribution, and that could maybe be used in simple graphical models.

A good point you make is that perhaps it would make sense for there to be some kind of dedicated hardware for probabilistic calculations. I wouldn't go so far as to say the whole computer should be that way, but if something like that could be done it could be useful in making probabilistic algorithms more tractable.

title: Basic intro to recursion for those still battling with it
body:
Recursion is a nasty beast until you tame it, at which time it becomes your friend. If you have not been able to grab it by the horns and are still battling with the basics, these two exercises should help you and take you all the way to solve most simple recursive problems, including all of the homework.

Dave pointed out that everything that you can do with a loop, you can do with recursion. Then let's try it. First, let's work with this function that prints the numbers from 1 to n:

def print_numbers(n):
    i = 1
    while i <= n:
        print i
        i = i+1

ok.. now recursively. It you want to flex your muscles give it a try before looking at the explanation. It should not take you more than a few minutes.

first you need your base case. A condition for which you solve the problem inmediately is when n is 1. Hence we have:

def recursive_print_numbers(n):
    if n == 1:
        print n
        return
    else:
       <treat the other cases>

This was easy because you focused on only a single case.. what to do if n = 1.

Now the recursive case.. you want to make the problem smaller each time that you call your function recursively:

def recursive_print_numbers(n):
    if i == n:
        print n
        return
    else:
        recursive_print_numbers(n-1)
        print n
        return

So how do you come up with this? you do the same thing that you did for the base case: you focus on a single case. For the base case you focused on n=1. for the recursive case you focus on the n-th case: assume that your recursive call of "recursive_print_numbers(n-1)" magically prints all the numbers from 1 to n-1.. what is left? print n. Those are exactly the 2 statements in the recursive case: a) reduced the problem and b) what to do after the reduced problem has been solved. You are done.

Now taking into account the particular idiosincrasies of Python, your final code can do away with a number of lines:

def recursive_print_numbers(n):
    if 1 == n:
        print n
        return
    recursive_print_numbers(n-1)
    print n

If you are struggling with recursion, the Python version looks much more mysterious that the "generic" version. I would stick to adding returns and else statements until I fully understand what is going on.

Now for the next step.. the next level of complexity. We now want to add the numbers from 1 to n instead of simply printing them:

def sum_numbers(n):
    sum = 0
    i = 1
    while i <= n:
        sum = sum + i
        i = i + 1
    return sum

This is a bit more complex because now, somehow, we need to carry information among the recursive calls. So let's see.. what is your base case? n = 1:

def recursive_sum_numbers(n):
    if n == 1:
        return 1
    else:
        <recursive case>

Now what is your recursive case? Again, focus on what you need to do on the n-th case.. assume that your recursive call already added all the numbers from 1 to n-1 and is returning them to you. All that is left do to is to add n and return:

def recursive_sum_numbers(n):
    if n == 1:
        return 1
    else:
        sum = recursive_sum_numbers(n-1)
        return sum + n

Done. The information between recursive functions is passed in the return statement. We recursively reduce the problem until n = 1 and only then we set the sum to one. Then, as we return from the calls, each return contributes its own 'n' to sum.. i.e., the n-th return sets sum = 1, the (n-1) adds 2 to sum to make sum=3, the (n-2)th adds 3 to sum to make sum = 6, and so on, until the last return adds n and returns to the main caller.

If you fully understand these examples, you are now in a strong position to tackle the homework problems. Good luck.

@Milos, Udacity seems to gradually be evolving the ways in which they run classes. In previous sessions, we had semi-hard deadlines for homework. Back then the 'rules' were pretty easy:

  • Before the deadline, give hints/guidance.
  • After the deadline, share full solutions.

But now, with 'no deadlines', it's a lot harder to figure out what to do. I haven't seen any real guidance from Udacity on this, so it seems that it is really up to us to blunder our way through.

Personally, I really DON'T want this to become an ego battle where people race to see who can post their solution first. (So far this hasn't been an issue.) I'd rather see people wait at least four or five days from homework release before they post complete solutions. But it's hard to even suggest this when the homework release dates aren't consistent from week to week.

So all I think we can do for now is to be careful to put 'spoiler' in the tags when we publish solutions.

As a final comment, I enjoy reading the solutions that other folks come up with... especially the ones that have a unique take/approach to the problem.

In Python return statements are not strictly necessary. If you do not put one in (because your function doesn't have to return anything) there is an implicit return None at the end. A function that is purely for printing is a good example of a function that might not have a return statement.

While your algorithm you wrote works for exactly three numbers, what happens if you want to find the largest number from a different number of integers? What if you were asked to determine the largest number from a set of 1,000,000 numbers? Do you see the problem?
it means your program broke the virtual python interpreter.

The data in testdata1 contains 4 moves, which implies 5 poses. The first pose is added by the slam/online_slam routine itself:



Xi.value[0][0] = world_size / 2.0 # position the start point at the centre of the world

Xi.value[1][0] = world_size / 2.0

To those 5 poses add the 3 landmarks (note that the indices for landmarks in testdata1 are 0, 1, and 2).
This gives a total of 8 items to be tracked in the Omega matrix and the Xi vector.
