title: Run cs101 Web Crawler as an Application Rev 2.0
tagnames: cs101 compute_rank application contest webcrawler crawl_web
body:
Please use this code as a base for your contest submission. Don't re-invent the wheel. Hit the ground running instead.

UPDATED:

  • Added the ability to save, load, delete the index. [20 Mar 2012]
  • Added Trending Algorithm. [27 Mar 2012]
  • Implements lookup_best and compute_ranks
  • Created github repository found here: [14 Apr 2012]
  • Feel free to improve the code and/or create your own fork.
  • Changed all .format() calls to use {0} syntax instead of {}. [16 Apr 2012]

To run the code the professor has taught us on your own computer follow these steps:

  1. Install Python on your computer: http://www.python.org/download/
  2. Copy and Paste the code below into a text file and save as webcrawler.py in the same folder you installed Python. For example, the default location is c:\Python27. (alternately get the latest code revision from the github repository).
  3. Open a DOS cmd prompt window and navigate to c:\Python27. Type python webcrawler.py and press enter.
*********************************************************************************
***********************  CODE STARTS HERE    ************************************ 
*********************************************************************************

import urllib
import socket
socket.setdefaulttimeout(10)
# in a true webcrawler you should not use re instead use a DOM parser
import re
# for sorting a nested list
from operator import itemgetter

def get_page(url):
        try:
            f = urllib.urlopen(url)
            page = f.read()
            f.close()
            return page
        except:
            return ""
        return ""
def get_next_target(page):
        start_link = page.find('<a href=')
        if start_link == -1:
            return None, 0
        start_quote = page.find('"', start_link)
        end_quote = page.find('"', start_quote + 1)
        url = page[start_quote + 1:end_quote]
        return url, end_quote
def union(p,q):
        cnt = 0
        for e in q:
            if e not in p:
                p.append(e)
                cnt += 1
        return cnt
def get_all_links(page):
        links = []
        while True:
            url,endpos = get_next_target(page)
            if url:
                links.append(url)
                page = page[endpos:]
            else:
                break
        return links
def add_to_index(index,keyword,url):
        if keyword in index:
            if url not in index[keyword]:
                index[keyword].append(url)
        else:
            index[keyword] = [url]
def split_string(source,splitlist):
    return ''.join([ w if w not in splitlist else ' ' for w in source]).split()
def add_page_to_index_re(index,url,content):
        i = 0
        # it is not a good idea to use regular expression to parse html
        # i did this just to give a quick and dirty result
        # to parse html pages in practice you should use a DOM parser
        regex = re.compile('(?<!script)[>](?![\s\#\'-<]).+?[<]')

        for words in regex.findall(content):
            word_list = split_string(words, """ ,"!-.()<>[]{};:?!-=`&""")
            for word in word_list:
                add_to_index(index,word,url)
                i += 1
        return i
def format_url(root,page):
        if page[0] == '/':
            return root + page
        return page
def crawl_web(seed,max_pages=10,max_depth=1):
        root = seed
        tocrawl = [seed]
        depth = [0]
        crawled = []
        index = {}
        graph = {}
        while tocrawl and len(crawled) < max_pages:
            page = tocrawl.pop()
            d = depth.pop()
            if page not in crawled:
                page = format_url(root,page)
                content = get_page(page)
                success = add_page_to_index_re(index,page,content)
                outlinks = get_all_links(content)
                graph[page] = outlinks
                if d != max_depth:
                    cnt = union(tocrawl,outlinks)
                    for i in range(cnt):
                        depth.append(d+1)
                crawled.append(page)
        return index, graph
def lookup(index, keyword):
        if keyword in index:
            return index[keyword]
        return None
def sort_by_score(l):
        get_score = itemgetter(0)
        map(get_score,l)
        l = sorted(l,key=get_score)
        l.reverse()
        return l
def lookup_best(index, keyword, ranks):
        result = []
        if keyword in index:
            for url in index[keyword]:
                if url in ranks:
                    result.append([ranks[url], url])
        if len(result) > 0:
            result = sort_by_score(result)
        return result
def get_inlinks(page,graph):
        il = {}
        for p in graph:
            for ol in graph[p]:
                if ol == page:
                    il[p] = graph[p]
        return il
def compute_ranks(graph):
        d = 0.8 # damping factor
        numloops = 10
        ranks = {}
        npages = len(graph)
        for page in graph:
            ranks[page] = 1.0 / npages
        for i in range(0, numloops):
            newranks = {}
            for page in graph:
                newrank = (1 - d) / npages
                inlinks = get_inlinks(page,graph)
                for il in inlinks:
                    newrank += ((0.8 * ranks[il])/len(inlinks[il]))
                newranks[page] = newrank
            ranks = newranks
        return ranks
# code below only runs when this file is run as a script
# if you imported this code into your own module the code
# below would not be accessible by your code
if __name__ == "__main__":
        import os
        import pickle
        GLOBAL_NUM_SEARCHES = 8
        GLOBAL_TRENDING_INTERVAL = 4
        def calculate_trending(trending,now,before,interval,threshhold=0.5):
            for s in now:
                if s in before:
                    slope = float(now[s] - before[s])/interval
                    # set trending
                    if slope > threshhold:
                        trending[s] = 1
                    # clear trending
                    if slope < 0:
                        if s in trending:
                            trending.pop(s)
            return trending
        def trending(searches,interval):
            curr_searches = {}
            prev_searches = {}
            is_trending = {}
            i = 0
            while(searches):
                search = searches.pop()
                if search in curr_searches:
                    curr_searches[search] = curr_searches[search] + 1
                else:
                    curr_searches[search] = 1
                i += 1
                if i == interval:
                    is_trending = calculate_trending(is_trending,curr_searches,prev_searches,interval)
                    i = 0
                    prev_searches = curr_searches.copy()
                    curr_searches.clear()
            return is_trending
        def print_cmds():
                return "    Welcome to the CS101 Web Crawler\n" + \
                       "    What do you want to do?\n" + \
                       "    Enter 1 - To start crawling a web page\n" + \
                       "    Enter 2 - Print the Index\n" + \
                       "    Enter 3 - Find a word in the Index\n" + \
                       "    Enter 4 - Save Index\n" + \
                       "    Enter 5 - Load Index\n" + \
                       "    Enter 6 - Delete Index\n" + \
                       "    Enter q - Quit\n" + \
                       "    crawler:"
        def execute_start_crawl(index):
                maxdepth = int(raw_input("    Enter Max Depth:"))
                maxpages = int(raw_input("    Enter Max Pages:"))
                url = raw_input("    Enter Web Url:")
                return crawl_web(url,maxpages,maxdepth)
        def delete_file(path):
            ret = ""
            if os.path.exists(path):
                try:
                    size2 = os.path.getsize(path)
                    os.remove(path)
                    ret += "        Deleted {0} ({1} bytes)\n".format(path,size2)
                except:
                    ret += "        Failed to delete {0}\n".format(path)
                print ret
        def clear_data(data,data_str,path):
            ret = ''
            delete_file(path)
            length = len(data)
            data.clear()
            ret += "        Cleared {0} entries from {1}\n".format(length,data_str)
            print ret
            return data
        def open_file(data,data_str,path):
            ret = ""
            file = open(path,"wb")
            if file:
                fail = 0
                try:
                    pickle.dump(data,file)
                except:
                    fail += 1
                    ret += "        Failed to save {0} to {1}\n".format(data_str,path)
                try:
                    size = os.path.getsize(path)
                except:
                    size = 0
                    fail += 1
                    ret += "        Failed to get the size of {0}\n".format(path)
                if fail == 0:
                    ret += "        {0} was saved to {1} ({2} bytes)\n".format(data_str,path,size)
                    ret += "        {0} contains {1} entries.\n".format(data_str,len(data))
                file.close()
            else:
                ret += "        Failed to open {0} at {1}\n".format(data_str,path)
            print ret
        def load_file(data,data_str,path):
            ret = ""
            if os.path.exists(path):
                file1 = open(path,'rb')
                if file1:
                    try:
                        data = pickle.load(file1)
                        size1 = os.path.getsize(path)
                        ret += "        Loaded {0} from {1} ({2} bytes)\n".format(data_str,path,size1)
                        ret += "        {0} contains {1} entries.\n".format(data_str,len(data))
                    except:
                        size1 = 0
                        ret += "        Failed to load {0} from {1}\n".format(data_str,path)
                else:
                    ret += "        Failed to open {0}\n".format(path)
            else:
                ret += "        {0} does not exist\n".format(path)
            print ret
            return data
        def execute_cmd(c,index,graph, ranks, searches):
                if c == '1':
                    index, graph = execute_start_crawl(index)
                    ranks = compute_ranks(graph)
                    print "    Crawl finished.  Index has {0} items.".format(len(index))
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                elif c == '2':
                    maxentries = raw_input("    Enter Number of Index Entries to Display (Type a for all):")
                    if maxentries == 'a' or maxentries == 'A':
                        maxentries = 0xFFFFFFFF
                    else:
                        maxentries = int(maxentries)
                    for i, e in enumerate(index):
                        if i >= maxentries:
                            break
                        print "        Entry {0}:".format(i)
                        print "            '{0}' appears in the following urls:".format(e)
                        for u in index[e]:
                            print "                {0}".format(u)
                    if len(index) == 0:
                        print "        Index is empty"
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                elif c == '4':
                    open_file(index,"Index",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'index.pkl')
                    open_file(graph,"Graph",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'graph.pkl')
                    open_file(ranks,"Ranks",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'ranks.pkl')
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                elif c == '5':
                    index = load_file(index,"Index",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'index.pkl')
                    graph = load_file(graph,"Graph",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'graph.pkl')
                    ranks = load_file(ranks,"Ranks",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'ranks.pkl')
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                elif c == '6':
                    index = clear_data(index,"Index",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'index.pkl')
                    graph = clear_data(graph,"Graph",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'graph.pkl')
                    ranks = clear_data(ranks,"Ranks",os.getcwd() + os.path.sep + 'ranks.pkl')
                    searches = []
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                else:
                    w = raw_input("    Enter a word to find from the index:")
                    ret = ""
                    if len(ranks) == 0:
                        ranks = compute_ranks(graph)
                    l = lookup_best(index, w, ranks)
                    if len(l) == 0:
                        ret = "        {0} was not found in index".format(w)
                    else:
                        ret += "        '{0}' appears in the following urls:\n".format(w)
                        for e in l:
                            ret += "            {0}\n            score = {1}\n".format(e[1],e[0])
                    searches.append(w)
                    is_trending = {}
                    if len(searches) == GLOBAL_NUM_SEARCHES:
                        searches.reverse()
                        is_trending = trending(searches,GLOBAL_TRENDING_INTERVAL)
                        searches = []
                    if len(is_trending) > 0:
                        ret += "        The following are trending:\n"
                        for word in is_trending:
                            ret += "            '{0}'\n".format(word)
                    print ret
                    raw_input("    Press Enter")
                    print ""
                return index, graph, ranks, searches
        def main():
                index = {}
                graph = {}
                ranks = {}
                searches = []
                while(True):
                    c = raw_input(print_cmds())
                    if c == 'q' or c == 'Q':
                        break
                    index, graph, ranks, searches = execute_cmd(c,index, graph, ranks, searches)
        main()

Python 2.7 divides 2 integers and even if the quotient is a floating point/decimal number, it returns an integer as the quotient. (ie, it truncates the digits after the the decimal point).

So, 10/4 doesn't give 2.5, which is what you would expect. Instead, you get 2 as the quotient, the .5 is truncated.

If you want to get the right answer, ie, a floating point number (2.5), you need to add a decimal point to either the divisor or the dividend.

So, if you use 10.0/4 or 10/4.0 or just 10./4 or 10/4. , you will get 2.5.

The last option in this question is 10/50. That should give 0.2, but instead gives just 0 (the digis after the decimal point are truncated again). Again, if you use 10./50, you'll get the right answer.

Hallo Anthony,

Hmm, I don't quite understand all that is going on from your code :S (I can see what each part is doing, but I can't tell if it will give the correct results).

Here is my solution:

def rabbits(n):
    rabbitsA = [0,1,1]
    month = 3
    while month <= n:
        if month > 5:
            newRabbits = (rabbitsA[month-1] + rabbitsA[month-2] - rabbitsA[month-5])
        else:
            newRabbits = (rabbitsA[month-1] + rabbitsA[month-2])
        rabbitsA.append(newRabbits) 
        month = month + 1
    return rabbitsA[n]

Hope this helps..

Cheers,
Paul

Hi @Kris King, I agree with you in the inclusion of the random tester in the regression suite, for me also finding more bugs is more important than a constant regression suite.

Once the software/hardware under test is somewhat mature, my experience is that the primary regression is the random tester, supplemented by something else (could be a fixed regression suite) that acts as a 'sanity' check, in case your random tester has gone off into the bit bucket for some reason.

title: Where and when do you get the time to do the work?

For me: At home, 8:00pm - 10:00pm, after I have done dishes, put our 2 year old to bed

a few times just to see what's going on. The bulk of the homework will be done

Please don't be discouraged by the issues with homework grading --- the important thing is what you are learning.

Because of the way the automatic grading is done, it is quite possible that you got everything we wanted about the question, but didn't pass the grading scripts because of a little misunderstanding with the directions. We are working on ways to make grading more resilient to these types of things, but unfortunately don't have that in place yet. As fnenu said, this should also get better in future homeworks since now that you know how to define a procedure, it is easier to specify more clearly what you need to do for the answer to be correct.

I should also note that its perfectly fine to take the class without worrying about your grade at all. For some students, grades are a useful motivator and they are working towards having a transcript that includes grades for prospective employers, but it is also perfectly fine to take the classes without paying any attention to grades and we don't share your grades with anyone unless you ask us to. We don't kick anyone out of our courses, even if you don't do the homeworks or answer questions correctly.

def mode_chris(L):
    counts = defaultdict(int)
    for i in L:

First, my disclaimer: I think that all the people you name have been positive forces on the board. And I think that we are lucky to have you.

But, I think that the board can tend to be dominated by a couple of voices. This is hard to judge, because I personally tend to like those voices. But it kind of gives the impression that in order to understand the material well enough to answer questions you have to have already known it.

As for how Udacity should take this kind of board dynamics into account, I think they should continue with a fairly hands-off policy.

One of my concerns with the dominance of a couple of voices on this discussion board is that it leads people to trust authority over argument. In other words, I think that if a relatively unknown person posts an answer, that answer will be less likely to be believed and/or accepted until @Ken Laws or @Sergei (or a couple others) pop by to rule on it.

It's a great time and stress saver for people to have recognizable names on the forum who they can trust will give accurate answers. But when there's so few of them (relative to overall enrollment in the class) and most of them started out with the knowledge that the rest of us are here to pick up, the dynamic makes me a little uneasy. Basically it is because strings use a, if I'm not wrong with the name, lexicographical order. The position in the string matters.

"40" <= "5" is true because the first character in string "40" is lower than the first character in string "5", so no matter how many characters follows ("4000" <= "5" or "4000000000" <= "5").

This is the same ordering that uses any file browser when you sort by name and you prefix any file or folder with a 0 or a _ to get them show first (on top).

title: What happen with the subtitles?
body: Why the subtitles of the unit1 and unit2 are unavailable, one week ago this are available why not now?

I'm not sure we're being asked to solve the entire real world problem. They say we are making a search engine, but it's a toy one.

After all, we were given two inadequate pieces of code to being with. To name a few:

We were given the split problem in add_page_to_index as a starting point, so quotes and other punctuation are left in our index, masking words we would normally want to find.

The lookup function does a case-sensitive match.

get_next_target - html anchors don't necessarily start with <a href... The attributes can appear anywhere in the tag

Moreover, the problem posed asks for consecutive whole words in the order of search, which is not what you want in a real search engine.

It seems unlikely that the pass requirement is to solve not only the central multi-word search problem, but all the problems in the existing code that make it a toy rather than a real search engine.

My impression is we're being asked simply to deal with tracking work position and lookups that identify strings of consecutive words. That's all.

I'm suggesting that the communication from Udacity should be as good as it can be.

People will still miss information. There are language problems, apart from anything else.

At the moment, though, it's a bit haphazard.

If you have identified two possible functions for an exam to fulfil, you can choose either, or try to do both.

Students want feedback that they understand the course material adequately, and you have provided that. A 100% or near result on that level of exam fulfils that requirement.

Students also want to be ranked and to see their ranking. Additional challenge questions with additional marks would do that.

An ongoing ranking would satisfy some needs. The trick would be to do it without discouraging anyone. Some accumulating score based on all the material, including unit questions, and homework, might do that. Make it more like a game, except nobody loses health and dies.

Just as with the exams, you can have two scores - one for completing correctly with as many attempts as needed, and one for completing weighted on attempts and other criteria, such as code efficiency. Of course there can be many independent scores. There's already a ranking for forum participation.

There are some very competitive people doing these courses, and you don't want to drive them away any more than you want to drive away the sweet, easy-going, non-assertive types like me.

Thanks, Prof. Thrun. These are truly great principles in education.

There were some great challenges in the final exam. You could pass with inefficient algorithms, and then challenge yourself to improve the efficiency.

Even designing a comprehensive test set for your code can be a great challenge.

Here's my code. I checked if each number was less than or equal to n and then checked if it was listed twice in a row/column. I supposedly got it 'incorrect' but I couldn't find a test case that would break it. Additionally, this will automatically reject non-square inputs as either a number must be repeated or greater than n in a non-square input.

def check_sudoku(sod):
    #check verticals.
    for c in range(0, len(sod)):
        test_hold = []
        for r in range(0, len(sod)):
            test = sod[int(r)][int(c)]
            if test > len(sod):
                return False
            if test in test_hold:
                return False
            test_hold.append(test)

    #check horizontals.
    for r in range(0, len(sod)):
        test_hold = []
        for c in range(0, len(sod[r])):
            test = sod[r].pop()
            if test > len(sod):
                return False
            if test in test_hold:
                return False
            test_hold.append(test)
    else:
        return True

I definitely liked the immediate grading of the exam questions. It de-stresses the whole process. The challenge is to create exam questions for which this doesn't allow you to guess the answer.

Udacity almost succeeded in meeting this challenge this time.

  • Obviously multiple choice questions are out.
  • Questions with a small and finite number of checkbox combinations are out, and there were one or two of these.
  • Questions with a numeric answer to a reasonable degree of precision are good.
  • Programming questions, for which you can try test cases, but which are graded with different test cases, are perfect.
Well done the engineering team.

My experiments with the autograder (version as at the date of this posting) indicate:

  • functions external to the required function are acceptable
  • default valued additional function arguments are acceptable
  • helper functions are acceptable
  • debugging output is acceptable

Answer to Unit 1 Final Explained

I posted it a few moments ago

empty string isn't a valid input, I believe this one is safe to assume that code always is an existing, non-bugged procedure.

In the other assignments where there were boundary cases w/empty strings, it was perfectly valid for a list or dictionary to have '' as an entry and so you'd need to handle those.

In the case of functions/procedures, you'd solve this via exception handling and we've not covered that yet.

Here you go. My code checks that each row contains the numbers 1...n once. If a number is outside that range, it is not a valid sudoku code; likewise if a number appears more than once it is invalid. I use a list seen_number to maintain whether or not a number has appeared already. Each entry is True/False. Since the sudoku range of numbers is 1...n, to index the list we subtract one, so we check 0...n-1.

Note that checking the columns is equivalent to checking the rows of the transposed matrix. I use this fact to simplify the logic.

def check_sudoku(s):
    return check_rows(s) and check_rows(transpose(s))

def check_rows(matrix):
    n = len(matrix)

    for row in matrix:
        if len(row) != n:
            return False

        seen_number = [ False for number in range(n) ]

        for col in row:
            cols_index -= 1
            if not (0 <= cols_index < n):
                return False
            elif seen_number[cols_index] != False:
                return False
            seen_number[cols_index] = True

    return True

def transpose(matrix):
    transposed = []

    num_cols = len(matrix[0])
    num_rows = len(matrix)

    new_matrix = []
    for col in xrange(num_cols):
        new_row = []
        for row in xrange(num_rows):
            new_row.append(matrix[row][col])
        new_matrix.append(new_row)
    return new_matrix

I am not the most experienced programmer but I have found a few things that work for me. When learning programming for the first or when learning a new language, I program a line at a time. I check to make sure things are as I expect by setting break points or using print messages. Tedious at first but saves debug time. Once I get more comfortable, then I start writing entire functions (albeit I never write a function that has more than 4 or 5 lines of code). Then I do the same as before, I test it out before moving on. The more you practice the quicker all of this goes. In the beginning it will feel really slow.

As far as coming up with solutions/algorithms I can't give you much advice on that. I tend to see what others have already done to solve a problem. If I understand how they did it, then I try to duplicate what they did, not copying their code but putting their code into my own style.

Over time you will develop your own style and learn best practices from other people's code.

I know what the problem was. This is definitely a bug in the grading system.

If you Submit a programming assignment, it is marked as submitted.

Then if you click Run again, the code is marked as not submitted. The grading system does not keep the last one you submitted as your final answer, as obviously it should. It isn't documented anywhere that it doesn't, so how would you know?

This has wiped out two of my correct answers. I only just noticed the problem with the last question of the final. I ran it as a final check that it worked as I expected, then I happened to notice that it was no longer shown as submitted in the Progress.

Please reinstate the grades I should have received for the two answers I that were incorrectly marked as not submitted.

It's very hard to see how Udacity could provide a recognised qualification using only online submission and automated grading. It's impossible to prevent cheating.

If you don't use online submission and automated grading, and you have to qualify and pay graders and examiners, then the cost of the service increases spectacularly.

So there's a conflict between keeping the price low and providing a recognised qualification.

The price you pay for a university course depends on the recognition of the qualification.

However Udacity has a plan to short-circuit the whole process by feeding screened students directly into employment with Silicon Valley companies. This depends on finding companies that are prepared to look at alternatives to the traditional system of recognised qualifications.

If this works, and Udacity establishes a track record for placement, then they could conceivably charge a small price for the course. This would effectively be a payment for entering the competition for jobs.

Wouldn't too many timesteps be bad, because we would count relationships over and over again. It's a shame they didn't bother going in depth, by showing us examples of the algorithm and how it behaves.

I guess I should try to do that myself, but I figure my time is better spent working through more course material...

title: hw5.5 -  involved - correct  function

Extracting by value. If a person has two rolls (teacher and assistant) his course title will appear only once.

def involved(courses, person):

    my_work = {}
    for hexamester in courses:    
        my_courses = []
        for course in courses[hexamester]:
            for dict_element in courses[hexamester][course]:
                s = courses[hexamester][course]
                if dict_element in s:
                    p = s[dict_element]
                    if p == person:
                        if course not in my_courses:
                            my_courses.append(course)
                            if my_courses != []:
                                my_work[hexamester] = my_courses
    return my_work

It's interesting to see this kind of suspicion emerging.

My take on it is this:

Udacity has to have some kind of business model. As publicly stated many times, that model is to reduce the cost of providing education to such a low level that the students can be offered the courses for nothing.

The profit comes in gathering information about the students and the way they do the courses. This information is useful in the recruitment industry, and in many other applications. Apart from the socially valuable goal of providing free education, this information is the whole point. Naturally, if Udacity is sold, this information is the mother lode and it is sold too.

Providing this information is how you are paying for your education. It's a price no higher than the price you pay for Facebook or Gmail.

The intellectual property of Udacity is the technology with which it provides the education. The autograding mechanism, in particular, is central to its ability to compete in this emerging marketplace.

As we have all discovered, when it doesn't work the students don't like it and consider taking their custom elsewhere. If you solve the autograding problem well, you're on the way to providing reliable certification from an online university. This achievement would mark a turning point, almost a singularity, in global access to education.

We shouldn't be surprised that this turning point hasn't quite happened yet.

We shouldn't be surprised that Udacity keeps fairly quiet about the details of the autograding mechanism.

We shouldn't be surprised that Udacity is reserving information about enrolments, graduations, and other details for publication at Udacity's convenience.

In conclusion, now that someone has found a way to provide a free education, there is no need to search for deep, dark, secret conspiracies. It's a nice, obvious, open source conspiracy, free to all.

I echo your sentiments. I learned a lot too.

Regarding your first suggestion: I think the Run and Submit buttons do not have the same function.

The Run button runs the code you created, including any tests that you included, and prints anything your code says to print. It's the same as if you ran the code on your interpreter locally, with only the differences that might ensue from a different platform and Python version, and a limited run duration: the online interpreter stops if your program runs too long (thank goodness).
This allows you to pick up any errors that you might have introduced when you cut and pasted your code, or incompatibility errors.

The Submit button hands the code onto the Auto Grader, which runs tests of its own, the details of which we may never know. So unless your tests exactly match those of the Auto Grader, you may see a difference in result from Run and Submit.

I agree with you that it would be good to have a more precise specification for the expected output. Degree of precision for numeric answers would be excellent.

Such students not only help the beginner students through clear and professional explanations, but also help the motivated/intermediate students who seek a deeper level of understanding to reach that level. I found some forum discussions to be too advanced for me, but there were other posts without which I would be completely lost in the course. Because ST101 is still experimental and new, there were some topics/hw/units that were confusing and not self-contained, and advanced students helped clarify those for all the other students. def crawl_web(seed,max_depth):
    tocrawl = [[0, seed]]
    crawled = []
    while tocrawl:
        page       = tocrawl.pop()
        page_depth = page[0]
        page_url   = page[1]
        if ((page_url not in crawled) and (page_depth<=max_depth)):
            links       = get_all_links(get_page(page_url))
            links_depth = []
            for i in links:
                links_depth.append([page_depth+1,i])
            union(tocrawl, links_depth)
            crawled.append(page_url)
    return crawled

The heading for the starting post of this thread creates a misleading impression.

What is being said is this: this sudden glorious revolution in online education, pioneered by Khan Academy, Udacity and several established mainstream universities, is now gaining enough momentum to shift society in a more open and fair direction.

But there are two problems:

  1. The online course pioneers have not yet discovered how to offer you an education that takes no time and work on your part.

  2. They haven't yet completely shifted the Zeitgeist to the point where the online qualifications have the same chic as the qualifications from the old establishment.

Regarding Problem 1, I don't think it is going to be solved, until someone figures out how to induce connections directly in your brain. I'm happy to be a lab rat for this Udacity experiment, but I do not want to be involved in that one.

However it may be that solving Problem 2 will increase the likelihood that employers will offer support and paid time to do the online courses.

And am I wrong, or do courses like this usually take a semester? Didn't we just cut the time by something like seventy percent? And no commuting! No cafeteria food!

As for the second problem:
This isn't a Problem, it's an Opportunity.

So maybe a better heading would have been:

Challenging Opportunities for Udacity and Coursera

def search():
    closed = [[0 for row in range(len(grid[0]))] for col in range(len(grid))]
    closed[init[0]][init[1]] = 1
    path = [[' ' for row in range(len(grid[0]))] for col in range(len(grid))]

    x = init[0]
    y = init[1]
    g = 0

    open = [[g, x, y]]

    found = False  # flag that is set when search is complet
    resign = False # flag set if we can't find expand

    while not found and not resign:
        if len(open) == 0:
            resign = True
            return 'fail'
        else:
            open.sort()
            open.reverse()
            next = open.pop()
            x = next[1]
            y = next[2]
            g = next[0]

            if x == goal[0] and y == goal[1]:
                found = True
            else:
                for dx, dy in delta:
                    x2, y2 = x + dx, y + dy
                    if x2 >= 0 and x2 < len(grid) and y2 >=0 and y2 < len(grid[0]):
                        if closed[x2][y2] == 0 and grid[x2][y2] == 0:
                            g2 = g + cost
                            open.append([g2, x2, y2])
                            closed[x2][y2] = g2 + 1
    x, y = goal
    path[x][y] = '*'
    while closed[x][y] > 1:
        for dx, dy in delta:
            x2, y2 = x + dx, y + dy
            if x2 >= 0 and x2 < len(grid) and y2 >=0 and y2 < len(grid[0]):
                if closed[x2][y2] == closed[x][y] - 1:
                    path[x2][y2] = delta_name[ [2, 3, 0, 1][(dx + 1) + (dy + 1) / 2]]
                    x, y = x2, y2
                    break

    return path# make sure you return the shortest path.

title: Final Multiword Queries:  What to do if the query phrase appears more than once?
body: If the query phrase appears twice in the content of a single url, should the output list include that url twice? It makes sense to me to only include the url once, but the original lookup function seems to include it twice.
Your divison is integer divison. The divison needs to be floating point. Then only the answer will be correct.

Your function has improper indents. However, even if we fix those you have other issues.

You should get in the habit of testing your functions with more than one or two test cases. Try to think of all of the possible inputs you could receive, and test thoroughly.

Assuming that we fixed the indents in your code here is the result of passing it some numbers:

print greatest([ 3, 16, 19]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs None
print greatest([ 3, 19, 16]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([16,  3, 19]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 16
print greatest([16, 19,  3]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([19,  3, 16]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([19, 16,  3]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([ 3,  3, 19]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs None
print greatest([ 3, 19,  3]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([19,  3,  3]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([ 3, 19, 19]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs None
print greatest([19,  3, 19]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([19, 19,  3]) # Should be 19 - Your code outputs 19
print greatest([16, 16, 16]) # Should be 16 - Your code outputs None

I think this fits more as an answer than an edit to the question, so here goes:

If you want to improve the search engine, there's a number of things you can do. I've tried to sort them by difficulty, with the easy ones first.

  1. Run the code and report any bugs.
  2. Write documentation for all functions and modules.
  3. Write tests for all functions.
  4. Add some code for a search engine front-end.
  5. Improve the add_page_to_index function to ignore words inside URLs and tags.
  6. Improve the crawl_web function to handle relative links better.
  7. Make get_all_links use a DOM parser to grab links.
  8. Make the crawler support unicode.
  9. Add a way to store the index to disk.
  10. Add a way to read the index from disk, and preferably to update it as well.
  11. Make the crawler respect robots.txt.
  12. Attach a web front-end to the search
  13. Make a way to rank results.
  14. Come up with a way to handle weird characters in words.
  15. Come up with a way to handle common misspellings.
  16. Come up with a good name for the search engine. (I don't like using the Udacity name, as we don't have official support.)

Further ideas are of course welcome. Feel free to contact me if you want to help and heed assistance with mercurial.

title: Request Sudoku analysis
tagnames: cs101 incorrect hw3.8 grader correct sudoku
body:
Someone more experienced please critique my solution.
The code runs fine in the Udacity interpreter in Chrome for Mac, it works for the various (some nefarious!) combinations I've listed at the bottom of this post, after the code. You may find the code verbose, but I've used only the tools taught prior to the HW in Q.

It's also worked for the cases given in hw3.8: Sudoku test cases lacking including those given in the 'accepted answer' by KeithE and further edited by jesyspa. I got the correct return even with the Jumbo Sudoku.
(Needless to say, I'm getting that "Incorrect. Your procedure did not return the correct value." grader message.)

I am not satisfied with my analysis of Sudoku Theory concerning 'completeness' of my algorithm. Here's an example of the question, unanswered, in my mind: for a 9 x 9 Sudoku, the sum of all elements = 1+2+3 .......+9 = 45. Is there another combination of 9 different numbers that can still total 45 without repeating a number?

(confession, I changed the erroneous u=s(1) to u=s(0) in the 'create_col(s)' def below, so as to adress the case ([[1]]), I am thrilled at being able to work at this level and the power of changing just one digit!)

def gridsum(d):        #for an 'n x n' sudoku, gives us the total = 1+2+. . .. +n
    s=1                    #each row and column total *should* equal this number 'gridsum'
    total=1
    while s!=d:
        s=s+1
        total=total+s
    return total

def sum(s):           #adds all the numbers in a row or column and,
    tot=0              
    grd=0
    for r in s:
        a=0
        if grd==0:
            l=len(r)
            grd=gridsum(l)
        grd=grd
        if tot!=0:
            tot=0
        while a<=l-1:
            tot=tot+r[a]
            a=a+1
        if tot!=grd:
            return 0      #returns 0 if **any** row or column total does not equal 'gridsum'
    return 1              #returns 1 if **all** row and column totals equal 'gridsum'

def norepeats(s):    #checks if any number is repeated more than once in a row or column
    for r in s:
        l=len(r)-1
        for i in r:
            a=1
            while a <=l:
                if a>r.index(i):
                    if i==r[a]:
                        return 0       #returns 0 if a number appears more than once \
                    a=a+1             #within **any** row or column
    return 1     #returns 1 if within **every** row and every column no number repeats itself

def create_col(s):   #creates the list of columns using 'index' and 'append' on the list of rows
    c=[]
    t=[]
    a=0
    u=s[0]
    l=len(u)
    while a<=l-1:
        if c!=[]:
            c=[]
        for r in s:
            c.append(r[a])
        t.append(c)
        a=a+1
    return t

#my algorithm consists of checking the sum of all numbers for each row and column equals 'gridsum',
#if this test is passed, then check if numbers repeated within any row or column. 
#If the totals are good and there are no repeats then the Sudoku is correct.

def check_sudoku(s):                                                
    if sum(s)==1 and sum(create_col(s))==1:
        if norepeats(s)==1 and norepeats(create_col(s))==1:
            return 'True'                                                            
    return 'False'

        #print check_sudoku([[1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2]])
        #print check_sudoku([[1,2,3,4],[2,3,1,3],[3,1,2,3],[4,4,4,4]])
        #print check_sudoku([[5,1,3,4,2],[4,2,5,3,1],[2,3,4,1,5],[1,4,2,5,3],[3,5,1,2,4]])
        #print check_sudoku([[4,4,4,4],[4,4,4,4],[4,4,4,4],[4,4,4,4]])
        #print check_sudoku([[2,2,2],[2,2,2],[2,2,2]])
        #print check_sudoku([[2,3,3,3,4],[1,3,3,3,5],[5,3,3,3,1],[4,3,3,3,2],[3,3,3,3,3]])
        #print check_sudoku([[2,2,2,2],[2,2,2,2],[2,2,2,2],[2,2,2,2]])

My Autograder Solution

This is how I suspect the autograder might work. This fits the observed behaviour.
This turns off stdout, then imports the entire program code, discarding output, then turns stdout back on.
Then it just calls the function using a specified test suite.
This uses the test cases from the assignment.

The code indenting is proving unpredictable. Everything before the comment # ----------- / autoGrade is in the autoGrade function.


 # autoGrader model
import sys
class NullDevice():
    def write(self, s):
        pass

original_stdout = sys.stdout  # keep a reference to STDOUT        
sys.stdout = NullDevice()  # redirect the real STDOUT
from final22q20 import *   # any output from the import is discarded
sys.stdout  = original_stdout # restore stdout

 # -----------
def autoGrade():

    ################# TESTING ##################

    # ------------------------------------------
    # solution check - Checks your path function using
    # data from list called test[]. Uncomment the call
    # to solution_check at the bottom to test your code.
    #
    def solution_check(test, epsilon = 0.00001, verbose=0):
        if verbose:
            print 'solution_check'
        answer_list = []
        for i in range(len(test[0])):
            user_cost = plan(test[0][i], test[1][i], test[2][i], test[3][i])
            true_cost = test[4][i]

                answer_list.append(1)
            else:
                answer_list.append(0)
        correct_answers = 0
        print
        for i in range(len(answer_list)):
            if answer_list[i] == 1:
                if verbose:
                    print 'Test case', i+1, 'passed!'
                correct_answers += 1
            else:
                if verbose:
                    print 'Test case', i+1, 'failed.'
        if correct_answers == len(answer_list):
            if verbose:
                print "\nYou passed all test cases!"
            return True
        else:
            if verbose:
                print "\nYou passed", correct_answers, "of", len(answer_list), "test cases. Try to get them all!"
            return False

    # Test Case 1 (FAST left lane)
    test_road1 = build_road(8, [100, 10, 1])
    lane_change_cost1 = 1.0 / 1000.0
    test_init1 = [len(test_road1) - 1, 0]
    test_goal1 = [len(test_road1) - 1, len(test_road1[0]) - 1]
    true_cost1 = 1.244

    # Test Case 2 (more realistic road)

    test_goal2 = [len(test_road2) - 1, len(test_road2[0]) - 1]

    # Test Case 3 (Obstacles included)

                  [40, 40, 40, 40, 40, 30, 20, 30, 40, 40, 40, 40, 40, 40, 40],
                  [30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30]] # right lane: 30 km/h
    lane_change_cost3 = 1.0 / 500.0
    test_init3 = [len(test_road3) - 1, 0]
    test_goal3 = [len(test_road3) - 1, len(test_road3[0]) - 1]
    true_cost3 = 0.355333333333

    # Test Case 4 (Slalom)
    test_road4 = [[50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 40,  0, 40, 50, 50,  0, 50, 50, 50, 50], # left lane: 50 km/h
                  [40, 40, 40, 40,  0, 30, 20, 30,  0, 40, 40, 40, 40, 40, 40],
                  [30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30]] # right lane: 30 km/h
    lane_change_cost4 = 1.0 / 65.0
    test_init4 = [len(test_road4) - 1, 0]
    test_goal4 = [len(test_road4) - 1, len(test_road4[0]) - 1]
    true_cost4 = 0.450641025641

    test_road5 = [[50, 50, ], # left lane: 50 km/h
                  [40, 40, ],
                  [30, 30, ]] # right lane: 30 km/h
    lane_change_cost5 = 1.0 / 65.0
    test_init5 = [len(test_road5) - 1, 0]
    test_goal5 = [len(test_road5) - 1, len(test_road5[0]) - 1]

    test_road6 = [[50, 50, 50, 50, ], # left lane: 50 km/h
                  [40, 40, 40, 40, ],
                  [30, 30, 30, 30, ]] # right lane: 30 km/h
    lane_change_cost6 = 1.0 / 65.0
    test_init6 = [len(test_road5) - 1, 0]
    test_goal6 = [len(test_road5) - 1, len(test_road6[0]) - 1]

    testing_suite = [[test_road1, test_road2, test_road3, test_road4],
                     [lane_change_cost1, lane_change_cost2, lane_change_cost3, lane_change_cost4],
                     [test_init1, test_init2, test_init3, test_init4],
                     [test_goal1, test_goal2, test_goal3, test_goal4],
                     [true_cost1, true_cost2, true_cost3, true_cost4]]
    return solution_check(testing_suite)

 # ----------- / autoGrade

if autoGrade():

title: Server Downtime
body:
Can we have a thread/question where we put the current Udacity server downtime and an estimate on how long it will take? Also, possibly in advance for future downtimes? In order to better plan our learning time.

2012-03-12 02:50 pm UTC/GMT: Currently down. [Server Error 500] Any information on how long it will take?
Here's a good article that will explain all things rounding.

Search the discussion forum. Various students have provided gorgeous visualisations using a range of technologies.
Search tags for visual or demo, then open all the posts tagged with likely tags. You'll learn a lot from reading the source for these visualisations:

Python/Tcl

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/14131/unit-3-graphical-demo-of-robot-localization-based-on-particle-filters

Python Turtle Graphics

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/26429/hw5-4-python-turtle-graphics-racetrack

Javascript/HTML5

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/32660/final-exam-visualization-demo-using-javascript-and-canvas

Java/Jython

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/13970/carsim-a-simple-simulator
  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/20913/a-simulation-visualization-update2

Python/Matplotlib/Pylab

http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/26065/what-do-you-use-for-visualizationplotting, http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/27485/hw5-1-and-matplotlib
http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/31515/visualization-code-for-final-exam-spoiler-free-pic-is-from-a-random-road-not-test-road
* http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/31405/visualisation-unit6-7-and-unit6_22

Google Docs or other spreadsheet

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/25324/tips-easily-visualize-the-robot-movement-or-smooth-path-in-google-docs

C#

  • http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs373/questions/18861/particle-filter-demo-and-visualization-tool-in-c-opensource

There's more out there.

The Python white-space as syntax issue is notorious. C++ and Java programmers find it difficult to take Python seriously for this reason. However, it makes it work well as a learning and teaching language, because your code is forced to be neat, and you have to visualise code blocks.

An even more terrible thing about Python is that variables are automatically created when you first mention them. This is part of Python's philosophy - run-time binding. You worry about what a variable means as late as possible in the process.

An IDE like Eclipse (PyDev) helps by issuing warnings, such as variable declared but not used.

This IDE also provides an excellent debugger. I would very strongly recommend firing the whole thing up the moment you have a problem with understanding what your code is doing. I wish I took my own advice more often.

  • http://www.eclipse.org/
  • http://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/pydev-python-ide-eclipse

I thought I was getting close to cracking hw6.3 star but then I got the error <built-in function="" sorted="">.

I tried to solve it using iteration because I couldn't figure out how to do it through recursion. Is this approach specifically forbidden?

I also had to change the code of the update function a little bit to

... 1./(1./var1 + 1./var2)

before the answers were correct. Otherwise it seemed to return integers for the variance.

I'm with Aushin on this one. Exponential was my gut feeling based on what was probably being asked, but in answering the question literally in how it was asked, I ended up with linear. No biggie. The pressure is now off to maintain a 100% :) Now just need to pick up my C average :)

CS373 assumes you are familiar with programming in general, and linear mathematics. CS101 won't teach you what you need to use in CS373. If you are not comfortable with basic matrix maths, you will need to go learn about that somewhere else. Simple matrix maths are actually pretty easy to learn, and there is a lot of good material out there on the web for that. You could start with wikipedia. The tricky bit about professor Thrun's matrix math class is that it is a class, so you will need to learn enough programming to follow Object Oriented Programming with classes etc. Really, CS373 is far beyond a beginner programmer. That said, I encourage you to follow along as best you can .

As a rule of thumb, usually 100 level courses like CS101 are first year university courses, and 300 level courses like CS373 are major-level courses, that is 3rd or 4th year courses (with appropriate prerequisite courses required).

title: Are all the 11 questions in final exam, of  equal weightage ?
body:
Hello,

A query to Dave, TAs:

The final exam has 8 + 3(Starred) questions. Is the score for final exam going to be calculated by assuming all problems are of same weightage i.e. if one gets 8 problems correct out of 11, would his score be exactly 72.72% or each final problem has different weightage? If yes, how is it going to work out?

I didn't mind 7.2. You're right in saying it's unlikely a student will come up with the efficient Levenshtein distance algorithm. However without knowing about that, I came up with a solution that works, as specified in the problem notes: don't worry about not handling much longer strings than those provided in the test cases.

My solution doesn't come back in any reasonable time if you use a really long string against a short one. I thought of ways to fix it, then found the Levenshtein wikipedia entry, located a Java version of the algorithm, translated to Python and tried it. It can handle in a fraction of a second words as long as you're ever likely to use.

http://www.merriampark.com/ld.htm

Basically it avoids the combinatorial explosion of my method. Mine was elegant but inefficient, like an antique car.

This was a great demonstration of the benefits of good algorithm design, which I'm
guessing is why David put it there.

title: Understanding recursion: the stack model
body:
Someone asked in to explain the recursion in the following code:

Before we start

x = [1]
y = x

In this example, x and y refer to the exact same list. If we call x.append(2), then y is affected too.

However,

x = [1]
y = x
y = y + [2]

After the third line, a new list is created, so y and x no longer refer to the same list.

Now to the problem

Here's Peter's code again. I've written line numbers on the left from L1 to L7 (line 1 to line 7)

L1    def deep_count(p):
L2       sum = 0
L3       for e in p:
L4           sum = sum + 1
L5           if is_list(e):
L6               sum = sum + deep_count(e)
L7       return sum

We're going to trace the code (that is, step through the code, a line at a time, like the Python interpreter might.

We want to see what happens for deep_count([1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]]).

First, let's look at L2:

sum = 0

This initializes the sum.

Next, let's look at this Lines 3-4:

for e in p:
    sum = sum + 1

e is either a non-list (a number or a string, typically) in which case it needs to be counted, or it is a list in which case the list needs to be counted (and later on its content).

This is the recursion magic (Lines 5-6):

    if is_list(e):
        sum = sum + deep_count(e)

deep_count(e) does a deep count of e and returns that value. This is added to sum.

OK, here's the recursion magic. Pay attention.

Each time a recursive call is made, a copy of all the input and local variables are made

Let's see this in action for the input: [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]]

Initially, after entering the for loop and doing sum = sum + 1

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 1, e = 1, p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [After Line 4]

e is not a list, so we go back to the top of the loop.

In the next iteration through

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 2, e = 3, p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [After Line 4]

sum is incremented by 1, e is 3, which is not a list, so we go back up to the top of the for loop.

In this next iteration,

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [After Line 4]

The sum already counts the list (so even if it's empty, it gets counted).

At this point e is a list, so a recursive call is made. In this call, a new p is created (set to [2, [7, 6], [], 5]), a new sum is created, initialized to 0, and we loop.

I'll write it like this:

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 0, p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 2]

Notice there are two copies of sum. We always use the one on the bottom.

When we reach the for loop and increment sum, we get:

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 1, e = 2, p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]

We go back to the top of the loop (since e is not a list). In the next iteration e is [7, 6].

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 2, e = [7,6], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]

e is a list, so we make a third recursive call. Another copy of p is made (set to [7, 6]) and another copy of sum is created. Let's jump into the loop for that call

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 2, e = [7,6], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]
      • (3rd recursive call) sum = 1, e = 7, p = [7, 6] [After Line 4]

e is not a list, so go back to the top of loop, set e to 6, increment sum to 2,

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 2, e = [7,6], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]
      • (3rd recursive call) sum = 2, e = 6, p = [7, 6] [After Line 4]

Notice, we have three copies of sum, three copies of e. We are done processing the list [7, 6] and return 2.

We remove the third line because we have completed the third recursive call.

The 2 is added in the code in the second recursive call (Line 6):

sum = sum + deep_count(e)

where e was [7, 6] from the second recursive call. So sum gets 2 more added to it to total 4.

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 4, e = [7,6], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 6]

Now, back to the top of the loop, sum gets incremented from 4 to 5, e is set to []

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 5, e = [], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]

e is a list, so we make a recursive call. In this case, a new p, and sum are created. p is []

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 5, e = [], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]
      • (3rd recursive call) sum = 0, p = [] [After Line 2]

Since p is empty, we don't go through the for loop, and merely return sum which is 0.

We add 0 to the sum of the second recursive call. This means sum is unchanged at 5.

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 5, e = [], p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 6]

Back to the top of the loop, and e is set to 5, we increment sum to 6.

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 3, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]
    • (2nd recursive call) sum = 6, e = 5, p = [2, [7, 6], [], 5] [After Line 4]

No more elements in this list. We return sum which is 6. This gets added to the sum from the first recursive call (in the line sum = sum + deep_count(e). sum is now 3 + 6 or 9.

  • (Initial recursive call) sum = 9, e = [2, [7, 6], [], 5], p = [1, 3, [2, [7, 6], [], 5]] [At Line 6]

We go back to the top of the loop in the first recursive call. There are no more elements left in the list, so we do return sum (at Line 7) which has 9, and that is the answer.

The Stack Model

This is the "stack" model. Each recursive call creates a new set of local variables. This does not necessarily copy the values in the variables, but merely points to them (thus variables from different recursive calls could refer to the same, say, list). sum is, however, created up to 3 times in our example, each with its own number (since numbers are immutable).

This wasn't explained in the lectures, presumably because they thought they could avoid this discussion. To be fair, most books don't cover it like this, but I like to, because it's not obvious, for example, that there are multiple sum variables.

The stack model works with any procedure, not just recursive methods.

Here's some simple code

L1 def sum(x, y):
L2     return x + y

L3 def doublePlusOne(n):
L4     val = sum(n, n) + 1
L5     return val

Suppose we call doublePlusOne(10). We start at Line 4

  • (doublePlusOne) n = 10

Then, this calls sum(10, 10) (we plug in 10 to n). This then calls sum

  • (doublePlusOne) n = 10 {Line 4]
    • (sum) x = 10, y = 10

We return x + y which is 10 + 10 or 20. We were in the middle of sum(n, n) + 1. The sum(n, n) evaluated to 20, so we add 20 + 1 to get 21.

We get,

  • (doublePlusOne) n = 10, val = 21 [After Line 5]

So the stack model works on any procedure call, not just recursive ones.

body:
How the printed values should be presented?

1
2

4

or it should look like in example as strings:
'1 * 1 = 1'
'1 * 2 = 2'
'2 * 1 = 2'
'2 * 2 = 4'
I believe that making the website compatible with popular versions of IE is on the TODO list, but for now the recommendation seems to be that you install Chrome or Firefox.
Use a custom one

If you get it, could you explain.

Should we add the gaussian to the distance ? The gaussian (random.gauss(0.0, self.distance_noise)) returns me value between -10 and 10. It is quiet a BIG noise especially for a mouvement of 20. Isn't it ?

Very interesting indeed. But I am pretty sure that even after this course it will be pretty difficult for any one of us to do all the coding/testing needed for all the different aspects... Maybe this could be done in teams?

I've used ARIA before (http://robots.mobilerobots.com/wiki/ARIA) and it was pretty good. Actually, one of the videos seems to show some output similar to ARIA's simulation, but it may just be a coincidence. It's C++, so it is quite easy to get it working if you are familiar with it.

I get the same result and the path seems correct to me, it does not violate any rule and costs less of the path that is supposed to be the correct solution.
Here is the relevant code I use:

        open.sort(lambda a, b: cmp(heuristic[a[1]][a[2]] + a[0], heuristic[b[1]][b[2]] + b[0]), reverse = True)
        #open.reverse()

Nice, that looks more mathmatical to me, in that way i can do

$$ \frac{7.2\pi}{\pi/2} = 14.4 \leftrightarrow 7.2\pi =(14+0.4)\frac{\pi}2 = 14 * \frac{\pi}2 + \frac25 * \frac{\pi}2 = 14 * \frac{\pi}2 + \frac{\pi}5$$

I have also realised I could have done below:

$$\frac{\pi}5 - \frac{\pi}2 = -\frac{3\pi}{10}$$

After correcting that rookie mistake I get the negative angle and the trig gives me $%x = -0.81*x_{max}$% :D

Thanks a lot for your help, I would still like to come up with solution as beautiful as Andy's though.
